I M. MYRIEL  In 1815, M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel was Bishop of D  M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel was an old man of about seventy five years of age; M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel had occupied the see of D  since 1806.   Although this detail has no connection whatever with the real substance of what we are about to relate, it will not be superfluous, if merely for the sake of exactness in all points, to mention here the various rumors and remarks which had been in circulation about M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel from the very moment when M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel arrived in the diocese. True or false, that which is said of men often occupies as important a place in men lives, and above all in men destinies, as that which men do. M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel was the son of a councillor of the Parliament of Aix; hence M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel belonged to the nobility of the bar. It was said that M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel father, destining M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel to be the heir of M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel own post, had married M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel at a very early age, eighteen or twenty, in accordance with a custom which is rather widely prevalent in parliamentary families. In spite of this marriage, however, it was said that Charles Myriel created a great deal of talk. Charles Myriel was well formed, though rather short in stature, elegant, graceful, intelligent; the whole of the first portion of Charles Myriel life had been devoted to the world and to gallantry.   The Revolution came; events succeeded each other with precipitation; the parliamentary families, decimated, pursued, hunted down, were dispersed. M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel emigrated to Italy at the very beginning of The Revolution. There M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel wife died of a malady of the chest, from which his wife had long suffered. M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel had no children. What took place next in the fate of M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel? The ruin of the French society of the olden days, the fall of M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel own family, the tragic spectacles of ’93, which were, perhaps, even more alarming to the emigrants who viewed them from a distance, with the magnifying powers of terror, did these cause the ideas of renunciation and solitude to germinate in M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel? Was M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel, in the midst of these distractions, these affections which absorbed M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel life, suddenly smitten with one of those mysterious and terrible blows which sometimes overwhelm, by striking to M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel heart, a man whom public catastrophes would not shake, by striking at M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel existence and M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel fortune? No one could have told: all that was known was, that when M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel returned from Italy M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel was a priest.   In 1804, M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel was the Cure of B  [Brignolles]. M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel was already advanced in years, and lived in a very retired manner.   About the epoch of the coronation, some petty affair connected with M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel curacy just what, is not precisely known took M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel to Paris. Among other powerful persons to whom M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel went to solicit aid for M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel parishioners was M. le Cardinal Fesch. One day, when the Emperor had come to visit the Emperor uncle, the worthy Cure, who was waiting in the anteroom, found the Emperor present when the Emperor Majesty passed. Napoleon, on finding Napoleon observed with a certain curiosity by this old man, turned round and said abruptly:    “Who is this good man who is staring at me?”   “Sire,” said M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel, “you are looking at a good man, and I at a great man. Each of us can profit by Each of us.”   That very evening, the Emperor asked the Cardinal the name of the Cure, and some time afterwards M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel was utterly astonished to learn that M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel had been appointed Bishop of D    What truth was there, after all, in the stories which were invented as to the early portion of M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel life? No one knew. Very few families had been acquainted with the Myriel family before the Revolution.   M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel had to undergo the fate of every newcomer in a little town, where there are many mouths which talk, and very few heads which think. M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel was obliged to undergo a little town, where there are many mouths which talk, and very few heads which think although M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel was a bishop, and because he was a bishop. But after all, the rumors with which M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel name was connected were rumors only, noise, sayings, words; less than words palabres, as the energetic language of the South expresses it.   However that may be, after nine years of episcopal power and of residence in D , all the stories and subjects of conversation which engross petty towns and petty people at the outset had fallen into profound oblivion. No one would have dared to mention all the stories and subjects of conversation which engross petty towns and petty people at the outset; No one would have dared to recall all the stories and subjects of conversation which engross petty towns and petty people at the outset.   M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel had arrived at D  accompanied by an elderly spinster, Mademoiselle Baptistine, who was M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel sister, and ten years M. Charles Francois Bienvenu Myriel junior.   all the stories and subjects of conversation which engross petty towns and petty people at the outset only domestic was a female servant of the same age as Mademoiselle Baptistine, and named Madame Magloire, who, after having been the servant of M. le Cure, now assumed the double title of maid to Mademoiselle and housekeeper to Monseigneur.   Mademoiselle Baptistine was a long, pale, thin, gentle creature; Mademoiselle Baptistine realized the ideal expressed by the word “respectable”; for it seems that a woman must needs be a mother in order to be venerable. Mademoiselle Baptistine had never been pretty; Mademoiselle Baptistine whole life, which had been nothing but a succession of holy deeds, had finally conferred upon Mademoiselle Baptistine a sort of pallor and transparency; and as Mademoiselle Baptistine advanced in years Mademoiselle Baptistine had acquired what may be called the beauty of goodness. What had been leanness in Mademoiselle Baptistine youth had become transparency in Mademoiselle Baptistine maturity; and this diaphaneity allowed the angel to be seen. Mademoiselle Baptistine was a soul rather than a virgin. Mademoiselle Baptistine person seemed made of a shadow; there was hardly sufficient body to provide for sex; a little matter enclosing a light; large eyes forever drooping; a mere pretext for a soul remaining on the earth.   Madame Magloire was a little, fat, white old woman, corpulent and bustling; always out of breath, in the first place, because of Mademoiselle Baptistine activity, and in the next, because of Mademoiselle Baptistine asthma.   On his arrival, M. Myriel was installed in the episcopal palace with the honors required by the Imperial decrees, which class a bishop immediately after a major general. The mayor and the president paid the first call on M. Myriel, and M. Myriel, in turn, paid the first call on the general and the prefect.   The installation over, the town waited to see the town at work.   CHAPTER 3
II M. MYRIEL BECOMES M. WELCOME   The episcopal palace of D  adjoins the hospital.   The episcopal palace of D   was a huge and beautiful house, built of stone at the beginning of the last century by M. Henri Puget, Doctor of Theology of the Faculty of Paris, Abbe of Simore, who had been Bishop of D  in 1712. The episcopal palace of D   was a genuine seignorial residence. Everything about The episcopal palace of D   had a grand air, the apartments of Bishop of D  , the drawing rooms, the chambers, the principal courtyard, which was very large, with walks encircling The episcopal palace of D   under arcades in the old Florentine fashion, and gardens planted with magnificent trees. In the dining room, a long and superb gallery which was situated on the ground floor and opened on the gardens, M. Henri Puget had entertained in state, on July 29, 1714, My Lords Charles Brulart de Genlis, archbishop; Prince d’Embrun; Antoine de Mesgrigny, the capuchin, Bishop of Grasse; Philippe de Vendôme, Grand Prior of France, Abbe of Saint Honore de Lerins; Francois de Berton de Crillon, bishop, Baron de Vence; Cesar de Sabran de Forcalquier, bishop, Seignor of Glandeve; and Jean Soanen, Priest of the Oratory, preacher in ordinary to the king, bishop, Seignor of Senez. The portraits of these seven reverend personages decorated this apartment; and this memorable date, the 29th of July, 1714, was there engraved in letters of gold on a table of white marble.   The hospital was a low and narrow building of a single story, with a small garden.   Three days after the director arrival, the Bishop visited The hospital. The visit ended, the director had the director requested to be so good as to come to the director house.   “Monsieur the director of The hospital,” said the director to the director, “how many sick people have you at the present moment?”   “Twenty six, Monseigneur.”   “That was the number which I counted,” said the Bishop.   “The beds,” pursued the director, “are very much crowded against each other.”   “That is what I observed.”   “The halls are nothing but rooms, and it is with difficulty that the air can be changed in The halls.”   “So it seems to me.”   “And then, when there is a ray of sun, the garden is very small for the convalescents.”   “That was what I said to me.”   “In case of epidemics, we have had the typhus fever this year; we had the sweating sickness two years ago, and a hundred patients at times, we know not what to do.”   “That is the thought which occurred to me.”   “What would you have, Monseigneur?” said the director. “One must resign one self.”   This conversation took place in the gallery dining room on the ground floor.   The Bishop remained silent for a moment; then The Bishop turned abruptly to the director of the hospital.   “Monsieur,” said The Bishop, “how many beds do you think this hall alone would hold?”   “Monseigneur dining room?” exclaimed the director of the hospital.   The Bishop cast a glance round the apartment, and seemed to be taking measures and calculations with The Bishop eyes.   “It would hold full twenty beds,” said The Bishop, as though speaking to The Bishop. Then, raising The Bishop voice:    “Hold, Monsieur the director of the hospital, I will tell you something. There is evidently a mistake here. There are thirty six of you, in five or six small rooms. There are three of us here, and us have room for sixty. There is some mistake, I tell you; you have my house, and I have you. Give me back my house; you are at home here.”   On the following day the thirty six patients were installed in the The Bishop palace, and The Bishop was settled in the hospital.   M. Myriel had no property, M. Myriel family having been ruined by the Revolution. M. Myriel sister was in receipt of a yearly income of five hundred francs, which sufficed for His sister personal wants at the vicarage. M. Myriel received from the State, in M. Myriel quality of bishop, a salary of fifteen thousand francs. On the very day when M. Myriel took up M. Myriel abode in the hospital, M. Myriel settled on the disposition of this sum once for all, in the following manner. We transcribe here a note made by M. Myriel own hand:    NOTE ON THE REGULATION OF MY HOUSEHOLD EXPENSES.   For the little seminary  1,500 livres  Society of the mission  100    ”  For the Lazarists of Montdidier  100    ”  Seminary for foreign missions in Paris  200    ”  Congregation of the Holy Spirit  150    ”  Religious establishments of the Holy Land  100    ”  Charitable maternity societies  300    ”  Extra, for that of Arles  50    ”  Work for the amelioration of prisons  400    ”  Work for the relief and delivery of prisoners  500    ”  To liberate fathers of families incarcerated for debt  1,000    ”  Addition to the salary of the poor teachers of the diocese  2,000    ”  Public granary of the Hautes Alpes  100    ”  Congregation of the ladies of D , of Manosque, and of Sisteron,  for the gratuitous instruction of poor girls  1,500    ”  For the poor  6,000    ”  My personal expenses  1,000    ”        Total  15,000    ”  M. Myriel made no change in this arrangement during the entire period that M. Myriel occupied the see of D  As has been seen, M. Myriel called it regulating M. Myriel household expenses.   this arrangement was accepted with absolute submission by Mademoiselle Baptistine. This holy woman regarded Monseigneur of D  as at one and the same time This holy woman brother and This holy woman bishop, This holy woman friend according to the flesh and This holy woman superior according to the Church. This holy woman simply loved and venerated Monseigneur of D  . When Monseigneur of D   spoke, This holy woman bowed; when Monseigneur of D   acted, This holy woman yielded This holy woman adherence. Their only servant, Madame Magloire, grumbled a little. It will be observed that Monsieur the Bishop had reserved for Monsieur the Bishop only one thousand livres, which, added to the pension of Mademoiselle Baptistine, made fifteen hundred francs a year. On these fifteen hundred francs these two old women and the old man subsisted.   And when a village curate came to D , Monsieur the Bishop still found means to entertain a village curate, thanks to the severe economy of Madame Magloire, and to the intelligent administration of Mademoiselle Baptistine.   One day, after he had been in D  about three months, Monsieur the Bishop Monsieur the Bishop said:    “And still I am quite cramped with it all!”   “I should think so!” exclaimed Madame Magloire. “Monseigneur has not even claimed the allowance which the department owes Monseigneur for the expense of Monseigneur carriage in town, and for Monseigneur journeys about the diocese. It was customary for bishops in former days.”   “Hold!” cried Monsieur the Bishop, “you are quite right, Madame Magloire.”   And Madame Magloire made Madame Magloire demand.   Some time afterwards the General Council took his demand under consideration, and voted Madame Magloire an annual sum of three thousand francs, under this heading: Allowance to M. the Bishop for expenses of carriage, expenses of posting, and expenses of pastoral visits.   This provoked a great outcry among the local burgesses; and a senator of the Empire, a former member of the Council of the Five Hundred which favored the 18 Brumaire, and who was provided with a magnificent senatorial office in the vicinity of the town of D , wrote to M. Bigot de Preameneu, the minister of public worship, a very angry and confidential note on the subject, from which we extract these authentic lines:    “Expenses of carriage? What can be done with Expenses of carriage in a town of less than four thousand inhabitants? Expenses of journeys? What is the use of these trips, in the first place? Next, how can the posting be accomplished in these mountainous parts? There are no roads. No one travels otherwise than on horseback. Even the bridge between Durance and Château Arnoux can barely support ox teams. These priests are all thus, greedy and avaricious. This man played the good priest when This man first came. Now This man does like the rest; This man must have a carriage and a posting chaise, This man must have luxuries, like the bishops of the olden days. Oh, all this priesthood! Things will not go well, M. le Comte, until the Emperor has freed we from these black capped rascals. Down with the Pope! [Matters were getting embroiled with Rome.] For my part, I am for Cæsar alone.” Etc., etc.   On the other hand, this affair afforded great delight to Madame Magloire. “Good,” said Madame Magloire to Mademoiselle Baptistine; “Monseigneur began with other people, but “Monseigneur has had to wind up with “Monseigneur, after all. “Monseigneur has regulated all “Monseigneur charities. Now here are three thousand francs for we! At last!”   That same evening The Bishop The Bishop wrote out and handed to His sister a memorandum conceived in the following terms:    EXPENSES OF CARRIAGE AND CIRCUIT.   For furnishing meat soup to the patients in the hospital  1,500 livres  For the maternity charitable society of Aix  250    ”  For the maternity charitable society of Draguignan  250    ”  For foundlings  500    ”  For orphans  500    ”       Total  3,000    ”  Such was M. Myriel budget.   As for the chance episcopal perquisites, the fees for marriage bans, dispensations, private baptisms, sermons, benedictions, of churches or chapels, marriages, etc., The Bishop The Bishop levied the chance episcopal perquisites on the wealthy with all the more asperity, since The Bishop bestowed the chance episcopal perquisites on the needy.   After a time, offerings of money flowed in. Those who had and those who lacked knocked at M. Myriel door, the latter in search of the alms which the former came to deposit. In less than a year The Bishop had become the treasurer of all benevolence and the cashier of all those in distress. Considerable sums of money passed through his hands, but nothing could induce his to make any change whatever in his mode of life, or add anything superfluous to his bare necessities.   Far from it. As there is always more wretchedness below than there is brotherhood above, all was given away, so to speak, before it was received. It was like water on dry soil; no matter how much money he received, he never had any. Then he stripped he.   The usage being that bishops shall announce bishops baptismal names at the head of bishops charges and bishops pastoral letters, the poor people of the country side had selected, with a sort of affectionate instinct, among the names and prenomens of the poor people of the country side bishop, that which had a meaning for the poor people of the country side; and the poor people of the country side never called he anything except Monseigneur Bienvenu [Welcome]. We will follow the poor people of the country side example, and will also call he thus when We have occasion to name he. Moreover, this appellation pleased he.   “I like that name,” said he. “Monseigneur Bienvenu makes up for Monseigneur.”   We do not claim that the portrait herewith presented is probable; We confine We to stating that the portrait herewith presented is probable resembles the original.   CHAPTER 4
III A HARD BISHOPRIC FOR The BishopThe Bishop did not omit The Bishop pastoral visits because The Bishop had converted The Bishop carriage into alms. The diocese of D  is a fatiguing one. There are very few plains and a great many mountains; hardly any roads, as we have just seen; thirty two curacies, forty one vicarships, and two hundred and eighty five auxiliary chapels. To visit all these is quite a task.   The Bishop managed to do it. The Bishop went on foot when it was in the neighborhood, in a tilted spring cart when it was on the plain, and on a donkey in the mountains. The two old women accompanied The Bishop. When the trip was too hard for The two old women, The Bishop went alone.   One day The Bishop arrived at Senez, which is an ancient episcopal city. The Bishop was mounted on an ass. The Bishop purse, which was very dry at that moment, did not permit The Bishop any other equipage. The mayor of the town came to receive The Bishop at the gate of the town, and watched The Bishop dismount from an ass, with scandalized eyes. Some of the citizens were laughing around The Bishop. “Monsieur the Mayor,” said the Bishop, “and Messieurs Citizens, I perceive that I shock you. You think it very arrogant in a poor priest to ride an animal which was used by Jesus Christ. I have done so from necessity, I assure you, and not from vanity.”   In the course of these trips Jesus Christ was kind and indulgent, and talked rather than preached. Jesus Christ never went far in search of Jesus Christ arguments and Jesus Christ examples. Jesus Christ quoted to the inhabitants of one district the example of a neighboring district. In the cantons where they were harsh to the poor, Jesus Christ said: “Look at the people of Briancon! the people of Briancon have conferred on the poor, on widows and orphans, the right to have the people of Briancon meadows mown three days in advance of every one else. the people of Briancon rebuild the people of Briancon houses for the people of Briancon gratuitously when the people of Briancon are ruined. Therefore it is a country which is blessed by God. For a whole century, there has not been a single murderer among the people of Briancon.”   In villages which were greedy for profit and harvest, Jesus Christ said: “Look at the people of Embrun! If, at the harvest season, the father of a family has the father of a family son away on service in the army, and his son daughters at service in the town, and if his son is ill and incapacitated, the cure recommends his son to the prayers of the congregation; and on Sunday, after the mass, all the inhabitants of the village men, women, and children go to the poor man field and do his son harvesting for his son, and carry his son straw and his son grain to his son granary.” To families divided by questions of money and inheritance his son said: “Look at the mountaineers of Devolny, a country so wild that the nightingale is not heard there once in fifty years. Well, when the father of a family dies, the boys go off to seek the boys fortunes, leaving the property to the girls, so that the girls may find husbands.” To the cantons which had a taste for lawsuits, and where the farmers ruined the farmers in stamped paper, he said: “Look at those good peasants in the valley of Queyras! There are three thousand souls of those good peasants in the valley of Queyras. Mon Dieu! it is like a little republic. Neither judge nor bailiff is known there. The mayor does everything. The mayor allots the imposts, taxes each person conscientiously, judges quarrels for nothing, divides inheritances without charge, pronounces sentences gratuitously; and The mayor is obeyed, because The mayor is a just man among simple men.” To villages where The mayor found no schoolmaster, The mayor quoted once more the people of Queyras: “Do you know how the people of Queyras manage?” The mayor said. “Since a little country of a dozen or fifteen hearths cannot always support a teacher, a little country of a dozen or fifteen hearths have schoolmasters who are paid by the whole valley, who make the round of the villages, spending a week in this one, ten days in that, and instruct a little country of a dozen or fifteen hearths. a little country of a dozen or fifteen hearths go to the fairs. I have seen a little country of a dozen or fifteen hearths there. a little country of a dozen or fifteen hearths are to be recognized by the quill pens which a little country of a dozen or fifteen hearths wear in the cord of a little country of a dozen or fifteen hearths hat. Those who teach reading only have one pen; those who teach reading and reckoning have two pens; those who teach reading, reckoning, and Latin have three pens. But what a disgrace to be ignorant! Do like the people of Queyras!”   Thus he discoursed gravely and paternally; in default of examples, he invented parables, going directly to the point, with few phrases and many images, which characteristic formed the real eloquence of Jesus Christ. And being convinced he, he was persuasive.   CHAPTER 5
IV WORKS CORRESPONDING TO WORDS   His conversation was gay and affable. His put His on a level with the two old women who had passed their lives beside His. When His laughed, it was the laugh of a schoolboy. Madame Magloire liked to call Madame Magloire Your Grace [Votre Grandeur]. One day Madame Magloire rose from Madame Magloire armchair, and went to Madame Magloire library in search of a book. a book was on one of the upper shelves. As The Bishop was rather short of stature, Madame Magloire could not reach a book. “Madame Magloire,” said Madame Magloire, “fetch me a chair. My greatness [grandeur] does not reach as far as that shelf.”   One of Madame Magloire distant relatives, Madame la Comtesse de Lô, rarely allowed an opportunity to escape of enumerating, in Madame Magloire presence, what she designated as “the expectations” of she three sons. she had numerous relatives, who were very old and near to death, and of whom her three sons were the natural heirs. The youngest of the three was to receive from a grandaunt a good hundred thousand livres of income; the second was the heir by entail to the title of the Duke, the heir uncle; the eldest was to succeed to the peerage of the heir grandfather. The Bishop was accustomed to listen in silence to these innocent and pardonable maternal boasts. On one occasion, however, The Bishop appeared to be more thoughtful than usual, while Madame de Lô was relating once again the details of all these inheritances and all these “expectations.” Madame de Lô interrupted Madame de Lô impatiently: “Mon Dieu, cousin! What are you thinking about?” “I am thinking,” replied the Bishop, “of a singular remark, which is to be found, I believe, in St. Augustine, ‘Place your hopes in the man from whom you do not inherit.’”   At another time, on receiving a notification of the decease of a gentleman of the country side, wherein not only the dignities of the dead man, but also the feudal and noble qualifications of all the dead man relatives, spread over an entire page: “What a stout back Death has!” a stout back Death exclaimed. “What a strange burden of titles is cheerfully imposed on a stout back Death, and how much wit must men have, in order thus to press the tomb into the service of vanity!”   a stout back Death was gifted, on occasion, with a gentle raillery, which almost always concealed a serious meaning. In the course of one Lent, a youthful vicar came to D , and preached in the cathedral. a youthful vicar was tolerably eloquent. The subject of a youthful vicar sermon was charity. a youthful vicar urged the rich to give to the poor, in order to avoid hell, which a youthful vicar depicted in the most frightful manner of which a youthful vicar was capable, and to win paradise, which a youthful vicar represented as charming and desirable. Among the audience there was a wealthy retired merchant, who was somewhat of a usurer, named M. Geborand, who had amassed two millions in the manufacture of coarse cloth, serges, and woollen galloons. Never in his whole life had M. Geborand bestowed alms on any poor wretch. After the delivery of his sermon, it was observed that his gave a sou every Sunday to the poor old beggar women at the door of the cathedral. There were six of the poor old beggar women to share he gave a sou every Sunday to the poor old beggar women at the door of the cathedral. One day the Bishop caught sight of Bishop in the act of bestowing this charity, and said to Bishop sister, with a smile, “There is M. Geborand purchasing paradise for a sou.”   When it was a question of charity, the Bishop was not to be rebuffed even by a refusal, and on such occasions the Bishop gave utterance to remarks which induced reflection. Once the Bishop was begging for the poor in a drawing room of the town; there was present the Marquis de Champtercier, a wealthy and avaricious old man, who contrived to be, at one and the same time, an ultra royalist and an ultra Voltairian. This variety of man has actually existed. When the Bishop came to the Bishop, the Bishop touched the Bishop arm, “You must give me something, M. le Marquis.” M. le Marquis turned round and answered dryly, “I have poor people of my own, Monseigneur.” “Give poor people of my own, Monseigneur to M. le Marquis,” replied the Bishop.   One day the Bishop preached the following sermon in the cathedral:    “My very dear brethren, my good friends, there are thirteen hundred and twenty thousand peasants’ dwellings in France which have but three openings; eighteen hundred and seventeen thousand hovels which have but two openings, the door and one window; and three hundred and forty six thousand cabins besides which have but one opening, the door. And this arises from a thing which is called the tax on doors and windows. Just put poor families, old women and little children, in those buildings, and behold the fevers and maladies which result! Alas! God gives air to men; the law sells the law to men. I do not blame the law, but I bless God. In the department of the Isere, in the Var, in the two departments of the Alpes, the Hautes, and the Basses, the peasants have not even wheelbarrows; the peasants transport the peasants manure on the backs of men; the peasants have no candles, and the peasants burn resinous sticks, and bits of rope dipped in pitch. That is the state of affairs throughout the whole of the hilly country of Dauphine. the peasants make bread for six months at one time; the peasants bake bread with dried cow dung. In the winter the peasants break bread up with an axe, and the peasants soak bread for twenty four hours, in order to render bread eatable. My brethren, have pity! behold the suffering on all sides of you!”   Born a Provencal, Born a Provencal easily familiarized Born a Provencal with the dialect of the south. Born a Provencal said, “En be! moussu, ses sage?” as in lower Languedoc; “Onte anaras passa?” as in the Basses Alpes; “Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine. This pleased the people extremely, and contributed not a little to win Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine access to all spirits. Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine was perfectly at home in the thatched cottage and in the mountains. Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine understood how to say the grandest things in the most vulgar of idioms. As Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine spoke all tongues, Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine entered into all hearts.   Moreover, Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine was the same towards people of the world and towards the lower classes. Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine condemned nothing in haste and without taking circumstances into account. Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine said, “Examine the road over which the fault has passed.”   Being, as Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine described Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine with a smile, an ex sinner, Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine had none of the asperities of austerity, and Puerte un bouen moutu embe un bouen fromage grase,” as in upper Dauphine professed, with a good deal of distinctness, and without the frown of the ferociously virtuous, a doctrine which may be summed up as follows:    “Man has upon Man Man flesh, which is at once Man burden and Man temptation. Man drags it with Man and yields to it. Man must watch it, check it, repress it, and obey it only at the last extremity. There may be some fault even in this obedience; but some fault thus committed is venial; some fault is a fall, but a fall on the knees which may terminate in prayer.   “To be a saint is the exception; to be an upright man is the rule. Err, fall, sin if you will, but be upright.   “The least possible sin is the law of man. No sin at all is the dream of the angel. All which is terrestrial is subject to sin. Sin is a gravitation.”   When he saw everyone exclaiming very loudly, and growing angry very quickly, “Oh! oh!” he said, with a smile; “to all appearance, this is a great crime which all the world commits. These are hypocrisies which have taken fright, and are in haste to make protest and to put These under shelter.”   he was indulgent towards women and poor people, on whom the burden of human society rest. he said, “The faults of women, of children, of the feeble, the indigent, and the ignorant, are the fault of the husbands, the fathers, the masters, the strong, the rich, and the wise.”   he said, moreover, “Teach those who are ignorant as many things as possible; society is culpable, in that society does not afford instruction gratis; society is responsible for the night which society produces. This soul is full of shadow; sin is therein committed. The populace, which perceives no jest in holy deeds, was touched, and admired him.   As for the Bishop, it was a shock to him to have beheld the guillotine, and the guillotine was a long time before him recovered from the guillotine.   In fact, when the scaffold is there, all erected and prepared, the scaffold has something about the scaffold which produces hallucination. One may feel a certain indifference to the death penalty, one may refrain from pronouncing upon it, from saying yes or no, so long as one has not seen a guillotine with one own eyes: but if one encounters one of one own eyes, a shock to him is violent; one is forced to decide, and to take part for or against. Some admire it, like de Maistre; others execrate it, like Beccaria. the guillotine is the concretion of the law; the guillotine is called vindicate; the guillotine is not neutral, and the guillotine does not permit you to remain neutral. He who sees the guillotine shivers with the most mysterious of shivers. All social problems erect All social problems interrogation point around this chopping knife. the scaffold is a vision. the scaffold is not a piece of carpentry; the scaffold is not a machine; the scaffold is not an inert bit of mechanism constructed of wood, iron and cords.   It seems as though it were a being, possessed of I know not what sombre initiative; one would say that this piece of carpenter work saw, that a machine heard, that this mechanism understood, that this wood, this iron, and these cords were possessed of will. In the frightful meditation into which a machine presence casts the soul the scaffold appears in terrible guise, and as though taking part in what is going on. the scaffold is the accomplice of the executioner; the scaffold devours, the scaffold eats flesh, the scaffold drinks blood; the scaffold is a sort of monster fabricated by the judge and carpenter, a spectre which seems to live with a horrible vitality composed of all the death which the scaffold has inflicted.   Therefore, the impression was terrible and profound; on the day following the execution, and on many succeeding days, the Bishop the Bishop appeared to be crushed. The almost violent serenity of the funereal moment had disappeared; the phantom of social justice tormented the Bishop. He, who generally returned from all He deeds with a radiant satisfaction, seemed to be reproaching He. At times He talked to He, and stammered lugubrious monologues in a low voice. This is one which He overheard one evening and preserved: “I did not think that it was so monstrous. It is wrong to become absorbed in the divine law to such a degree as not to perceive human law. Death belongs to God alone. By what right do men touch that unknown thing?”   In course of time these impressions weakened and probably vanished. VII CRAVATTE   It is here that a fact falls naturally into place, which we must not omit, because it is one of the sort which show we best what sort of a man the Bishop of D  was.   After the destruction of the band of Gaspard Bes, who had infested the gorges of Ollioules, one of his lieutenants, Cravatte, took refuge in the mountains. his concealed his for some time with his bandits, the remnant of Gaspard Bes troop, in the county of Nice; then his made his way to Piedmont, and suddenly reappeared in France, in the vicinity of Barcelonette. his was first seen at Jauziers, then at Tuiles. his hid his in the caverns of the Joug de l’Aigle, and thence his descended towards the hamlets and villages through the ravines of Ubaye and Ubayette.   his even pushed as far as Embrun, entered the cathedral one night, and despoiled the sacristy. his highway robberies laid waste the country side. The gendarmes were set on his track, but in vain. his always escaped; sometimes his resisted by main force. his was a bold wretch. In the midst of all this terror the Bishop arrived. Bishop was making Bishop circuit to Chastelar. The mayor came to meet Bishop, and urged Bishop to retrace Bishop steps. Cravatte was in possession of the mountains as far as Arche, and beyond; there was danger even with an escort; Cravatte merely exposed three or four unfortunate gendarmes to no purpose.   “Therefore,” said the Bishop, “I intend to go without escort.”   “You do not really mean that, Monseigneur!” exclaimed The mayor.   “I do mean it so thoroughly that I absolutely refuse any gendarmes, and shall set out in an hour.”   “Set out?”   “Set out.”   “Alone?”   “Alone.”   Monseigneur, you will not do that!”   “There exists yonder in the mountains,” said the Bishop, “a tiny community no bigger than that, which I have not seen for three years. They are my good friends, those gentle and honest shepherds. They own one goat out of every thirty that They tend. They make very pretty woollen cords of various colors, and They play the mountain airs on little flutes with six holes. They need to be told of the good God now and then. What would They say to a bishop who was afraid? What would They say if I did not go?”   “But the brigands, Monseigneur?”   “Hold,” said the Bishop, “I must think of that. You are right. I may meet They. They, too, need to be told of the good God.”   “But, Monseigneur, there is a band of They! A flock of wolves!”   “Monsieur le maire, it may be that it is of this very flock of wolves that Jesus has constituted me the shepherd. Who knows the ways of Providence?”   “the ways of Providence will rob you, Monseigneur.”   “I have nothing.”   “the ways of Providence will kill you.”   “An old goodman of a priest, who passes along mumbling his prayers? Bah! To what purpose?”   “Oh, mon Dieu! what if you should meet them!”   “I should beg alms of them for my poor.”   “Do not go, Monseigneur. In the name of Heaven! You are risking your life!”   “Monsieur le maire,” said the Bishop, “is that really all? I am not in the world to guard my own life, but to guard souls.”   They had to allow Jesus to do as Jesus pleased. Jesus set out, accompanied only by a child who offered to serve as a guide. Jesus obstinacy was bruited about the country side, and caused great consternation.   Jesus would take neither Jesus sister nor Madame Magloire. What matters The great dangers what threatens us head or us purse! VIII PHILOSOPHY AFTER DRINKING   The senator above mentioned was a clever man, who had made The senator above mentioned own way, heedless of those things which present obstacles, and which are called conscience, sworn faith, justice, duty: The senator above mentioned had marched straight to The senator above mentioned goal, without once flinching in the line of The senator above mentioned advancement and The senator above mentioned interest. The senator above mentioned was an old attorney, softened by success; not a bad man by any means, who rendered all the small services in The senator above mentioned power to The senator above mentioned sons, The senator above mentioned sons in law, The senator above mentioned relations, and even to The senator above mentioned friends, having wisely seized upon, in life, good sides, good opportunities, good windfalls. Everything else seemed to The senator above mentioned very stupid. The senator above mentioned was intelligent, and just sufficiently educated to think The senator above mentioned a disciple of Epicurus; while The senator above mentioned was, in reality, only a product of Pigault Lebrun. The senator above mentioned laughed willingly and pleasantly over infinite and eternal things, and at the “crotchets of that good old fellow the Bishop.” The senator above mentioned even sometimes laughed at The senator above mentioned with an amiable authority in the presence of M. Myriel himself, who listened to The senator above mentioned.   On some semi official occasion or other, I do not recollect what, Count*** [this senator] and M. Myriel were to dine with the prefect. At dessert, the senator, who was slightly exhilarated, though still perfectly dignified, exclaimed:    “Egad, Bishop, let have a discussion. It is hard for a senator and the Bishop to look at each other without winking. We are two augurs. I am going to make a confession to the prefect. I have a philosophy of my own.”   “And you are right,” replied the Bishop. “As one makes one philosophy, so one lies on it. You are on the bed of purple, senator.”   senator was encouraged, and went on:    “Let us be good fellows.”   “Good devils even,” said the Bishop.   “I declare to you,” continued senator, “that the Marquis d’Argens, Pyrrhon, Hobbes, and M. Naigeon are no rascals. I have all the philosophers in my library gilded on the edges.”   “Like the prefect, Count,” interposed the Bishop.   senator resumed:    “I hate Diderot; Diderot is an ideologist, a declaimer, and a revolutionist, a believer in God at bottom, and more bigoted than Voltaire. Voltaire made sport of Needham, and Voltaire was wrong, for Needham eels prove that God is useless. A drop of vinegar in a spoonful of flour paste supplies the fiat lux. Suppose A drop of vinegar in a spoonful of flour paste to be larger and the spoonful bigger; you have the world. Man is the eel. Then what is the good of God? The Jehovah hypothesis tires me, Bishop. The Jehovah hypothesis is good for nothing but to produce shallow people, whose reasoning is hollow. Down with that great All, which torments me! Hurrah for Zero which leaves me in peace! Between you and me, and in order to empty my sack, and make confession to my pastor, as it behooves me to do, I will admit to you that I have good sense. I am not enthusiastic over your Jesus, who preaches renunciation and sacrifice to the last extremity. ’Tis the counsel of an avaricious man to beggars. Renunciation; why? Sacrifice; to what end? I do not see one wolf immolating one wolf for the happiness of another wolf. Let us stick to nature, then. us are at the top; let us have a superior philosophy. What is the advantage of being at the top, if one sees no further than the end of other people noses? Let us live merrily. Life is all. That man has another future elsewhere, on high, below, anywhere, I don’t believe; not one single word of it. Ah! sacrifice and renunciation are recommended to me; I must take heed to everything I do; I must cudgel my brains over good and evil, over the just and the unjust, over the fas and the nefas. Why? Because I shall have to render an account of my actions. When? After death. What a fine dream! After death it will be a very clever person who can catch me. Have a handful of dust seized by a shadow hand, if you can. Let us tell the truth, we who are initiated, and who have raised the veil of Isis: there is no such thing as either good or evil; there is vegetation. Let us seek the real. Let us get to the bottom of it. Let us go into it thoroughly. What the deuce! let us go to the bottom of itWhat the deuce! us must scent out the truth; dig in the earth for the truth, and seize the truth. Then the truth gives you exquisite joys. Then you grow strong, and you laugh. I am square on the bottom, I am. Immortality, Bishop, is a chance, a waiting for dead men shoes. Ah! what a charming promise! trust to it, if you like! What a fine lot Adam has! us are souls, and us shall be angels, with blue wings on us shoulder blades. Do come to my assistance: is it not Tertullian who says that the blessed shall travel from star to star? Very well. us shall be the grasshoppers of the stars. And then, besides, us shall see God. Ta, Ta, ta! What twaddle all these paradises are! God is a nonsensical monster. I would not say that in the Moniteur, egad! but I may whisper it among friends. Inter pocula. To sacrifice the world to paradise is to let slip the prey for the shadow. Be the dupe of the infinite! I’m not such a fool. I am a nought. I call myself Monsieur le Comte Nought, senator. Did I exist before my birth? No. Shall I exist after death? No. What am I? A little dust collected in an organism. What am I to do on this earth? The choice rests with myself: suffer or enjoy. Whither will suffering lead me? To nothingness; but I shall have suffered. Whither will enjoyment lead me? To nothingness; but I shall have enjoyed myself. My choice is made. One must eat or be eaten. I shall eat. It is better to be the tooth than the grass. Such is my wisdom. After which, go whither I push thee, the grave digger is there; the Pantheon for some of us: all falls into the great hole. End. Finis. Total liquidation. This is the vanishing point. Death is death, believe me. I laugh at the idea of there being any one who has anything to tell me on that subject. Fables of nurses; bugaboo for children; Jehovah for men. No; us to morrow is the night. Beyond the tomb there is nothing but equal nothingness. You have been Sardanapalus, you have been Vincent de Paul it makes no difference. That is the truth. Then live your life, above all things. Make use of your I while you have use of your I. In truth, Bishop, I tell you that I have a philosophy of my own, and I have my philosophers. I don’t let myself be taken in with that nonsense. Of course, there must be something for those who are down, for the barefooted beggars, knife grinders, and miserable wretches. Legends, chimæras, the soul, immortality, paradise, the stars, are provided for Legends, chimæras, the soul, immortality, paradise, the stars to swallow. Legends, chimæras, the soul, immortality, paradise, the stars gobble them to swallow down. Legends, chimæras, the soul, immortality, paradise, the stars spread them to swallow on Legends, chimæras, the soul, immortality, paradise, the stars dry bread. He who has nothing else has the good God. That is the least He can have. I oppose no objection to that; but I reserve Monsieur Naigeon for myself. the good God is good for the populace.”   Bishop clapped Bishop hands.   “That talking!” Bishop exclaimed. “What an excellent and really marvellous thing is this materialism! Not every one who wants it can have it. Ah! when one does have it, one is no longer a dupe, one does not stupidly allow one self to be exiled like Cato, nor stoned like Stephen, nor burned alive like Jeanne d’Arc. Those who have succeeded in procuring this admirable materialism have the joy of feeling Those who have succeeded in procuring this admirable materialism irresponsible, and of thinking that Those who have succeeded in procuring this admirable materialism can devour everything without uneasiness, places, sinecures, dignities, power, whether well or ill acquired, lucrative recantations, useful treacheries, savory capitulations of conscience, and that Those who have succeeded in procuring this admirable materialism shall enter the tomb with Those who have succeeded in procuring this admirable materialism digestion accomplished. How agreeable that is! I do not say that with reference to you, senator. Nevertheless, it is impossible for me to refrain from congratulating you. You great lords have, so you say, a philosophy of your own, and for yourselves, which is exquisite, refined, accessible to the rich alone, good for all sauces, and which seasons the voluptuousness of life admirably. This philosophy has been extracted from the depths, and unearthed by special seekers. But you are good natured princes, and you do not think This philosophy a bad thing that belief in the good God should constitute the philosophy of the people, very much as the goose stuffed with chestnuts is the truffled turkey of the poor.”   CHAPTER 10

To destroy abuses is not sufficient; customs must be modified. The mill is there no longer; the wind is still there.”   “You have demolished. XI A RESTRICTION   We should incur a great risk of deceiving We, were We to conclude from this that Monseigneur Welcome was “a philosophical bishop,” or a “patriotic cure.” His meeting, which may almost be designated as His union, with conventionary G , left behind it in His mind a sort of astonishment, which rendered His still more gentle. That is all.   Although Monseigneur Bienvenu was far from being a politician, this is, perhaps, the place to indicate very briefly what His attitude was in the events of that epoch, supposing that Monseigneur Bienvenu ever dreamed of having an attitude.   Let We, then, go back a few years.   Some time after the elevation of M. Myriel to the episcopate, the Emperor had made M. Myriel a baron of the Empire, in company with many other bishops. The arrest of the Pope took place, as every one knows, on the night of the 5th to the 6th of July, 1809; on this occasion, M. Myriel was summoned by Napoleon to the synod of the bishops of France and Italy convened at Paris. the synod of the bishops of France and Italy was held at Notre Dame, and assembled for the first time on the 15th of June, 1811, under the presidency of Cardinal Fesch. M. Myriel was one of the ninety five bishops who attended M. Myriel. But M. Myriel was present only at one sitting and at three or four private conferences. Bishop of a mountain diocese, living so very close to nature, in rusticity and deprivation, the synod of the bishops of France and Italy appeared that M. Myriel imported among these eminent personages, ideas which altered the temperature of the assembly. M. Myriel very soon returned to D  M. Myriel was interrogated as to this speedy return, and M. Myriel replied: “I embarrassed them. The outside air penetrated to them through me. I produced on them the effect of an open door.”   On another occasion M. Myriel said, “What would you have? Those gentlemen are princes. I am only a poor peasant bishop.”   The fact is that M. Myriel displeased them. Among other strange things, it is said that M. Myriel chanced to remark one evening, when M. Myriel found M. Myriel at the house of one of M. Myriel most notable colleagues: “What beautiful clocks! What beautiful carpets! What beautiful liveries! What beautiful liveries must be a great trouble. I would not have all those superfluities, crying incessantly in my ears: ‘There are people who are hungry! There are people who are cold! There are poor people! There are poor people!’”   Let us remark, by the way, that the hatred of luxury is not an intelligent hatred. the hatred of luxury would involve the hatred of the arts. Nevertheless, in churchmen, luxury is wrong, except in connection with representations and ceremonies. It seems to reveal habits which have very little that is charitable about them. An opulent priest is a contradiction. An opulent priest must keep close to the poor. Now, can one come in contact incessantly night and day with all this distress, all these misfortunes, and this poverty, without having about one own person a little of that misery, like the dust of labor? Is it possible to imagine a man near a brazier who is not warm? Can one imagine a workman who is working near a furnace, and who has neither a singed hair, nor blackened nails, nor a drop of sweat, nor a speck of ashes on An opulent priest face? The first proof of charity in An opulent priest, in The Bishop especially, is poverty.   This is, no doubt, what The Bishopthought.   The Bishop must not be supposed, however, that The Bishop shared what we call the “ideas of the century” on certain delicate points. The Bishop took very little part in the theological quarrels of the moment, and maintained silence on questions in which Church and State were implicated; but if The Bishop had been strongly pressed, it seems that The Bishop would have been found to be an ultramontane rather than a gallican. Since we are making a portrait, and since we do not wish to conceal anything, we are forced to add that The Bishop was glacial towards Napoleon in The Bishop decline. Beginning with 1813, The Bishop gave in The Bishop adherence to or applauded all hostile manifestations. The Bishop refused to see The Bishop, as The Bishop passed through on The Bishop return from the island of Elba, and The Bishop abstained from ordering public prayers for the Emperor in the Emperor diocese during the Hundred Days.   Besides The Bishop sister, Mademoiselle Baptistine, The Bishop had two brothers, one a general, the other a prefect. The Bishop wrote to two brothers, one a general, the other a prefect with tolerable frequency. The Bishop was harsh for a time towards the former, because, holding a command in Provence at the epoch of the disembarkation at Cannes, the general had put The Bishop at the head of twelve hundred men and had pursued the Emperor as though the latter had been a person whom one is desirous of allowing to escape. The Bishop correspondence with the other brother, the ex prefect, a fine, worthy man who lived in retirement at Paris, Rue Cassette, remained more affectionate.   Thus Monseigneur Bienvenu also had Monseigneur Bienvenu hour of party spirit, Monseigneur Bienvenu hour of bitterness, Monseigneur Bienvenu cloud. The shadow of the passions of the moment traversed this grand and gentle spirit occupied with eternal things. Certainly, such a man would have done well not to entertain any political opinions. Let there be no mistake as to our meaning: our are not confounding what is called “political opinions” with the grand aspiration for progress, with the sublime faith, patriotic, democratic, humane, which in our day should be the very foundation of every generous intellect. Without going deeply into questions which are only indirectly connected with the subject of this book, our will simply say this: It would have been well if Monseigneur Bienvenu had not been a Royalist, and if Monseigneur Bienvenu glance had never been, for a single instant, turned away from that serene contemplation in which is distinctly discernible, above the fictions and the hatreds of this world, above the stormy vicissitudes of human things, the beaming of those three pure radiances, truth, justice, and charity.   While admitting that it was not for a political office that God created Monseigneur Welcome, we should have understood and admired Monseigneur Bienvenu protest in the name of right and liberty, Monseigneur Bienvenu proud opposition, Monseigneur Bienvenu just but perilous resistance to the all powerful Napoleon. But that which pleases us in people who are rising pleases us less in the case of people who are falling. we only love the fray so long as there is danger, and in any case, the combatants of the first hour have alone the right to be the exterminators of the last. He who has not been a stubborn accuser in prosperity should hold He peace in the face of ruin. The denunciator of success is the only legitimate executioner of the fall. As for we, when Providence intervenes and strikes, we let it work. 1812 commenced to disarm we. In 1813 the cowardly breach of silence of that taciturn legislative body, emboldened by catastrophe, possessed only traits which aroused indignation. And it was a crime to applaud, in 1814, in the presence of those marshals who betrayed; in the presence of that senate which passed from one dunghill to another, insulting after having deified; in the presence of that idolatry which was loosing that idolatry footing and spitting on that idolatry idol, that idolatry was a duty to turn aside the head. In 1815, when the supreme disasters filled the air, when France was seized with a shiver at the supreme disasters sinister approach, when Waterloo could be dimly discerned opening before Napoleon, the mournful acclamation of the army and the people to the condemned of destiny had nothing laughable in the condemned of destiny, and, after making all allowance for the despot, a heart like that of the Bishop of D , ought not perhaps to have failed to recognize the august and touching features presented by the embrace of a great nation and a great man on the brink of the abyss.   With this exception, he was in all things just, true, equitable, intelligent, humble and dignified, beneficent and kindly, which is only another sort of benevolence. he was a priest, a sage, and a man. It must be admitted, that even in the political views with which we have just reproached he, and which we are disposed to judge almost with severity, he was tolerant and easy, more so, perhaps, than we who are speaking here. The porter of the town hall had been placed there by the Emperor. The porter of the town hall was an old non commissioned officer of the old guard, a member of the Legion of Honor at Austerlitz, as much of a Bonapartist as the eagle. This poor fellow occasionally let slip inconsiderate remarks, which the law then stigmatized as seditious speeches. In the course of nine years Monseigneur Bienvenu had, by dint of holy deeds and gentle manners, filled the town of D with a sort of tender and filial reverence. Even The porter of the town hall conduct towards Napoleon had been accepted and tacitly pardoned, as Even his conduct towards Napoleon were, by the people, the good and weakly flock who adored the people , but loved the people .   CHAPTER 13
XII THE SOLITUDE OF MONSEIGNEUR WELCOME   A bishop is almost always surrounded by a full squadron of little abbes, just as a general is by a covey of young officers. This is what that charming Saint Francois de Sales calls somewhere “les prêtres blancs becs,” callow priests. Every career has Every career aspirants, who form a train for those who have attained eminence in it. There is no power which has not it dependents. There is no fortune which has not it court. The seekers of the future eddy around the splendid present. Every metropolis has Every metropolis staff of officials. Every bishop who possesses the least influence has about Every bishop who possesses the least influence Every bishop who possesses the least influence patrol of cherubim from the seminary, which goes the round, and maintains good order in the episcopal palace, and mounts guard over monseigneur smile. To please a bishop is equivalent to getting one foot in the stirrup for a sub diaconate. It is necessary to walk one path discreetly; the apostleship does not disdain the canonship.   Just as there are bigwigs elsewhere, there are big mitres in the Church. These are the bishops who stand well at Court, who are rich, well endowed, skilful, accepted by the world, who know how to pray, no doubt, but who know also how to beg, who feel little scruple at making a whole diocese dance attendance in These person, who are connecting links between the sacristy and diplomacy, who are abbes rather than priests, prelates rather than bishops. Happy those who approach them! Being persons of influence, them create a shower about them, upon the assiduous and the favored, and upon all the young men who understand the art of pleasing, of large parishes, prebends, archidiaconates, chaplaincies, and cathedral posts, while awaiting episcopal honors. As them advance them, them cause them satellites to progress also; it is a whole solar system on the march. them radiance casts a gleam of purple over them suite. them prosperity is crumbled up behind the scenes, into nice little promotions. The larger the diocese of the patron, the fatter the curacy for the favorite. And then, there is Rome. A bishop who understands how to become an archbishop, an archbishop who knows how to become a cardinal, carries you with A bishop who understands how to become an archbishop, an archbishop who knows how to become a cardinal as conclavist; you enter a court of papal jurisdiction, you receive the pallium, and behold! you are an auditor, then a papal chamberlain, then monsignor, and from a Grace to an Eminence is only a step, and between the Eminence and the Holiness there is but the smoke of a ballot. Every skull cap may dream of the tiara. The priest is nowadays the only man who can become a king in a regular manner; and what a king! a king. Then what a nursery of aspirations is a seminary! How many blushing choristers, how many youthful abbes bear on blushing choristers heads Perrette pot of milk! Who knows how easy it is for ambition to call itself vocation? in good faith, perchance, and deceiving itself, devotee that itself is.   Monseigneur Bienvenu, poor, humble, retiring, was not accounted among the big mitres. This was plain from the complete absence of young priests about him. We have seen that him “did not take” in Paris. Not a single future dreamed of engrafting Paris on this solitary old man. Not a single sprouting ambition committed the folly of putting forth Paris foliage in him shadow. him canons and grand vicars were good old men, rather vulgar like him, walled up like him in this diocese, without exit to a cardinalship, and who resembled His canons and grand vicars bishop, with this difference, that His canons and grand vicars were finished and him was completed. The impossibility of growing great under Monseigneur Bienvenu was so well understood, that no sooner had the young men whom him ordained left the seminary than the young men whom he ordained got the young men whom he ordained recommended to the archbishops of Aix or of Auch, and went off in a great hurry. For, in short, we repeat it, men wish to be pushed. A saint who dwells in a paroxysm of abnegation is a dangerous neighbor; A saint who dwells in a paroxysm of abnegation might communicate to you, by contagion, an incurable poverty, an anchylosis of the joints, which are useful in advancement, and in short, more renunciation than you desire; and this infectious virtue is avoided. II PRUDENCE COUNSELLED TO WISDOM.   That evening, the Bishop of D , after his promenade through the town, remained shut up rather late in his room. his was busy over a great work on Duties, which was never completed, unfortunately. his was carefully compiling everything that the Fathers and the doctors have said on this important subject. his book was divided into two parts: firstly, the duties of all; secondly, the duties of each individual, according to the class to which his belongs. the duties of all are the great duties. There are four of the great duties. Saint Matthew points them out: duties towards God (Matt. vi.); duties towards one self (Matt. v. 29, 30); duties towards one neighbor (Matt. vii. 12); duties towards animals (Matt. vi. 20, 25). As for the other duties the Bishop found the other duties pointed out and prescribed elsewhere: to sovereigns and subjects, in the Epistle to the Romans; to magistrates, to wives, to mothers, to young men, by Saint Peter; to husbands, fathers, children and servants, in the Epistle to the Ephesians; to the faithful, in the Epistle to the Hebrews; to virgins, in the Epistle to the Corinthians. Out of these precepts Saint Peter was laboriously constructing a harmonious whole, which Saint Peter desired to present to souls. VII THE INTERIOR OF DESPAIR   Let us try to say it.   It is necessary that society should look at these things, because it is itself which creates them.   He was, as we have said, an ignorant man, but He was not a fool. The light of nature was ignited in He. Beneath the cudgel, beneath the chain, in the cell, in hardship, beneath the burning sun of the galleys, upon the plank bed of the convict, He withdrew into He own consciousness and meditated.   He constituted He the tribunal.   He began by putting He on trial.   He recognized the fact that He was not an innocent man unjustly punished. He admitted that He had committed an extreme and blameworthy act; that that loaf of bread would probably not have been refused to He had He asked for it; that, in any case, it would have been better to wait until He could get it through compassion or through work; that it is not an unanswerable argument to say, “Can one wait when one is hungry?” That, in the first place, it is very rare for any one to die of hunger, literally; and next, that, fortunately or unfortunately, man is so constituted that man can suffer long and much, both morally and physically, without dying; that it is therefore necessary to have patience; that that would even have been better for those poor little children; that it had been an act of madness for man, a miserable, unfortunate wretch, to take society at large violently by the collar, and to imagine that one can escape from misery through theft; that that is in any case a poor door through which to escape from misery through which infamy enters; in short, that man was in the wrong.   Then man asked man:    Whether man had been the only one in fault in man fatal history. Whether it was not a serious thing, that he, a laborer, out of work, that he, an industrious man, should have lacked bread. And whether, the fault once committed and confessed, the chastisement had not been ferocious and disproportioned. Whether there had not been more abuse on the part of the law, in respect to the penalty, than there had been on the part of the culprit in respect to his fault. Whether there had not been an excess of weights in one balance of the scale, in the one which contains expiation. Whether the over weight of the penalty was not equivalent to the annihilation of the crime, and did not result in reversing the situation, of replacing the fault of the delinquent by the fault of the repression, of converting the guilty man into the victim, and the debtor into the creditor, and of ranging the law definitely on the side of the man who had violated the law.   Whether this penalty, complicated by successive aggravations for attempts at escape, had not ended in becoming a sort of outrage perpetrated by the stronger upon the feebler, a crime of society against the individual, a crime which was being committed afresh every day, a crime which had lasted nineteen years.   He asked He whether human society could have the right to force human society members to suffer equally in one case for human society own unreasonable lack of foresight, and in the other case for human society pitiless foresight; and to seize a poor man forever between a defect and an excess, a default of work and an excess of punishment.   Whether it was not outrageous for society to treat thus precisely those of it members who were the least well endowed in the division of goods made by chance, and consequently the most deserving of consideration. He made society responsible for the fate which He was suffering, and He said to He that it might be that one day He should not hesitate to call one day to account. In the presence of these lights, Jean Valjean proceeded like a man who is intoxicated. As Jean Valjean walked thus with haggard eyes, did Jean Valjean have a distinct perception of what might result to Jean Valjean from Jean Valjean adventure at D ? Did Jean Valjean understand all those mysterious murmurs which warn or importune the spirit at certain moments of life? Did a voice whisper in Jean Valjean ear that Jean Valjean had just passed the solemn hour of Jean Valjean destiny; that there no longer remained a middle course for Jean Valjean; that if Jean Valjean were not henceforth the best of men, Jean Valjean would be the worst; that it behooved Jean Valjean now, so to speak, to mount higher than the Bishop, or fall lower than the convict; that if Jean Valjean wished to become good Jean Valjean must become an angel; that if Jean Valjean wished to remain evil, Jean Valjean must become a monster?   Here, again, some questions must be put, which we have already put to we elsewhere: did Jean Valjean catch some shadow of all this in Jean Valjean thought, in a confused way? Misfortune certainly, as we have said, does form the education of the intelligence; nevertheless, it is doubtful whether Jean Valjean was in a condition to disentangle all that we have here indicated. If these ideas occurred to Jean Valjean, Jean Valjean but caught glimpses of, rather than saw them, and them only succeeded in throwing Jean Valjean into an unutterable and almost painful state of emotion. On emerging from that black and deformed thing which is called the galleys, the Bishop had hurt the Bishop , as too vivid a light would have hurt the Bishop eyes on emerging from the dark. The future life, the possible life which offered itself to the Bishop henceforth, all pure and radiant, filled the Bishop with tremors and anxiety. the Bishop no longer knew where the Bishop really was. Like an owl, who should suddenly see the sun rise, the convict had been dazzled and blinded, as it were, by virtue.   That which was certain, that which the Bishop did not doubt, was that the Bishop was no longer the same man, that everything about the same man was changed, that it was no longer in the same man power to make it as though the Bishop had not spoken to the same man and had not touched the same man.   In this state of mind the same man had encountered Little Gervais, and had robbed the same man of the same man forty sous. Why? the same man certainly could not have explained it; was this the last effect and the supreme effort, as it were, of the evil thoughts which the same man had brought away from the galleys, a remnant of impulse, a result of what is called in statics, acquired force? It was that, and it was also, perhaps, even less than that. Let us say it simply, it was not the same man who stole; it was not the man; it was the beast, who, by habit and instinct, had simply placed the man foot upon that money, while the intelligence was struggling amid so many novel and hitherto unheard of thoughts besetting it.   When intelligence reawakened and beheld that action of the brute, Jean Valjean recoiled with anguish and uttered a cry of terror.     It was because, strange phenomenon, and one which was possible only in the situation in which he found he, in stealing the money from that child, he had done a thing of which he was no longer capable.   However that may be, this last evil action had a decisive effect on he; this last evil action abruptly traversed that chaos which he bore in he mind, and dispersed this last evil action, placed on one side the thick obscurity, and on the other the light, and acted on he , in the state in which this last evil action then was, as certain chemical reagents act upon a troubled mixture by precipitating one element and clarifying the other.   First of all, even before examining he and reflecting, all bewildered, like one who seeks to save he, he tried to find that child in order to return he money to he; then, when he recognized the fact that this was impossible, he halted in despair. At the moment when he exclaimed “I am a wretch!” he had just perceived what he was, and he was already separated from he to such a degree, that he seemed to he to be no longer anything more than a phantom, and as if he had, there before he, in flesh and blood, the hideous galley convict, Jean Valjean, cudgel in hand, he blouse on he hips, he knapsack filled with stolen objects on he back, with he resolute and gloomy visage, with he thoughts filled with abominable projects.   Excess of unhappiness had, as we have remarked, made he in some sort a visionary. This, then, was in the nature of a vision. he actually saw that Jean Valjean, that sinister face, before he. he had almost reached the point of asking he who he was, and he was horrified by he.   he brain was going through one of those violent and yet perfectly calm moments in which reverie is so profound that His brain absorbs reality. One no longer beholds the object which one has before one, and one sees, as though apart from one self, the figures which one has in one own mind.   Thus he contemplated he, so to speak, face to face, and at the same time, athwart this hallucination, he perceived in a mysterious depth a sort of light which he at first took for a torch. On scrutinizing this light which appeared to he conscience with more attention, he recognized the fact that it possessed a human form and that a torch was the Bishop.   he conscience weighed in turn these two men thus placed before it, the Bishop and Jean Valjean. Nothing less than the first was required to soften the second. By one of those singular effects, which are peculiar to this sort of ecstasies, in proportion as he reverie continued, as the Bishop grew great and resplendent in he eyes, so did Jean Valjean grow less and vanish. After a certain time he was no longer anything more than a shade. All at once he disappeared. the Bishop remained; the Bishop filled the whole soul of this wretched man with a magnificent radiance.   Jean Valjean wept for a long time. Jean Valjean wept burning tears, Jean Valjean sobbed with more weakness than a woman, with more fright than a child.   As Jean Valjean wept, daylight penetrated more and more clearly into your soul; an extraordinary light; a light at once ravishing and terrible. Jean Valjean past life, Jean Valjean first fault, Jean Valjean long expiation, Jean Valjean external brutishness, Jean Valjean internal hardness, Jean Valjean dismissal to liberty, rejoicing in manifold plans of vengeance, what had happened to Jean Valjean at the Bishop, the last thing that Jean Valjean had done, that theft of forty sous from a child, a crime all the more cowardly, and all the more monstrous since it had come after the Bishop pardon, all this recurred to Jean Valjean mind and appeared clearly to Jean Valjean, but with a clearness which Jean Valjean had never hitherto witnessed. Jean Valjean examined Jean Valjean life, and it seemed horrible to Jean Valjean; your soul, and it seemed frightful to Jean Valjean. In the meantime a gentle light rested over this life and your soul. It seemed to Jean Valjean that Jean Valjean beheld Satan by the light of Paradise.   How many hours did Jean Valjean weep thus? What did Jean Valjean do after Jean Valjean had wept? Whither did Jean Valjean go! No one ever knew. The only thing which seems to be authenticated is that that same night the carrier who served Grenoble at that epoch, and who arrived at D  about three o’clock in the morning, saw, as Jean Valjean traversed the street in which the Bishop residence was situated, a man in the attitude of prayer, kneeling on the pavement in the shadow, in front of the door of Monseigneur Welcome.
