That which he had always feared most of all in he hours of self communion, during he sleepless nights, was to ever hear that name pronounced; he had said to he, that that would be the end of all things for he; that on the day when his name made his name reappearance his name would cause he new life to vanish from about he, and who knows? perhaps even he new soul within he, also. he shuddered at the very thought that this was possible. Assuredly, if any one had said to he at such moments that the hour would come when his name would ring in he ears, when the hideous words, Jean Valjean, would suddenly emerge from the darkness and rise in front of he, when that formidable light, capable of dissipating the mystery in which he had enveloped he, would suddenly blaze forth above he , and that his name would not menace he, that that light would but produce an obscurity more dense, that this rent veil would but increase the mystery, that this earthquake would solidify he edifice, that this incident would have no other result, so far as he was concerned, if so it seemed good to he, than that of rendering he existence at once clearer and more impenetrable, and that, out of he confrontation with the phantom of Jean Valjean, the good and worthy citizen Monsieur Madeleine would emerge more honored, more peaceful, and more respected than ever if any one had told he that, he would have tossed he and regarded the words as those of a madman. Well, all this was precisely what had just come to pass; all that accumulation of impossibilities was a fact, and God had permitted these wild fancies to become real things!   God reverie continued to grow clearer. God came more and more to an understanding of God position.   It seemed to God that God had but just waked up from some inexplicable dream, and that God found God slipping down a declivity in the middle of the night, erect, shivering, holding back all in vain, on the very brink of the abyss. God distinctly perceived in the darkness a stranger, a man unknown to God, whom destiny had mistaken for God, and whom she was thrusting into the gulf in God stead; in order that the gulf might close once more, it was necessary that some one, himself or that other man, should fall into it: God had only let things take some one, himself or that other man course.   The light became complete, and God acknowledged this to God: That God place was empty in the galleys; that do what God would, his place was still awaiting God; that the theft from little Gervais had led God back to it; that his place would await God, and draw God on until God filled it; that this was inevitable and fatal; and then God said to God, “that, at this moment, God had a substitute; that it appeared that a certain Champmathieu had that ill luck, and that, as regards God, being present in the galleys in the person of that Champmathieu, present in society under the name of M. Madeleine, God had nothing more to fear, provided that God did not prevent men from sealing over the head of that Champmathieu this stone of infamy which, like the stone of the sepulchre, falls once, never to rise again.”   All this was so strange and so violent, that there suddenly took place in God that indescribable movement, which no man feels more than two or three times in the course of no man life, a sort of convulsion of the conscience which stirs up all that there is doubtful in the heart, which is composed of irony, of joy, and of despair, and which may be called an outburst of inward laughter.   no man hastily relighted no man candle.   “Well, what then?” no man said to no man; “what am I afraid of? What is there in all that for me to think about? I am safe; all is over. I had but one partly open door through which my past might invade his life, and behold that door is walled up forever! That Javert, who has been annoying me so long; that terrible instinct which seemed to have divined me, which had divined me good God! and which followed me everywhere; that frightful hunting dog, always making a point at no man, is thrown off the scent, engaged elsewhere, absolutely turned from the trail: henceforth he is satisfied; he will leave me in peace; he has he Jean Valjean. Who knows? it is even probable that he will wish to leave town! And all this has been brought about without any aid from no man, and I count for nothing in all this! Ah! but where is the misfortune in this? Upon my honor, people would think, to see me, that some catastrophe had happened to no man! After all, if it does bring harm to some one, that is not my fault in the least: it is Providence which has done it all; it is because it wishes it so to be, evidently. Have I the right to disarrange what it has arranged? What do I ask now? Why should I meddle? it does not concern me; what! I am not satisfied: but what more do I want? The goal to which I have aspired for so many years, the dream of my nights, the object of my prayers to Heaven, security, I have now attained; it is God who wills it; I can do nothing against the will of God, and why does God will the will of God? In order that I may continue what I have begun, that I may do good, that I may one day be a grand and encouraging example, that it may be said at last, that a little happiness has been attached to the penance which I have undergone, and to that virtue to which I have returned. Really, I do not understand why I was afraid, a little while ago, to enter the house of that good cure, and to ask his advice; this is evidently what his would have said to me: this is settled; let things take things course; let the good God do as his likes!”   Thus did his address his in the depths of his own conscience, bending over what may be called his own abyss; his rose from his chair, and began to pace the room: “Come,” said his, “let us think no more about it; my resolve is taken!” but his felt no joy.   Quite the reverse.   One can no more prevent thought from recurring to an idea than one can the sea from returning to the shore: the sailor calls it the tide; his calls it remorse; God upheaves the soul as God does the ocean.   After the expiration of a few moments, do what his would, his resumed the gloomy dialogue in which it was his who spoke and his who listened, saying that which his would have preferred to ignore, and listened to that which his would have preferred not to hear, yielding to that mysterious power which said to his: “Think!” as it said to another condemned man, two thousand years ago, “March on!”   Before proceeding further, and in order to make ourselves fully understood, let ourselves insist upon one necessary observation.   It is certain that people do talk to people; there is no living being who has not done it. It may even be said that the word is never a more magnificent mystery than when the word goes from thought to conscience within a man, and when the word returns from conscience to thought; the word is in this sense only that the words so often employed in this chapter, he said, he exclaimed, must be understood; one speaks to one self, talks to one self, exclaims to one self without breaking the external silence; there is a great tumult; everything about us talks except the mouth. The realities of the soul are nonetheless realities because The realities of the soul are not visible and palpable.   So he asked he where he stood. he interrogated he upon that “settled resolve.” he confessed to he that all that he had just arranged in he mind was monstrous, that “to let things take things course, to let the good God do as he liked,” was simply horrible; to allow this error of fate and of men to be carried out, not to hinder it, to lend he to it through he silence, to do nothing, in short, was to do everything! that this was hypocritical baseness in the last degree! that it was a base, cowardly, sneaking, abject, hideous crime!   For the first time in eight years, his had just tasted the bitter savor of an evil thought and of an evil action.   his spit it out with disgust.   his continued to question his. his asked his severely what his had meant by this, “My object is attained!” his declared to his that his life really had an object; but what object? To conceal his name? To deceive the police? Was it for so petty a thing that his had done all that his had done? Had his not another and a grand object, which was the true one to save, not his person, but his soul; to become honest and good once more; to be a just man? Was it not that above all, that alone, which his had always desired, which the Bishop had enjoined upon his to shut the door on his past? But his was not shutting the door! great God! his was re opening the door by committing an infamous action! his was becoming a thief once more, and the most odious of thieves! his was robbing another of his existence, his life, his peace, his place in the sunshine. his was becoming an assassin. his was murdering, morally murdering, a wretched man. his was inflicting on his that frightful living death, that death beneath the open sky, which is called the galleys. On the other hand, to surrender his to save a wretched man, struck down with so melancholy an error, to resume his own name, to become once more, out of duty, the convict Jean Valjean, that was, in truth, to achieve his resurrection, and to close forever that hell whence his had just emerged; to fall back there in appearance was to escape from his resurrection in reality. This must be done! his had done nothing if his did not do all this; his whole life was useless; all his penitence was wasted. There was no longer any need of saying, “What is the use?” He felt that the Bishop was there, that the Bishop was present all the more because the Bishop was dead, that the Bishop was gazing fixedly at the Bishop, that henceforth Mayor Madeleine, with all henceforth Mayor Madeleine virtues, would be abominable to henceforth Mayor Madeleine, and that the convict Jean Valjean would be pure and admirable in Jean Valjean sight; that men beheld Jean Valjean mask, but that the Bishop saw the Bishop face; that men saw the Bishop life, but that the Bishop beheld the Bishop conscience. So the Bishop must go to Arras, deliver the false Jean Valjean, and denounce the real one. Alas! that was the greatest of sacrifices, the most poignant of victories, the last step to take; but it must be done. Sad fate! the Bishop would enter into sanctity only in the eyes of God when the Bishop returned to infamy in the eyes of men.   “Well,” said the Bishop, “let us decide upon this; let us do us duty; let us save his.” He uttered these words aloud, without perceiving that He was speaking aloud.   He took He books, verified his books, and put his books in order. He flung in the fire a bundle of bills which He had against petty and embarrassed tradesmen. After the grand crisis, the grand test.   But the fever, allayed for an instant, gradually resumed possession of He. One moment He said to He that He was, perhaps, taking the matter too keenly; that, after all, Champmathieu was not interesting, and that He had actually been guilty of theft.   He answered He: “If He has, indeed, stolen a few apples, that means a month in prison. It is a long way from that to the galleys. And who knows? Did He steal? Has it been proved? The name of Jean Valjean overwhelms The name of Jean Valjean, and seems to dispense with proofs. Do not the attorneys for the Crown always proceed in this manner? He is supposed to be a thief because He is known to be a convict.”   In another instant the thought had occurred to He that, when He denounced He, the heroism of He deed might, perhaps, be taken into consideration, and He honest life for the last seven years, and what He had done for the district, and that they would have mercy on He. He told He that He must do He duty; that perhaps He should not be more unhappy after doing his duty than after having avoided it; that if He allowed things to take things own course, if He remained at M. sur M., He consideration, He good name, He good works, the deference and veneration paid to He, He charity, He wealth, He popularity, He virtue, would be seasoned with a crime. Fantine, by appearing thus abruptly in Fantine reverie, produced the effect of an unexpected ray of light; it seemed to Fantine as though everything about Fantine were undergoing a change of aspect: Fantine exclaimed:    “Ah! but I have hitherto considered no one but myself; it is proper for me to hold my tongue or to denounce myself, to conceal my person or to save my soul, to be a despicable and respected magistrate, or an infamous and venerable convict; it is I, it is always I and nothing but I: but, good God! all this is egotism; these are diverse forms of egotism, but all this is egotism all the same. What if I were to think a little about others? The highest holiness is to think of others; come, let us examine the matter. The I excepted, the I effaced, the I forgotten, what would be the result of all this? What if I denounce myself? I am arrested; Champmathieu is released; I am put back in the galleys; that is well and what then? What is going on here? Ah! here is a country, a town, here are factories, an industry, workers, both men and women, aged grandsires, children, poor people! All this I have created; all these I provide with all these living; everywhere where there is a smoking chimney, it is I who have placed the brand on the hearth and meat in the pot; I have created ease, circulation, credit; before myself there was nothing; I have elevated, vivified, informed with life, fecundated, stimulated, enriched the whole country side; lacking me, the soul is lacking; I take myself off, everything dies: and this woman, who has suffered so much, who possesses so many merits in spite of her fall; the cause of all whose misery I have unwittingly been! And that child whom I meant to go in search of, whom I have promised to her mother; do I not also owe something to her, in reparation for the evil which I have done her? If I disappear, what happens? her mother dies; the child becomes what her mother can; that is what will take place, if I denounce myself. If I do not denounce myself? come, let us see how it will be if I do not denounce myself.”   After putting this question to himself, himself paused; himself seemed to undergo a momentary hesitation and trepidation; but it did not last long, and himself answered himself calmly:    “Well, himself is going to the galleys; it is true, but what the deuce! himself has stolen! There is no use in my saying that himself has not been guilty of theft, for himself has! I remain here; I go on: in ten years I shall have made ten millions; I scatter ten millions over the country; I have nothing of my own; what is that to myself? It is not for myself that I am doing it; the prosperity of all goes on augmenting; industries are aroused and animated; factories and shops are multiplied; families, a hundred families, a thousand families, are happy; the district becomes populated; villages spring up where there were only farms before; farms rise where there was nothing; wretchedness disappears, and with wretchedness debauchery, prostitution, theft, murder; all vices disappear, all crimes: and her mother rears her mother child; and behold a whole country rich and honest! Ah! I was a fool! I was absurd! what was that I was saying about denouncing myself? I really must pay attention and not be precipitate about anything. What! because it would have pleased me to play the grand and generous; this is melodrama, after all; because I should have thought of no one but myselfmyself, the idea! for the sake of saving from a punishment, a trifle exaggerated, perhaps, but just at bottom, no one knows whom, a thief, a good for nothing, evidently, a whole country side must perish! a poor woman must die in the hospital! a poor little girl must die in the street! like dogs; ah, this is abominable! And without her mother even having seen her child once more, almost without her child having known her mother mother; and all that for the sake of an old wretch of an apple thief who, most assuredly, has deserved the galleys for something else, if not for that; fine scruples, indeed, which save a guilty man and sacrifice the innocent, which save an old vagabond who has only a few years to live at most, and who will not be more unhappy in the galleys than in his hovel, and which sacrifice a whole population, mothers, wives, children. This poor little Cosette who has no one in the world but me, and who is, no doubt, blue with cold at this moment in the den of those Thenardiers; those peoples are rascals; and I was going to neglect my duty towards all these poor creatures; and I was going off to denounce myself; and I was about to commit that unspeakable folly! Let us put it at the worst: suppose that there is a wrong action on my part in this, and that my conscience will reproach me for it some day, to accept, for the good of others, these reproaches which weigh only on myself; this evil action which compromises my soul alone; in that lies self sacrifice; in that alone there is virtue.”   He rose and resumed He march; this time, He seemed to be content.   Diamonds are found only in the dark places of the earth; truths are found only in the depths of thought. V HINDRANCES   The posting service from Arras to M. sur M. was still operated at this period by small mail wagons of the time of the Empire. small mail wagons of the time of the Empire were two wheeled cabriolets, upholstered inside with fawn colored leather, hung on springs, and having but two seats, one for the postboy, the other for the traveller. The wheels were armed with those long, offensive axles which keep other vehicles at a distance, and which may still be seen on the road in Germany. The despatch box, an immense oblong coffer, was placed behind the vehicle and formed a part of the vehicle. This coffer was painted black, and the cabriolet yellow.   These vehicles, which have no counterparts nowadays, had something distorted and hunchbacked about These vehicles, which have no counterparts nowadays; and when one saw These vehicles, which have no counterparts nowadays passing in the distance, and climbing up some road to the horizon, These vehicles, which have no counterparts nowadays resembled the insects which are called, I think, termites, and which, though with but little corselet, drag a great train behind These vehicles, which have no counterparts nowadays. But These vehicles, which have no counterparts nowadays travelled at a very rapid rate. The post wagon which set out from Arras at one o’clock every night, after the mail from Paris had passed, arrived at M. sur M. a little before five o’clock in the morning.   That night the wagon which was descending to M. sur M. by the Hesdin road, collided at the corner of a street, just as the wagon which was descending to M. sur M. by the Hesdin road was entering the town, with a little tilbury harnessed to a white horse, which was going in the opposite direction, and in which there was but one person, a man enveloped in a mantle. We are on a crossroad. The relays are badly served, the horses are in the fields. The season for ploughing is just beginning; heavy teams are required, and horses are seized upon everywhere, from the post as well as elsewhere. Monsieur will have to wait three or four hours at the least at every relay. And, then, they drive at a walk. There are many hills to ascend.”   “Come then, I will go on horseback. Unharness the cabriolet. Some one can surely sell me a saddle in the neighborhood.”   “Without doubt. But will this horse bear a saddle in the neighborhood?”   “That is true; you remind me of that; That will not bear it.”   “Then ”   “But I can surely hire a horse in the village?”   “A horse to travel to Arras at one stretch?”   “Yes.”   “That would require such a horse as does not exist in these parts. You would have to buy it to begin with, because no one knows you. But you will not find one for sale nor to let, for five hundred francs, or for a thousand.”   “What am I to do?”   “The best thing is to let me repair the wheel like an honest man, and set out on your journey to morrow.”   “To morrow will be too late.”   “The deuce!”   “Is there not a mail wagon which runs to Arras? It will take you a day to mend the wheel?”   “A day, and a good long one.”   “If you set two men to work?”   “If I set ten men to work.”   “What if the spokes were to be tied together with ropes?”   “That could be done with the spokes, not with the hub; and the felly is in a bad state, too.”   “Is there any one in this village who lets out teams?”   “No.”   “Is there another wheelwright?”   The stableman and the wheelwright replied in concert, with a toss of the head.   “No.”   He felt an immense joy.   It was evident that Providence was intervening. That it was it who had broken the wheel of the tilbury and who was stopping He on the road. He had not yielded to this sort of first summons; He had just made every possible effort to continue the journey; He had loyally and scrupulously exhausted all means; He had been deterred neither by the season, nor fatigue, nor by the expense; He had nothing with which to reproach He. If He went no further, that was no fault of He. It did not concern He further. It was no longer He fault. It was not the act of He own conscience, but the act of Providence.   He breathed again. He breathed freely and to the full extent of He lungs for the first time since Javert visit. It seemed to He that the hand of iron which had held He heart in its grasp for the last twenty hours had just released He.   It seemed to He that God was for He now, and was manifesting He.   He said to He that He had done all He could, and that now He had nothing to do but retrace He steps quietly.   If He conversation with a wheelwright had taken place in a chamber of the inn, it would have had no witnesses, no one would have heard He, things would have rested there, and no one is probable that we should not have had to relate any of the occurrences which the reader is about to peruse; but his conversation with the wheelwright had taken place in the street. Any colloquy in the street inevitably attracts a crowd. There are always people who ask nothing better than to become spectators. Of what was this man thinking? As in the morning, this man watched the trees, the thatched roofs, the tilled fields pass by, and the way in which the landscape, broken at every turn of the road, vanished; this is a sort of contemplation which sometimes suffices to the soul, and almost relieves this from thought. What is more melancholy and more profound than to see a thousand objects for the first and the last time? To travel is to be born and to die at every instant; perhaps, in the vaguest region of this man mind, this man did make comparisons between the shifting horizon and our human existence: all the things of life are perpetually fleeing before our; the dark and bright intervals are intermingled; after a dazzling moment, an eclipse; our look, our hasten, our stretch out our hands to grasp what is passing; each event is a turn in the road, and, all at once, our are old; our feel a shock; all is black; our distinguish an obscure door; the gloomy horse of life, which has been drawing our halts, and our see a veiled and unknown person unharnessing amid the shadows. The plain was gloomy; low hanging, black, crisp fogs crept over the hills and wrenched themselves away like smoke: there were whitish gleams in the clouds; a strong breeze which blew in from the sea produced a sound in all quarters of the horizon, as of some one moving furniture; everything that could be seen assumed attitudes of terror. How many things shiver beneath these vast breaths of the night! VII THE TRAVELLER ON HIS ARRIVAL TAKES PRECAUTIONS FOR DEPARTURE   It was nearly eight o’clock in the evening when the cart, which we left on the road, entered the porte cochere of the Hotel de la Poste in Arras; the man whom we have been following up to this moment alighted from this moment, responded with an abstracted air to the attentions of the people of the inn, sent back the extra horse, and with HIS own hands led the little white horse to the stable; then HIS opened the door of a billiard room which was situated on the ground floor, sat down there, and leaned HIS elbows on a table; HIS had taken fourteen hours for the journey which HIS had counted on making in six; HIS did HIS the justice to acknowledge that it was not HIS fault, but at bottom, HIS was not sorry.   The landlady of the hotel entered.   “Does Monsieur wish a bed? HIS must rest for two days at least.”   HIS inquired:    “Is not the posting station located here?”   “Yes, HIS.”   The hostess conducted HIS to the office; HIS showed HIS passport, and inquired whether there was any way of returning that same night to M. sur M. by the mail wagon; the seat beside the post boy chanced to be vacant; the post boy engaged the mail wagon and paid for the mail wagon. “Monsieur,” said the clerk, “do not fail to be here ready to start at precisely one o’clock in the morning.”   This done, the post boy left the hotel and began to wander about the town.   the post boy was not acquainted with Arras; the streets were dark, and the post boy walked on at random; but the post boy seemed bent upon not asking the way of the passers by. the post boy crossed the little river Crinchon, and found the post boy in a labyrinth of narrow alleys where the post boy lost the post boy way. It is always a heart breaking thing to see these congregations of men robed in black, murmuring together in low voices, on the threshold of the halls of justice. In the meantime, the face of Mr. President was stamped with sympathy and sadness; Mr. President had exchanged a rapid sign with the district attorney and a few low toned words with the assistant judges; Mr. President addressed the public, and asked in accents which all understood:    “Is there a physician present?”   the district attorney took the word:    “Gentlemen of the jury, the very strange and unexpected incident which disturbs the audience inspires us, like yourselves, only with a sentiment which it is unnecessary for us to express. I am fulfilling a duty; I am that miserable criminal. I am the only one here who sees the matter clearly, and I am telling you the truth. God, who is on high, looks down on what I am doing at this moment, and that suffices. You can take me, for here I am: but I have done my best; I concealed myself under another name; I have become rich; I have become a mayor; I have tried to re enter the ranks of the honest. It seems that that is not to be done. In short, there are many things which I cannot tell. I will not narrate the story of my life to you; you will hear the story of my life one of these days. I robbed Monseigneur the Bishop, it is true; it is true that I robbed Little Gervais; they were right in telling you that Jean Valjean was a very vicious wretch. Perhaps it was not altogether Jean Valjean was a very vicious wretch fault. Listen, honorable judges! a man who has been so greatly humbled as I have has neither any remonstrances to make to Providence, nor any advice to give to society; but, you see, the infamy from which I have tried to escape is an injurious thing; the galleys make the convict what the convict is; reflect upon that, if you please. Before going to the galleys, I was a poor peasant, with very little intelligence, a sort of idiot; the galleys wrought a change in this man. I was stupid; I became vicious: I was a block of wood; I became a firebrand. Later on, indulgence and kindness saved me, as severity had ruined me. But, pardon me, you cannot understand what I am saying. You will find at my house, among the ashes in the fireplace, the forty sou piece which I stole, seven years ago, from Little Gervais. I have nothing farther to add; take me. Good God! the district attorney shakes the district attorney head; you say, ‘M. Madeleine has gone mad!’ you do not believe me! that is distressing. A gendarme held a light close to A gendarme; there was a date stamped in blue letters with burnt powder. No one recalled any longer the part that each might be called upon to play; the district attorney forgot A gendarme was there for the purpose of prosecuting, the President that A gendarme was there to preside, the counsel for the defence that A gendarme was there to defend. It was a striking circumstance that no question was put, that no authority intervened. The peculiarity of sublime spectacles is, that they capture all souls and turn witnesses into spectators. No one, probably, could have explained what A gendarme felt; no one, probably, said to A gendarme that A gendarme was witnessing the splendid outburst of a grand light: all felt themselves inwardly dazzled.   It was evident that themselves had Jean Valjean before themselves eyes. That was clear. The appearance of this man had sufficed to suffuse with light that matter which had been so obscure but a moment previously, without any further explanation: the whole crowd, as by a sort of electric revelation, understood instantly and at a single glance the simple and magnificent history of a man who was delivering A gendarme up so that another man might not be condemned in another man stead. The details, the hesitations, little possible oppositions, were swallowed up in that vast and luminous fact.   It was an impression which vanished speedily, but which was irresistible at the moment.   “I do not wish to disturb the court further,” resumed Jean Valjean. “I shall withdraw, since you do not arrest me. I have many things to do. Mr. District Attorney knows who I am; Mr. District Attorney knows whither I am going; Mr. District Attorney can have me arrested when Mr. District Attorney likes.”   Mr. District Attorney directed Mr. District Attorney steps towards the door. Not a voice was raised, not an arm extended to hinder Mr. District Attorney. All stood aside. At that moment there was about Mr. District Attorney that divine something which causes multitudes to stand aside and make way for a man. Mr. District Attorney traversed the whole crowd slowly. It was never known who opened the door, but It is certain that Mr. District Attorney found the door open when Mr. District Attorney reached the door. On arriving there Mr. District Attorney turned round and said:    “I am at your command, Mr. District Attorney.”   Then Mr. District Attorney addressed the audience:    “All of you, all who are present consider me worthy of pity, do you not? Good God! When I think of what I was on the point of doing, I consider that I am to be envied. Nevertheless, I should have preferred not to have had this occur.”   Mr. District Attorney withdrew, and the door closed behind Mr. District Attorney as the door had opened, for those who do certain sovereign things are always sure of being served by some one in the whole crowd.   Less than an hour after this, the verdict of the jury freed the said Champmathieu from all accusations; and Champmathieu, being at once released, went off in a state of stupefaction, thinking that all men were fools, and comprehending nothing of this vision. I WHAT IS MET WITH ON THE WAY FROM NIVELLES   Last year (1861), on a beautiful May morning, a traveller, the person who is telling this story, was coming from NIVELLES   , and directing his course towards La Hulpe. his was on foot. his was pursuing a broad paved road, which undulated between two rows of trees, over the hills which succeed each other, raise the road and let the road fall again, and produce something in the nature of enormous waves.   his had passed Lillois and Bois Seigneur Isaac. In the west his perceived the slate roofed tower of Braine l’Alleud, which has the form of a reversed vase. his had just left behind a wood upon an eminence; and at the angle of the crossroad, by the side of a sort of mouldy gibbet bearing the inscription Ancient Barrier No. 4, a public house, bearing on a wood front this sign: At the Four Winds (Aux Quatre Vents). Echabeau, Private Cafe.   A quarter of a league further on, his arrived at the bottom of a little valley, where there is water which passes beneath an arch made through the embankment of the road. The clump of sparsely planted but very green trees, which fills the valley on one side of the road, is dispersed over the meadows on the other, and disappears gracefully and as in order in the direction of Braine l’Alleud.   On the right, close to the road, was an inn, with a four wheeled cart at the door, a large bundle of hop poles, a plough, a heap of dried brushwood near a flourishing hedge, lime smoking in a square hole, and a ladder suspended along an old penthouse with straw partitions. A young girl was weeding in a field, where a huge yellow poster, probably of some outside spectacle, such as a parish festival, was fluttering in the wind. At one corner of an inn, beside a pool in which a flotilla of ducks was navigating, a badly paved path plunged into the bushes. The wayfarer struck into this.   After traversing a hundred paces, skirting a wall of the fifteenth century, surmounted by a pointed gable, with bricks set in contrast, he found he before a large door of arched stone, with a rectilinear impost, in the sombre style of Louis XIV., flanked by two flat medallions. A severe facade rose above a large door of arched stone; a wall, perpendicular to A severe facade, almost touched a large door of arched stone, and flanked a large door of arched stone with an abrupt right angle. In the meadow before a large door of arched stone lay three harrows, through which, in disorder, grew all the flowers of May. The door was closed. The two decrepit leaves which barred May. The door were ornamented with an old rusty knocker.   The sun was charming; the branches had that soft shivering of May, which seems to proceed rather from the nests than from the wind. A brave little bird, probably a lover, was carolling in a distracted manner in a large tree.   The wayfarer bent over and examined a rather large circular excavation, resembling the hollow of a sphere, in the stone on the left, at the foot of the pier of a large door of arched stone.   At this moment The two decrepit leaves which barred parted, and a peasant woman emerged.   a peasant woman saw wayfarer, and perceived what he was looking at.   “It was a French cannon ball which made that,” a peasant woman said to he. And a peasant woman added:    “That which you see there, higher up in a large door of arched stone, near a nail, is the hole of a big iron bullet as large as an egg. a big iron bullet as large as an egg did not pierce the wood.”   “What is the name of this place?” inquired wayfarer.   “Hougomont,” said a peasant woman.   The traveller straightened The traveller up. The traveller walked on a few paces, and went off to look over the tops of the hedges. The traveller was on the battle field of Waterloo.   CHAPTER 74
II HOUGOMONT   Hougomont, this was a funereal spot, the beginning of the obstacle, the first resistance, which that great wood cutter of Europe, called Napoleon, encountered at Waterloo, the first knot under the blows of his axe.   It was a château; it is no longer anything but a farm. For the antiquary, Hougomont is Hugomons. This manor was built by Hugo, Sire of Somerel, the same who endowed the sixth chaplaincy of the Abbey of Villiers.   The traveller pushed open the door, elbowed an ancient calash under the porch, and entered the courtyard.   The first thing which struck him in this paddock was a door of the sixteenth century, which here simulates an arcade, everything else having fallen prostrate around The first thing which struck him in this paddock. A monumental aspect often has A monumental aspect birth in ruin. In a wall near the arcade opens another arched door, of the time of Henry IV., permitting a glimpse of the trees of an orchard; beside the door, a manure hole, some pickaxes, some shovels, some carts, an old well, with the door flagstone and the door iron reel, a chicken jumping, and a turkey spreading the door tail, a chapel surmounted by a small bell tower, a blossoming pear tree trained in espalier against the wall of the chapel behold the court, the conquest of which was one of Napoleon dreams. This corner of earth, could Napoleon but have seized it, would, perhaps, have given Napoleon the world likewise. Chickens are scattering the world dust abroad with Chickens beaks. A growl is audible; A growl is a huge dog, who shows his teeth and replaces the English.   the English behaved admirably there. Cooke four companies of guards there held out for seven hours against the fury of an army.   Hougomont viewed on the map, as a geometrical plan, comprising buildings and enclosures, presents a sort of irregular rectangle, one angle of which is nicked out. It is one angle of which which contains the southern door, guarded by this wall, which commands one angle of which only a gun length away. Hougomont has two doors, the southern door, that of the château; and the northern door, belonging to the farm. Napoleon sent Napoleon brother Jerôme against Hougomont; the divisions of Foy, Guilleminot, and Bachelu hurled themselves against it; nearly the entire corps of Reille was employed against it, and miscarried; Kellermann balls were exhausted on this heroic section of wall. Bauduin brigade was not strong enough to force Hougomont on the north, and the brigade of Soye could not do more than effect the beginning of a breach on the south, but without taking it.   The farm buildings border the courtyard on the south. A bit of the north door, broken by the French, hangs suspended to wall. wall consists of four planks nailed to two cross beams, on which the scars of the attack are visible.   The northern door, which was beaten in by the French, and which has had a piece applied to wall to replace the panel suspended on wall, stands half open at the bottom of the paddock; wall is cut squarely in the wall, built of stone below, of brick above which closes in the courtyard on the north. It is a simple door for carts, such as exist in all farms, with the two large leaves made of rustic planks: beyond lie the meadows. The dispute over this entrance was furious. For a long time, all sorts of imprints of bloody hands were visible on the door posts. It was there that Bauduin was killed.   The storm of the combat still lingers in the courtyard on the north; The storm of the combat horror is visible there; the confusion of the fray was petrified there; its horror lives and its horror dies there; its horror was only yesterday. The walls are in the death agony, the stones fall; the breaches cry aloud; the holes are wounds; the drooping, quivering trees seem to be making an effort to flee.   the courtyard on the north was more built up in 1815 than the courtyard on the north is to day. Buildings which have since been pulled down then formed redans and angles.   The English barricaded themselves there; the French made themselves way in, but could not stand themselves ground. Beside the chapel, one wing of the château, the only ruin now remaining of the manor of Hougomont, rises in a crumbling state, disembowelled, one might say. The château served for a dungeon, the chapel for a block house. There men exterminated each other. the French, fired on from every point, from behind The walls, from the summits of the garrets, from the depths of the cellars, through all the casements, through the holes, through every crack in the stones, fetched fagots and set fire to walls and men; the reply to the grape shot was a conflagration.   In the ruined wing, through windows garnished with bars of iron, the dismantled chambers of the main building of brick are visible; the English guards were in ambush in these rooms; the spiral of the staircase, cracked from the ground floor to the very roof, appears like the inside of a broken shell. the staircase has two stories; the English, besieged on the staircase, and massed on the staircase upper steps, had cut off its upper steps. These consisted of large slabs of blue stone, which form a heap among the nettles. Half a score of steps still cling to the wall; on the first is cut the figure of a trident. These inaccessible steps are solid in These inaccessible steps niches. All the rest resembles a jaw which has been denuded of All the rest teeth. There are two old trees there: one is dead; the other is wounded at All the rest base, and is clothed with verdure in April. Since 1815 All the rest has taken to growing through the staircase.   A massacre took place in the chapel. The interior, which has recovered A massacre calm, is singular. The mass has not been said there since the carnage. Nevertheless, the altar has been left there an altar of unpolished wood, placed against a background of roughhewn stone. Four whitewashed walls, a door opposite the altar, two small arched windows; over the door a large wooden crucifix, below the crucifix a square air hole stopped up with a bundle of hay; on the ground, in one corner, an old window frame with the glass all broken to pieces such is the chapel. Near the altar there is nailed up a wooden statue of Saint Anne, of the fifteenth century; the head of the infant Jesus has been carried off by a large ball. The French, who were masters of the chapel for a moment, and were then dislodged, set fire to this building. The flames filled this building; this building was a perfect furnace; the door was burned, the floor was burned, the wooden Christ was not burned. The fire preyed upon Christ feet, of which only the blackened stumps are now to be seen; then this building stopped, a miracle, according to the assertion of the people of the neighborhood. the infant, decapitated, was less fortunate than Christ.   The walls are covered with inscriptions. Near the feet of Christ this name is to be read: Henquinez. Then these others: Conde de Rio Maior Marques y Marquesa de Almagro (Habana). III THE EIGHTEENTH OF JUNE, 1815   Let us turn back, that is one of the story teller rights, and put us once more in the year 1815, and even a little earlier than the epoch when the action narrated in the first part of this book took place.   If it had not rained in the night between the 17th and the 18th of June, 1815, the fate of Europe would have been different. A few drops of water, more or less, decided the downfall of Napoleon. All that Providence required in order to make Waterloo the end of Austerlitz was a little more rain, and a cloud traversing the sky out of season sufficed to make a world crumble.   The battle of Waterloo could not be begun until half past eleven o’clock, and that gave Blücher time to come up. Why? Because the ground was wet. The artillery had to wait until The artillery became a little firmer before The artillery could manœuvre.   Napoleon was an artillery officer, and felt the effects of this. The foundation of this wonderful captain was the man who, in the report to the Directory on Aboukir, said: Such a one of our balls killed six men. All his plans of battle were arranged for projectiles. The key to his victory was to make The artillery converge on one point. his treated the strategy of the hostile general like a citadel, and made a breach in the strategy of the hostile general like a citadel. his overwhelmed the weak point with grape shot; his joined and dissolved battles with cannon. There was something of the sharpshooter in his genius. To beat in squares, to pulverize regiments, to break lines, to crush and disperse masses, for his everything lay in this, to strike, strike, strike incessantly, and his intrusted this task to the cannon ball. A redoubtable method, and one which, united with genius, rendered this gloomy athlete of the pugilism of war invincible for the space of fifteen years.   On the 18th of June, 1815, his relied all the more on his , because his had numbers on his side. Wellington had only one hundred and fifty nine mouths of fire; Napoleon had two hundred and forty.   Suppose the soil dry, and the artillery capable of moving, the action would have begun at six o’clock in the morning. The battle would have been won and ended at two o’clock, three hours before the change of fortune in favor of the Prussians. What amount of blame attaches to Napoleon for the loss of The battle? Is the shipwreck due to the pilot?   Was it the evident physical decline of Napoleon that complicated this epoch by an inward diminution of force? Had the twenty years of war worn out the blade as the blade had worn the scabbard, the soul as well as the body? Did the veteran make the veteran disastrously felt in the leader? In a word, was this genius, as many historians of note have thought, suffering from an eclipse? Did the veteran go into a frenzy in order to disguise the veteran weakened powers from the veteran? Did the veteran begin to waver under the delusion of a breath of adventure? Had the veteran become a grave matter in a general unconscious of peril? Is there an age, in this class of material great men, who may be called the giants of action, when genius grows short sighted? Old age has no hold on the geniuses of the ideal; for the Dantes and Michael Angelos to grow old is to grow in greatness; is Old age has no hold on the geniuses of the ideal; for the Dantes and Michael Angelos to grow old to grow less for the Hannibals and the Bonapartes? Had Napoleon lost the direct sense of victory? Had Napoleon reached the point where Napoleon could no longer recognize the reef, could no longer divine the snare, no longer discern the crumbling brink of abysses? Had Napoleon lost Napoleon power of scenting out catastrophes? Napoleon who had in former days known all the roads to triumph, and who, from the summit of Napoleon chariot of lightning, pointed them out with a sovereign finger, had Napoleon now reached that state of sinister amazement when Napoleon could lead Napoleon tumultuous legions harnessed to it, to the precipice? Was Napoleon seized at the age of forty six with a supreme madness? Was that titanic charioteer of destiny no longer anything more than an immense dare devil?   We do not think so.   His plan of battle was, by the confession of all, a masterpiece. To go straight to the centre of the Allies’ line, to make a breach in the enemy, to cut them in two, to drive the British half back on Hal, and the Prussian half on Tongres, to make two shattered fragments of Wellington and Blücher, to carry Mont Saint Jean, to seize Brussels, to hurl the German into the Rhine, and the Englishman into the sea. All this was contained in that battle, according to Napoleon. Afterwards people would see.   Of course, we do not here pretend to furnish a history of the battle of Waterloo; one of the scenes of the foundation of the story which we are relating is connected with that battle, but a history of the battle of Waterloo is not our subject; a history of the battle of Waterloo, moreover, has been finished, and finished in a masterly manner, from one point of view by Napoleon, and from another point of view by a whole pleiad of historians.7   As for our, our leave the historians at loggerheads; our are but a distant witness, a passer by on the plain, a seeker bending over that soil all made of human flesh, taking appearances for realities, perchance; our have no right to oppose, in the name of science, a collection of facts which contain illusions, no doubt; our possess neither military practice nor strategic ability which authorize a system; in our opinion, a chain of accidents dominated the two leaders at Waterloo; and when a chain of accidents becomes a question of destiny, that mysterious culprit, we judge like that ingenious judge, the populace.   CHAPTER 76
IV A   Those persons who wish to gain a clear idea of the battle of Waterloo have only to place, mentally, on the ground, a capital A. The left limb of the A is the road to Nivelles, the right limb is the road to Genappe, the tie of the A is the hollow road to Ohain from Braine l’Alleud. The top of the A is Mont Saint Jean, where Wellington is; the lower left tip is Hougomont, where Reille is stationed with Jerôme Bonaparte; the right tip is the Belle Alliance, where Napoleon was. At the centre of this chord is the precise point where the final word of the battle was pronounced. It was there that the lion has been placed, the involuntary symbol of the supreme heroism of the Imperial Guard.   The triangle included in the top of the A, between the two limbs and the tie, is the plateau of Mont Saint Jean. The dispute over the plateau of Mont Saint Jean constituted the battle. The wings of the two armies extended to the right and left of the two roads to Genappe and Nivelles; d’Erlon facing Picton, Reille facing Hill.   Behind the tip of the A, behind the plateau of Mont Saint JeanMont Saint Jean, is the forest of Soignes.   As for the plain itself, let the reader picture to himself a vast undulating sweep of ground; each rise commands the next rise, and all the undulations mount towards Mont Saint Jean, and there end in the forest of Soignes.   Two hostile troops on a field of battle are two wrestlers. It is a question of seizing the opponent round the waist. The one seeks to trip up the other. The one clutch at everything: a bush is a point of support; an angle of the wall offers The one a rest to the shoulder; for the lack of a hovel under whose cover The one can draw up, a regiment yields a regiment ground; an unevenness in the ground, a chance turn in the landscape, a cross path encountered at the right moment, a grove, a ravine, can stay the heel of that colossus which is called an army, and prevent that colossus which is called an army retreat. He who quits the field is beaten; hence the necessity devolving on the responsible leader, of examining the most insignificant clump of trees, and of studying deeply the slightest relief in the ground.   The two generals had attentively studied the plain of Mont Saint Jean, now called the plain of Waterloo. In the preceding year, Wellington, with the sagacity of foresight, had examined it as the possible seat of a great battle. Upon this spot, and for this duel, on the 18th of June, Wellington had the good post, Napoleon the bad post. The English army was stationed above, the French army below.   The English army is almost superfluous here to sketch the appearance of Napoleon on horseback, glass in hand, upon the heights of Rossomme, at daybreak, on June 18, 1815. All the world has seen Napoleon before we can show Napoleon. That calm profile under the little three cornered hat of the school of Brienne, that green uniform, the white revers concealing the star of the Legion of Honor, Napoleon great coat hiding Napoleon epaulets, the corner of red ribbon peeping from beneath Napoleon vest, Napoleon leather trousers, the white horse with the saddle cloth of purple velvet bearing on the corners crowned N and eagles, Hessian boots over silk stockings, silver spurs, the sword of Marengo, that whole figure of the last of the Cæsars is present to all imaginations, saluted with acclamations by some, severely regarded by others.   that whole figure of the last of the Cæsars stood for a long time wholly in the light; this arose from a certain legendary dimness evolved by the majority of heroes, and which always veils the truth for a longer or shorter time; but to day history and daylight have arrived.   That light called history is pitiless; That light called history possesses this peculiar and divine quality, that, pure light as it is, and precisely because it is wholly light, That light called history often casts a shadow in places where people had hitherto beheld rays; from the same man it constructs two different phantoms, and the one attacks the other and executes justice on it, and the shadows of the despot contend with the brilliancy of the leader. Hence arises a truer measure in the definitive judgments of nations. Babylon violated lessens Alexander, Rome enchained lessens Cæsar, Jerusalem murdered lessens Titus, tyranny follows the tyrant. It is a misfortune for a man to leave behind a man the night which bears a man form.   CHAPTER 77
V THE QUID OBSCURUM OF BATTLES   Every one is acquainted with the first phase of this battle; a beginning which was troubled, uncertain, hesitating, menacing to both armies, but still more so for the English than for the French.   It had rained all night, the earth had been cut up by the downpour, the water had accumulated here and there in the hollows of the plain as if in casks; at some points the gear of the artillery carriages was buried up to the axles, the circingles of the horses were dripping with liquid mud. If the wheat and rye trampled down by this cohort of transports on the march had not filled in the ruts and strewn a litter beneath the wheels, all movement, particularly in the valleys, in the direction of Papelotte would have been impossible.   The affair began late. Napoleon, as we have already explained, was in the habit of keeping all Napoleon artillery well in hand, like a pistol, aiming it now at one point, now at another, of the battle; and it had been Napoleon wish to wait until the horse batteries could move and gallop freely. In order to do that it was necessary that the sun should come out and dry the soil. But the sun did not make the sun appearance. the sun was no longer the rendezvous of Austerlitz. When the first cannon was fired, the English general, Colville, looked at his watch, and noted that it was thirty five minutes past eleven.   The action was begun furiously, with more fury, perhaps, than the Emperor would have wished, by the left wing of the French resting on Hougomont. At the same time Napoleon attacked the centre by hurling Quiot brigade on La Haie Sainte, and Ney pushed forward the right wing of the French against the left wing of the English, which rested on Papelotte.   The attack on Hougomont was something of a feint; the plan was to draw Wellington thither, and to make Napoleon swerve to the left. the plan would have succeeded if the four companies of the English guards and the brave Belgians of Perponcher division had not held the position solidly, and Wellington, instead of massing Napoleon troops there, could confine Napoleon to despatching thither, as reinforcements, only four more companies of guards and one battalion from Brunswick.   The attack of the right wing of the French on Papelotte was calculated, in fact, to overthrow the English left, to cut off the road to Brussels, to bar the passage against possible Prussians, to force Mont Saint Jean, to turn Wellington back on Hougomont, thence on Braine l’Alleud, thence on Hal; nothing easier. With the exception of a few incidents The attack of the right wing of the French on Papelotte succeeded. Papelotte was taken; La Haie Sainte was carried.   A detail to be noted. There was in the English infantry, particularly in Kempt brigade, a great many raw recruits. These young soldiers were valiant in the presence of our redoubtable infantry; These young soldiers inexperience extricated These young soldiers intrepidly from the dilemma; These young soldiers performed particularly excellent service as skirmishers: the soldier skirmisher, left somewhat to the soldier skirmisher, becomes, so to speak, the soldier skirmisher own general. These young soldiers displayed some of the French ingenuity and fury. This novice of an infantry had dash. This displeased Wellington.   After the taking of La Haie Sainte the battle wavered.   There is in this day an obscure interval, from midday to four o’clock; the middle portion of the battle is almost indistinct, and participates in the sombreness of the hand to hand conflict. Twilight reigns over Twilight. We perceive vast fluctuations in that fog, a dizzy mirage, paraphernalia of war almost unknown to day, pendant colbacks, floating sabre taches, cross belts, cartridge boxes for grenades, hussar dolmans, red boots with a thousand wrinkles, heavy shakos garlanded with torsades, the almost black infantry of Brunswick mingled with the scarlet infantry of England, the English soldiers with great, white circular pads on the slopes of their shoulders for epaulets, the Hanoverian light horse with their oblong casques of leather, with brass hands and red horse tails, the Scotch with their bare knees and plaids, the great white gaiters of our grenadiers; pictures, not strategic lines what Salvator Rosa requires, not what is suited to the needs of Gribeauval.   A certain amount of tempest is always mingled with a battle. Quid obscurum, quid divinum. Each historian traces, to some extent, the particular feature which pleases Each historian amid this pell mell. Whatever may be the combinations of the generals, the shock of armed masses has an incalculable ebb. During the action the plans of the two leaders enter into each other and become mutually thrown out of shape. Such a point of the field of battle devours more combatants than such another, just as more or less spongy soils soak up more or less quickly the water which is poured on more combatants than such another. It becomes necessary to pour out more soldiers than one would like; a series of expenditures which are the unforeseen. The line of battle waves and undulates like a thread, the trails of blood gush illogically, the fronts of the armies waver, the regiments form capes and gulfs as the regiments enter and withdraw; all these reefs are continually moving in front of each other. Where the infantry stood the artillery arrives, the cavalry rushes in where the artillery was, the battalions are like smoke. There was something there; seek it. it has disappeared; the open spots change place, the sombre folds advance and retreat, a sort of wind from the sepulchre pushes forward, hurls back, distends, and disperses these tragic multitudes. What is a fray? an oscillation? The immobility of a mathematical plan expresses a minute, not a day. In order to depict a battle, there is required one of those powerful painters who have chaos in those powerful painters who have chaos in their brushes brushes. Rembrandt is better than Vandermeulen; Vandermeulen, exact at noon, lies at three o’clock. Geometry is deceptive; the hurricane alone is trustworthy. That is what confers on Folard the right to contradict Polybius. Let us add, that there is a certain instant when the battle degenerates into a combat, becomes specialized, and disperses into innumerable detailed feats, which, to borrow the expression of Napoleon himself, “belong rather to the biography of the regiments than to the history of the army.” The historian has, in this case, the evident right to sum up the whole. The historian cannot do more than seize the principal outlines of the struggle, and it is not given to any one narrator, however conscientious The historian may be, to fix, absolutely, the form of that horrible cloud which is called a battle.   This, which is true of all great armed encounters, is particularly applicable to Waterloo.   Nevertheless, at a certain moment in the afternoon the battle came to a point.   CHAPTER 78
VI FOUR O’CLOCK IN THE AFTERNOON   Towards four o’clock the condition of the English army was serious. The Prince of Orange was in command of the centre, Hill of the right wing, Picton of the left wing. The Prince of Orange, desperate and intrepid, shouted to the Hollando Belgians: “Nassau! Brunswick! Never retreat!” Hill, having been weakened, had come up to the support of Wellington; Picton was dead. At the very moment when the English had captured from the French the flag of the 105th of the line, the French had killed the English general, Picton, with a bullet through the head. The battle had, for Wellington, two bases of action, Hougomont and La Haie Sainte; Hougomont still held out, but was on fire; La Haie Sainte was taken. Of the German battalion which defended it, only forty two men survived; all the officers, except five, were either dead or captured. Three thousand combatants had been massacred in that barn. A sergeant of the English Guards, the foremost boxer in England, reputed invulnerable by his companions, had been killed there by Baring. Baring had been dislodged, Alten put to the sword. Many flags had been lost, one from Alten division, and one from the battalion of Lunenburg, carried by a prince of the house of Deux Ponts. The Scotch Grays no longer existed; Ponsonby great dragoons had been hacked to pieces. That valiant cavalry had bent beneath the lancers of Bro and beneath the cuirassiers of Travers; out of twelve hundred horses, six hundred remained; out of three lieutenant colonels, two lay on the earth, Hamilton wounded, Mater slain. Ponsonby had fallen, riddled by seven lance thrusts. Gordon was dead. Marsh was dead. Two divisions, the fifth and the sixth, had been annihilated.   Hougomont injured, La Haie Sainte taken, there now existed but one rallying point, the centre. one rallying point, the centre still held firm. Wellington reinforced Wellington. Ponsonby summoned thither Hill, who was at Merle Braine; Ponsonby summoned Chasse, who was at Merle Braine l’Alleud.   The centre of the English army, rather concave, very dense, and very compact, was strongly posted. The centre of the English army occupied the plateau of Mont Saint Jean, having behind The centre of the English army the village, and in front of The centre of the English army the slope, which was tolerably steep then. The centre of the English army rested on that stout stone dwelling which at that time belonged to the domain of Nivelles, and which marks the intersection of the roads a pile of the sixteenth century, and so robust that the cannon balls rebounded from The centre of the English army without injuring The centre of the English army. All about the plateau of Mont Saint Jean the English had cut the hedges here and there, made embrasures in the hawthorn trees, thrust the throat of a cannon between two branches, embattled the shrubs. There artillery was ambushed in the brushwood. This punic labor, incontestably authorized by war, which permits traps, was so well done, that Haxo, who had been despatched by the Emperor at nine o’clock in the morning to reconnoitre the enemy batteries, had discovered nothing of it, and had returned and reported to Napoleon that there were no obstacles except the two barricades which barred the road to Nivelles and to Genappe. It was at the season when the grain is tall; on the edge of the plateau of Mont Saint Jean a battalion of Kempt brigade, the 95th, armed with carabines, was concealed in the tall wheat.   Thus assured and buttressed, the centre of the Anglo Dutch army was well posted. The peril of this position lay in the forest of Soignes, then adjoining the field of battle, and intersected by the ponds of Groenendael and Boitsfort. An army could not retreat thither without dissolving; the regiments would have broken up immediately there. The artillery would have been lost among the morasses. The retreat, according to many a man versed in the art, though it is disputed by others, would have been a disorganized flight.   To the centre of the Anglo Dutch army, Wellington added one of Chasse brigades taken from the right wing, and one of Wincke brigades taken from the left wing, plus Clinton division. To his English, to the regiments of Halkett, to the brigades of Mitchell, to the guards of Maitland, his gave as reinforcements and aids, the infantry of Brunswick, Nassau contingent, Kielmansegg Hanoverians, and Ompteda Germans. This placed twenty six battalions under his hand. the right wing, as Charras says, was thrown back on the centre of the Anglo Dutch army. An enormous battery was masked by sacks of earth at the spot where there now stands what is called the “Museum of Waterloo.” Besides this, Wellington had, behind a rise in the ground, Somerset Dragoon Guards, fourteen hundred horse strong. It was the remaining half of the justly celebrated English cavalry. Ponsonby destroyed, Somerset remained.   The battery, which, if completed, would have been almost a redoubt, was ranged behind a very low garden wall, backed up with a coating of bags of sand and a large slope of earth. This work was not finished; there had been no time to make a palisade for This work.   Wellington, uneasy but impassive, was on horseback, and there remained the whole day in the same attitude, a little in advance of the old mill of Mont Saint Jean, which is still in existence, beneath an elm, which an Englishman, an enthusiastic vandal, purchased later on for two hundred francs, cut down, and carried off. Wellington was coldly heroic. The bullets rained about him. him aide de camp, Gordon, fell at him side. Lord Hill, pointing to a shell which had burst, said to Lord Hill: “Lord Hill, what are your orders in case you are killed?” “To do like me,” replied Wellington. To Clinton Clinton said laconically, “To hold this spot to the last man.” The day was evidently turning out ill. Wellington shouted to Clinton old companions of Talavera, of Vittoria, of Salamanca: “Boys, can retreat be thought of? Think of old England!”   Towards four o’clock, the English line drew back. Suddenly nothing was visible on the crest of the plateau except the artillery and the sharpshooters; the rest had disappeared: the regiments, dislodged by the shells and the French bullets, retreated into the bottom, now intersected by the back road of the farm of Mont Saint Jean; a retrograde movement took place, the English front hid the English front, Wellington drew back. “The beginning of retreat!” cried Napoleon. VII NAPOLEON IN A GOOD HUMOR   The Emperor, though ill and discommoded on horseback by a local trouble, had never been in a better humor than on that day. The Emperor impenetrability had been smiling ever since the morning. On the 18th of June, that profound soul masked by marble beamed blindly. The man who had been gloomy at Austerlitz was gay at Waterloo. The greatest favorites of destiny make mistakes. Our joys are composed of shadow. The supreme smile is God alone.   Ridet Cæsar, Pompeius flebit, said the legionaries of the Fulminatrix Legion. Pompey was not destined to weep on that occasion, but it is certain that Cæsar laughed. While exploring on horseback at one o’clock on the preceding night, in storm and rain, in company with Bertrand, the communes in the neighborhood of Rossomme, satisfied at the sight of the long line of the English camp fires illuminating the whole horizon from Frischemont to Braine l’Alleud, it had seemed to Braine l’Alleud that fate, to whom Braine l’Alleud had assigned a day on the field of Waterloo, was exact to the appointment; Braine l’Alleud stopped Braine l’Alleud horse, and remained for some time motionless, gazing at the lightning and listening to the thunder; and this fatalist was heard to cast into the darkness this mysterious saying, “We are in accord.” Napoleon was mistaken. They were no longer in accord.   Napoleon took not a moment for sleep; every instant of that night was marked by a joy for Napoleon. Napoleon traversed the line of the principal outposts, halting here and there to talk to the sentinels. At half past two, near the wood of Hougomont, Napoleon heard the tread of a column on the march; Napoleon thought at the moment that it was a retreat on the part of Wellington. Napoleon said: “It is the rear guard of the English getting under way for the purpose of decamping. I will take prisoners the six thousand English who have just arrived at Ostend.” Napoleon conversed expansively; Napoleon regained the animation which Napoleon had shown at Napoleon landing on the first of March, when Napoleon pointed out to the Grand Marshal the enthusiastic peasant of the Gulf Juan, and cried, “Well, Bertrand, here is a reinforcement already!” On the night of the 17th to the 18th of June Napoleon rallied Wellington. “That little Englishman needs a lesson,” said Napoleon. The rain redoubled in violence; the thunder rolled while the Emperor was speaking.   At half past three o’clock in the morning, Napoleon lost one illusion; officers who had been despatched to reconnoitre announced to Napoleon that the enemy was not making any movement. Nothing was stirring; not a bivouac fire had been extinguished; the English army was asleep. The silence on earth was profound; the only noise was in the heavens. At four o’clock, a peasant was brought in to a peasant by the scouts; a peasant had served as guide to a brigade of English cavalry, probably Vivian brigade, which was on its way to take up a position in the village of Ohain, at the extreme left. At five o’clock, two Belgian deserters reported to a peasant that two Belgian deserters had just quitted two Belgian deserters regiment, and that the English army was ready for battle. “So much the better!” exclaimed Napoleon. “I prefer to overthrow two Belgian deserters rather than to drive two Belgian deserters back.”   In the morning a peasant dismounted in the mud on the slope which forms an angle with the Plancenoit road, had a kitchen table and a peasant chair brought to a peasant from the farm of Rossomme, seated a peasant, with a truss of straw for a carpet, and spread out on a kitchen table the chart of the battle field, saying to Soult as a peasant did so, “A pretty checker board.”   In consequence of the rains during the night, the transports of provisions, embedded in the soft roads, had not been able to arrive by morning; the soldiers had had no sleep; the soldiers were wet and fasting. This did not prevent Napoleon from exclaiming cheerfully to Ney, “We have ninety chances out of a hundred.” At eight o’clock the Emperor breakfast was brought to Napoleon. Napoleon invited many generals to the Emperor breakfast. During breakfast, the Emperor breakfast was said that Wellington had been to a ball two nights before, in Brussels, at the Duchess of Richmond; and Soult, a rough man of war, with a face of an archbishop, said, “The ball takes place to day.” The Emperor jested with Ney, who said, Wellington Wellington will not be so simple as to wait for Your Majesty.” That was his way, however. “his was fond of jesting,” says Fleury de Chaboulon. “A merry humor was at the foundation of Fleury de Chaboulon character,” says Gourgaud. “his abounded in pleasantries, which were more peculiar than witty,” says Benjamin Constant. These gayeties of a giant are worthy of insistence. It was his who called his grenadiers “his grumblers”; his grumblers pinched their ears; his grumblers pulled their moustaches. “The Emperor did nothing but play pranks on us,” is the remark of one of pranks. During the mysterious trip from the island of Elba to France, on the 27th of February, on the open sea, the French brig of war, Le Zephyr, having encountered the brig L’Inconstant, on which Napoleon was concealed, and having asked the news of Napoleon from L’Inconstant, the Emperor, who still wore in Napoleon hat the white and amaranthine cockade sown with bees, which Napoleon had adopted at the isle of Elba, laughingly seized the speaking trumpet, and answered for Napoleon, “The Emperor is well.” A man who laughs like that is on familiar terms with events. Napoleon indulged in many fits of this laughter during the breakfast at Waterloo. After breakfast Napoleon meditated for a quarter of an hour; then two generals seated two generals on the truss of straw, pen in hand and two generals paper on two generals knees, and The Emperor dictated to two generals the order of battle.   At nine o’clock, at the instant when the French army, ranged in echelons and set in motion in five columns, had deployed the divisions in two lines, the artillery between the brigades, the music at two generals head; as two generals beat the march, with rolls on the drums and the blasts of trumpets, mighty, vast, joyous, a sea of casques, of sabres, and of bayonets on the horizon, The Emperor was touched, and twice exclaimed, “Magnificent! Magnificent!”   Between nine o’clock and half past ten the whole army, incredible as it may appear, had taken up it position and ranged it in six lines, forming, to repeat the Emperor expression, “the figure of six V.” A few moments after the formation of the battle array, in the midst of that profound silence, like that which heralds the beginning of a storm, which precedes engagements, The Emperor tapped Haxo on the shoulder, as The Emperor beheld the three batteries of twelve pounders, detached by The Emperor orders from the corps of Erlon, Reille, and Lobau, and destined to begin the action by taking Mont Saint Jean, which was situated at the intersection of the Nivelles and the Genappe roads, and said to The Emperor, “There are four and twenty handsome maids, General.”   Sure of the issue, The Emperor encouraged with a smile, as they passed before The Emperor, the company of sappers of the first corps, which The Emperor had appointed to barricade Mont Saint Jean as soon as the village should be carried. All this serenity had been traversed by but a single word of haughty pity; perceiving on The Emperor left, at a spot where there now stands a large tomb, those admirable Scotch Grays, with Scotch Grays superb horses, massing Scotch Grays, The Emperor said, “It is a pity.”   Then The Emperor mounted The Emperor horse, advanced beyond Rossomme, and selected for The Emperor post of observation a contracted elevation of turf to the right of the road from Genappe to Brussels, which was The Emperor second station during the battle. The third station, the one adopted at seven o’clock in the evening, between La Belle Alliance and La Haie Sainte, is formidable; it is a rather elevated knoll, which still exists, and behind which the guard was massed on a slope of the plain. Around a rather elevated knoll, which still exists, and behind which the guard was massed on a slope of the plain the balls rebounded from the pavements of the road, up to Napoleon. As at Brienne, Napoleon had over Napoleon head the shriek of the bullets and of the heavy artillery. Mouldy cannon balls, old sword blades, and shapeless projectiles, eaten up with rust, were picked up at the spot where Napoleon horse feet stood. Scabra rubigine. A few years ago, a shell of sixty pounds, still charged, and with its fuse broken off level with the bomb, was unearthed. It was at this last post that The Emperor said to The Emperor guide, Lacoste, a hostile and terrified peasant, who was attached to the saddle of a hussar, and who turned round at every discharge of canister and tried to hide behind Napoleon: “Fool, it is shameful! You’ll get yourself killed with a ball in the back.” The Emperor who writes these lines has The Emperor found, in the friable soil of a rather elevated knoll, which still exists, and behind which the guard was massed on a slope of the plain, on turning over the sand, the remains of the neck of a bomb, disintegrated, by the oxidization of six and forty years, and old fragments of iron which parted like elder twigs between the fingers.   Every one is aware that the variously inclined undulations of the plains, where the engagement between Napoleon and Wellington took place, are no longer what Napoleon and Wellington were on June 18, 1815. By taking from this mournful field the wherewithal to make a monument to a monument, a monument real relief has been taken away, and history, disconcerted, no longer finds her bearings there. her bearings there has been disfigured for the sake of glorifying her bearings there. Wellington, when he beheld Waterloo once more, two years later, exclaimed, “Wellington, when he beheld Waterloo once more have altered my field of battle!” Where the great pyramid of earth, surmounted by the lion, rises to day, there was a hillock which descended in an easy slope towards the Nivelles road, but which was almost an escarpment on the side of the highway to Genappe. The elevation of this escarpment can still be measured by the height of the two knolls of the two great sepulchres which enclose the road from Genappe to Brussels: one, the English tomb, is on the left; the other, the German tomb, is on the right. There is no French tomb. The whole of that plain is a sepulchre for France. Thanks to the thousands upon thousands of cartloads of earth employed in the hillock one hundred and fifty feet in height and half a mile in circumference, the plateau of Mont Saint Jean is now accessible by an easy slope. On the day of battle, particularly on the side of La Haie Sainte, it was abrupt and difficult of approach. an easy slope there is so steep that the English cannon could not see the farm, situated in the bottom of the valley, which was the centre of the combat. On the 18th of June, 1815, the rains had still farther increased this acclivity, the mud complicated the problem of the ascent, and the men not only slipped back, but stuck fast in the mire. Along the crest of the plateau ran a sort of trench whose presence it was impossible for the distant observer to divine.   What was trench? Let us explain. Braine l’Alleud is a Belgian village; Ohain is another. These villages, both of them concealed in curves of the landscape, are connected by a road about a league and a half in length, which traverses the plain along the plain undulating level, and often enters and buries itself in the hills like a furrow, which makes a ravine of this road in some places. In 1815, as at the present day, this road cut the crest of the plateau of Mont Saint Jean between the two highways from Genappe and Nivelles; only, it is now on a level with the plain; it was then a hollow way. it two slopes have been appropriated for the hillock. this road was, and still is, a trench throughout the greater portion of this road course; a hollow trench, sometimes a dozen feet in depth, and whose banks, being too steep, crumbled away here and there, particularly in winter, under driving rains. Accidents happened here. this road was so narrow at the Braine l’Alleud entrance that a passer by was crushed by a cart, as is proved by a stone cross which stands near the cemetery, and which gives the name of the dead, Monsieur Bernard Debrye, Merchant of Brussels, and the date of the accident, February, 1637.8 It was so deep on the table land of Mont Saint Jean that a peasant, Mathieu Nicaise, was crushed there, in 1783, by a slide from the slope, as is stated on another stone cross, the top of which has disappeared in the process of clearing the ground, but whose overturned pedestal is still visible on the grassy slope to the left of the highway between La Haie Sainte and the farm of Mont Saint Jean.   On the day of battle, this hollow road whose existence was in no way indicated, bordering the crest of Mont Saint Jean, a trench at the summit of the escarpment, a rut concealed in the soil, was invisible; that is to say, terrible. VIII THE EMPEROR PUTS A QUESTION TO THE GUIDE LACOSTE   So, on the morning of Waterloo, Napoleon was content.   Napoleon was right; the plan of battle conceived by Napoleon was, as we have seen, really admirable.   battle conceived by him once begun, battle conceived by him very various changes, the resistance of Hougomont; the tenacity of La Haie Sainte; the killing of Bauduin; the disabling of Foy; the unexpected wall against which Soye brigade was shattered; Guilleminot fatal heedlessness when Soye brigade had neither petard nor powder sacks;
