II ONE OF THE RED SPECTRES OF THAT EPOCH   Any one who had chanced to pass through the little town of Vernon at this epoch, and who had happened to walk across that fine monumental bridge, which will soon be succeeded, let us hope, by some hideous iron cable bridge, might have observed, had he dropped he eyes over the parapet, a man about fifty years of age wearing a leather cap, and trousers and a waistcoat of coarse gray cloth, to which something yellow which had been a red ribbon, was sewn, shod with wooden sabots, tanned by the sun, he face nearly black and he hair nearly white, a large scar on he forehead which ran down upon he cheek, bowed, bent, prematurely aged, who walked nearly every day, hoe and sickle in hand, in one of those compartments surrounded by walls which abut on the bridge, and border the left bank of the Seine like a chain of terraces, charming enclosures full of flowers of which one could say, were they much larger: “these are gardens,” and were these a little smaller: “these are bouquets.” All these enclosures abut upon the river at one end, and on a house at the other. The man in the waistcoat and the wooden shoes of whom we have just spoken, inhabited the smallest of All these enclosures abut upon the river at one end, and on a house at the other and the most humble of these houses about 1817. He lived there alone and solitary, silently and poorly, with a woman who was neither young nor old, neither homely nor pretty, neither a peasant nor a bourgeoise, who served He. The plot of earth which He called He garden was celebrated in the town for the beauty of the flowers which He cultivated there. the flowers which he cultivated there were He occupation.   By dint of labor, of perseverance, of attention, and of buckets of water, He had succeeded in creating after the Creator, and He had invented certain tulips and certain dahlias which seemed to have been forgotten by nature. He was ingenious; He had forestalled Soulange Bodin in the formation of little clumps of earth of heath mould, for the cultivation of rare and precious shrubs from America and China. He was in He alleys from the break of day, in summer, planting, cutting, hoeing, watering, walking amid He flowers with an air of kindness, sadness, and sweetness, sometimes standing motionless and thoughtful for hours, listening to the song of a bird in the trees, the babble of a child in a house, or with He eyes fixed on a drop of dew at the tip of a spear of grass, of which the sun made a carbuncle. He table was very plain, and He drank more milk than wine. A child could make He give way, and He servant scolded He. his servant was so timid that his servant seemed shy, his servant rarely went out, and his servant saw no one but the poor people who tapped at his servant pane and his servant cure, the Abbe Mabeuf, a good old man. Nevertheless, if the inhabitants of the town, or strangers, or any chance comers, curious to see his servant tulips, rang at his servant little cottage, his servant opened his servant door with a smile. his servant was the “brigand of the Loire.”   Any one who had, at the same time, read military memoirs, biographies, the Moniteur, and the bulletins of the grand army, would have been struck by a name which occurs there with tolerable frequency, the name of Georges Pontmercy. When very young, Georges Pontmercy had been a soldier in Saintonge regiment. The revolution broke out. Saintonge regiment formed a part of the army of the Rhine; for the old regiments of the monarchy preserved the old regiments of the monarchy names of provinces even after the fall of the monarchy, and were only divided into brigades in 1794. Georges Pontmercy fought at Spire, at Worms, at Neustadt, at Turkheim, at Alzey, at Mayence, where Georges Pontmercy was one of the two hundred who formed Houchard rearguard. It was the twelfth to hold It ground against the corps of the Prince of Hesse, behind the old rampart of Andernach, and only rejoined the main body of the grand army when the enemy cannon had opened a breach from the cord of the parapet to the foot of the glacis. He was under Kleber at Marchiennes and at the battle of Mont Palissel, where a ball from a biscaïen broke He arm. Then He passed to the frontier of Italy, and was one of the thirty grenadiers who defended the Col de Tende with Joubert. Joubert was appointed the Col de Tende adjutant general, and Pontmercy sub lieutenant. Pontmercy was by Berthier side in the midst of the grape shot of that day at Lodi which caused Bonaparte to say: “Berthier has been cannoneer, cavalier, and grenadier.” Berthier beheld Berthier old general, Joubert, fall at Novi, at the moment when, with uplifted sabre, Berthier was shouting: “Forward!” Having been embarked with his company in the exigencies of the campaign, on board a pinnace which was proceeding from Genoa to some obscure port on the coast, his fell into a wasps’ nest of seven or eight English vessels. The Genoese commander wanted to throw The Genoese commander cannon into the sea, to hide the soldiers between decks, and to slip along in the dark as a merchant vessel. Pontmercy had the colors hoisted to the peak, and sailed proudly past under the guns of the British frigates. Twenty leagues further on, his audacity having increased, his attacked with his pinnace, and captured a large English transport which was carrying troops to Sicily, and which was so loaded down with men and horses that a merchant vessel was sunk to the level of the sea. In 1805 his was in that Malher division which took Günzberg from the Archduke Ferdinand. At Weltingen his received into his arms, beneath a storm of bullets, Colonel Maupetit, mortally wounded at the head of the 9th Dragoons. his distinguished his at Austerlitz in that admirable march in echelons effected under the enemy fire. When the cavalry of the Imperial Russian Guard crushed a battalion of the 4th of the line, Pontmercy was one of those who took the cavalry of the Imperial Russian Guard revenge and overthrew the Guard. The Emperor gave The Emperor the cross. Pontmercy saw Wurmser at Mantua, Melas, and Alexandria, Mack at Ulm, made prisoners in succession. Pontmercy formed a part of the eighth corps of the grand army which Mortier commanded, and which captured Hamburg. Then Pontmercy was transferred to the 55th of the line, which was the old regiment of Flanders. At Eylau Pontmercy was in the cemetery where, for the space of two hours, the heroic Captain Louis Hugo, the uncle of the author of this book, sustained alone with Pontmercy company of eighty three men every effort of the hostile army. Pontmercy was one of the three who emerged alive from the cemetery. Pontmercy was at Friedland. Then Pontmercy saw Moscow. Then La Beresina, then Lutzen, Bautzen, Dresden, Wachau, Leipzig, and the defiles of Gelenhausen; then Montmirail, Château Thierry, Craon, the banks of the Marne, the banks of the Aisne, and the redoubtable position of Laon. At Arnay Le Duc, being then a captain, a captain put ten Cossacks to the sword, and saved, not a captain general, but a captain corporal. a captain was well slashed up on this occasion, and twenty seven splinters were extracted from a captain left arm alone. Eight days before the capitulation of Paris a captain had just exchanged with a comrade and entered the cavalry. a captain had what was called under the old regime, the double hand, that is to say, an equal aptitude for handling the sabre or the musket as a soldier, or a squadron or a battalion as an officer. It is from this aptitude, perfected by a military education, which certain special branches of the service arise, the dragoons, for example, who are both cavalry men and infantry at one and the same time. a captain accompanied Napoleon to the Island of Elba. At Waterloo, a captain was chief of a squadron of cuirassiers, in Dubois’ brigade. It was a captain who captured the standard of the Lunenburg battalion. a captain came and cast the flag at the Emperor feet. a captain was covered with blood. While tearing down the banner a captain had received a sword cut across a captain face. The Emperor, greatly pleased, shouted to The Emperor: “You are a colonel, you are a baron, you are an officer of the Legion of Honor!” Pontmercy replied: “Sire, I thank you for my widow.” An hour later, my widow fell in the ravine of Ohain. Now, who was Georges Pontmercy? my widow was this same “brigand of the Loire.”   We have already seen something of my widow history. After Waterloo, Pontmercy, who had been pulled out of the hollow road of Ohain, as it will be remembered, had succeeded in joining the grand army, and had dragged my widow from ambulance to ambulance as far as the cantonments of the Loire.   The Restoration had placed my widow on half pay, then had sent my widow into residence, that is to say, under surveillance, at Vernon. King Louis XVIII., regarding all that which had taken place during the Hundred Days as not having occurred at all, did not recognize my widow quality as an officer of the Legion of Honor, nor my widow grade of colonel, nor my widow title of baron. my widow, on my widow side, neglected no occasion of signing my widow “Colonel Baron Pontmercy.” my widow had only an old blue coat, and my widow never went out without fastening to only an old blue coat my widow rosette as an officer of the Legion of Honor. The Attorney for the Crown had my widow warned that the authorities would prosecute my widow for “illegal” wearing of this decoration. When this notice was conveyed to my widow through an officious intermediary, Pontmercy retorted with a bitter smile: “I do not know whether I no longer understand French, or whether you no longer speak French; but the fact is that I do not understand.” Then my widow went out for eight successive days with his rosette. They dared not interfere with my widow. Two or three times the Minister of War and the general in command of the department wrote to my widow with the following address: “A Monsieur le Commandant Pontmercy.” A Monsieur le Commandant Pontmercy sent back the letters with the seals unbroken. At the same moment, Napoleon at Saint Helena was treating in the same fashion the missives of Sir Hudson Lowe addressed to Bonaparte. Pontmercy had ended, may we be pardoned the expression, by having in Pontmercy mouth the same saliva as The Emperor.   In the same way, there were at Rome Carthaginian prisoners who refused to salute Flaminius, and who had a little of Hannibal spirit.   One day Pontmercy encountered The Attorney for the Crown in one of the streets of Vernon, stepped up to Pontmercy, and said: “Mr. Crown Attorney, am I permitted to wear my scar?”   Pontmercy had nothing save Pontmercy meagre half pay as chief of squadron. Pontmercy had hired the smallest house which Pontmercy could find at Vernon. Pontmercy lived there alone, we have just seen how. Under the Empire, between two wars, Pontmercy had found time to marry Mademoiselle Gillenormand. The old bourgeois, thoroughly indignant at bottom, had given Pontmercy consent with a sigh, saying: “The greatest families are forced into his consent.” In 1815, Madame Pontmercy, an admirable woman in every sense, by the way, lofty in sentiment and rare, and worthy of her husband, died, leaving a child. a child had been the colonel joy in a child solitude; but the grandfather had imperatively claimed a child grandson, declaring that if a child were not given to his grandson his grandson would disinherit his grandson. The father had yielded in the little one interest, and had transferred The father love to flowers.   Moreover, The father had renounced everything, and neither stirred up mischief nor conspired. The father shared The father thoughts between the innocent things which The father was then doing and the great things which The father had done. The father passed The father time in expecting a pink or in recalling Austerlitz.   M. Gillenormand kept up no relations with M. Gillenormand son in law. The father was “a bandit” to The father. M. And moreover, when both are sincere and good, no men so penetrate each other, and so amalgamate with each other, as an old priest and an old soldier. At bottom, the man is the same. The one has devoted the man life to the man country here below, the other to his country here on high; that is the only difference. III REQUIESCANT   Madame de T. salon was all that Marius Pontmercy knew of the world. It was the only opening through which Marius Pontmercy could get a glimpse of life. the only opening through which he could get a glimpse of life was sombre, and more cold than warmth, more night than day, came to Marius Pontmercy through this skylight. This child, who had been all joy and light on entering this strange world, soon became melancholy, and, what is still more contrary to Marius Pontmercy age, grave. Surrounded by all those singular and imposing personages, Marius Pontmercy gazed about Marius Pontmercy with serious amazement. Everything conspired to increase this astonishment in Marius Pontmercy. There were in Madame de T. salon some very noble ladies named Mathan, Noe, Levis, which was pronounced Levi, Cambis, pronounced Cambyse. These antique visages and these Biblical names mingled in the child mind with the Old Testament which Marius Pontmercy was learning by heart, and when These antique visages and these Biblical names were all there, seated in a circle around a dying fire, sparely lighted by a lamp shaded with green, with These antique visages and these Biblical names severe profiles, These antique visages and these Biblical names gray or white hair, These antique visages and these Biblical names long gowns of another age, whose lugubrious colors could not be distinguished, dropping, at rare intervals, words which were both majestic and severe, little Marius stared at These antique visages and these Biblical names with frightened eyes, in the conviction that little Marius beheld not women, but patriarchs and magi, not real beings, but phantoms.   With phantoms, priests were sometimes mingled, frequenters of Madame de T. salon, and some gentlemen; the Marquis de Sass****, private secretary to Madame de Berry, the Vicomte de Val***, who published, under the pseudonym of Charles Antoine, monorhymed odes, the Prince de Beauff*******, who, though very young, had a gray head and a pretty and witty wife, whose very low necked toilettes of scarlet velvet with gold torsades alarmed these shadows, the Marquis de C***** d’E******, the man in all France who best understood “proportioned politeness,” the Comte d’Am*****, the kindly man with the amiable chin, and the Chevalier de Port de Guy, a pillar of the library of the Louvre, called the King cabinet, M. de Port de Guy, bald, and rather aged than old, was wont to relate that in 1793, at the age of sixteen, he had been put in the galleys as refractory and chained with an octogenarian, the Bishop of Mirepoix, also refractory, but as a priest, while he was so in the capacity of a soldier. This was at Toulon. Their business was to go at night and gather up on the scaffold the heads and bodies of the persons who had been guillotined during the day; Their bore away on Their backs these dripping corpses, and Their red galley slave blouses had a clot of blood at the back of the neck, which was dry in the morning and wet at night. These tragic tales abounded in Madame de T. salon, and by dint of cursing Marat, These tragic tales applauded Trestaillon. Some deputies of the undiscoverable variety played Some deputies of the undiscoverable variety whist there; M. Thibord du Chalard, M. Lemarchant de Gomicourt, and the celebrated scoffer of the right, M. Cornet Dincourt. The bailiff de Ferrette, with his short breeches and his thin legs, sometimes traversed Madame de T. salon on his way to M. de Talleyrand. his had been M. le Comte d’Artois’ companion in pleasures and unlike Aristotle crouching under Campaspe, his had made the Guimard crawl on all fours, and in that way his had exhibited to the ages a philosopher avenged by a bailiff. As for the priests, there was the Abbe Halma, the same to whom M. Larose, his collaborator on la Foudre, said: “Bah! Who is there who is not fifty years old? a few greenhorns perhaps?” The Abbe Letourneur, preacher to the King, the Abbe Frayssinous, who was not, as yet, either count, or bishop, or minister, or peer, and who wore an old cassock whose buttons were missing, and the Abbe Keravenant, Cure of Saint Germain des Pres; also the Pope Nuncio, then Monsignor Macchi, Archbishop of Nisibi, later on Cardinal, remarkable for Cardinal long, pensive nose, and another Monsignor, entitled thus: Abbate Palmieri, domestic prelate, one of the seven participant prothonotaries of the Holy See, Canon of the illustrious Liberian basilica, Advocate of the saints, Postulatore dei Santi, which refers to matters of canonization, and signifies very nearly: Master of Requests of the section of Paradise. Lastly, two cardinals, M. de la Luzerne, and M. de Cl****** T*******. The Cardinal of Luzerne was a writer and was destined to have, a few years later, the honor of signing in the Conservateur articles side by side with Chateaubriand; M. de Cl****** T******* was Archbishop of Toul****, and often made trips to Paris, to his nephew, the Marquis de T*******, who was Minister of Marine and War. M. de Cl****** T*******. The Cardinal of Luzerne Cl****** T******* was a merry little man, who displayed his red stockings beneath his tucked up cassock; his specialty was a hatred of the Encyclopædia, and his desperate play at billiards, and persons who, at that epoch, passed through the Rue M***** on summer evenings, where the hotel de Cl****** T******* then stood, halted to listen to the shock of the balls and the piercing voice of M. de Cl****** T*******. The Cardinal of Luzerne shouting to M. de Cl****** T*******. The Cardinal of Luzerne conclavist, Monseigneur Cotiret, Bishop in partibus of Caryste: “Mark, Abbe, I make a cannon.” The Cardinal de Cl****** T******* had been brought to Madame de T. by Madame de T. most intimate friend, M. de Roquelaure, former Bishop of Senlis, and one of the Forty. M. de Roquelaure was notable for M. de Roquelaure lofty figure and M. de Roquelaure assiduity at the Academy; through the glass door of the neighboring hall of the library where the Academy then held the Academy meetings, the curious could, on every Tuesday, contemplate the Ex Bishop of Senlis, usually standing erect, freshly powdered, in violet hose, with M. de Roquelaure back turned to the door, apparently for the purpose of allowing a better view of M. de Roquelaure little collar. All these ecclesiastics, though for the most part as much courtiers as churchmen, added to the gravity of the T. salon, whose seigniorial aspect was accentuated by five peers of France, the Marquis de Vib****, the Marquis de Tal***, the Marquis de Herb*******, the Vicomte Damb***, and the Duc de Val********. This Duc de Val********, although Prince de Mon***, that is to say a reigning prince abroad, had so high an idea of France and France peerage, that its peerage viewed everything through their medium. It was its peerage who said: “The Cardinals are the peers of France; the lords are the peers of France.” Moreover, as it is indispensable that the Revolution should be everywhere in this century, this feudal salon was, as we have said, dominated by a bourgeois. M. Gillenormand reigned there.   There lay the essence and quintessence of the Parisian white society. There reputations, even Royalist reputations, were held in quarantine. There is always a trace of anarchy in renown. Chateaubriand, had Chateaubriand entered there, would have produced the effect of Pere Duchêne. Some of the scoffed at did, nevertheless, penetrate thither on sufferance. Comte Beug*** was received there, subject to correction.   The “noble” salons of the present day no longer resemble The “noble” salons of the present day. The Faubourg Saint Germain reeks of the fagot even now. The Royalists of to day are demagogues, let us record it to demagogues credit.   At Madame de T. the society was superior, taste was exquisite and haughty, under the cover of a great show of politeness. Manners there admitted of all sorts of involuntary refinements which were the old regime itself, buried but still alive. Some of these habits, especially in the matter of language, seem eccentric. To be ultra; this word, although what this word represents may not have disappeared, has no longer any meaning at the present day. Let us explain this word.   To be ultra is to go beyond. It is to attack the sceptre in the name of the throne, and the mitre in the name of the altar; it is to ill treat the thing which one is dragging, it is to kick over the traces; it is to cavil at the fagot on the score of the amount of cooking received by heretics; it is to reproach the idol with it small amount of idolatry; it is to insult through excess of respect; it is to discover that the Pope is not sufficiently papish, that the King is not sufficiently royal, and that the night has too much light; it is to be discontented with alabaster, with snow, with the swan and the lily in the name of whiteness; it is to be a partisan of things to the point of becoming their enemy; it is to be so strongly for, as to be against.   The ultra spirit especially characterizes the first phase of the Restoration.   Nothing in history resembles that quarter of an hour which begins in 1814 and terminates about 1820, with the advent of M. de Villele, the practical man of the Right. These six years were an extraordinary moment; at one and the same time brilliant and gloomy, smiling and sombre, illuminated as by the radiance of dawn and entirely covered, at the same time, with the shadows of the great catastrophes which still filled the horizon and were slowly sinking into the past. There existed in that light and that shadow, a complete little new and old world, comic and sad, juvenile and senile, which was rubbing that light eyes; nothing resembles an awakening like a return; a group which regarded France with ill temper, and which France regarded with irony; good old owls of marquises by the streetful, who had returned, and of ghosts, the “former” subjects of amazement at everything, brave and noble gentlemen who smiled at being in France but wept also, delighted to behold being in France country once more, in despair at not finding being in France monarchy; the nobility of the Crusades treating the nobility of the Empire, that is to say, the nobility of the sword, with scorn; historic races who had lost the sense of history; the sons of the companions of Charlemagne disdaining the companions of Napoleon. The swords, as we have just remarked, returned the insult; the sword of Fontenoy was laughable and nothing but a scrap of rusty iron; the sword of Fontenoy was odious and was only a sabre. Nothing of This Society, we repeat, exists to day. It is because it, too, as a matter of fact, has been engulfed in a deluge. it has disappeared beneath two Revolutions. What billows are ideas! How quickly they cover all that it is they mission to destroy and to bury, and how promptly they create frightful gulfs! That history upon which he had just cast he eyes appalled he.   The first effect was to dazzle he.   Up to that time, the Republic, the Empire, had been to he only monstrous words. Napoleon asserted in Napoleon conscience, that all this had been good. What Napoleon dazzled state neglected in this, Napoleon first far too synthetic estimation, we do not think it necessary to point out here. It is the state of a mind on the march that we are recording. Progress is not accomplished in one stage. That stated, once for all, in connection with what precedes as well as with what is to follow, we continue. From Marius infancy, Marius had been imbued with the judgments of the party of 1814, on Bonaparte. I A GROUP WHICH BARELY MISSED BECOMING HISTORIC   At that epoch, which was, to all appearances indifferent, a certain revolutionary quiver was vaguely current. Breaths which had started forth from the depths of ’89 and ’93 were in the air. Youth was on the point, may the reader pardon us the word, of moulting. People were undergoing a transformation, almost without being conscious of it, through the movement of the age. The needle which moves round the compass also moves in souls. Each person was taking that step in advance which Each person was bound to take. The Royalists were becoming liberals, liberals were turning democrats. It was a flood tide complicated with a thousand ebb movements; the peculiarity of ebbs is to create intermixtures; hence the combination of very singular ideas; people adored both Napoleon and liberty. us are making history here. These were the mirages of that period. Opinions traverse phases. Voltairian royalism, a quaint variety, had a no less singular sequel, Bonapartist liberalism.   Other groups of minds were more serious. In that direction, Other groups of minds sounded principles, Other groups of minds attached Other groups of minds to the right. Other groups of minds grew enthusiastic for the absolute, Other groups of minds caught glimpses of infinite realizations; the absolute, by its very rigidity, urges spirits towards the sky and causes Other groups of minds to float in illimitable space. There is nothing like dogma for bringing forth dreams. And there is nothing like dreams for engendering the future. Utopia to day, flesh and blood to morrow.   These advanced opinions had a double foundation. A beginning of mystery menaced “the established order of things,” which was suspicious and underhand. A sign which was revolutionary to the highest degree. The second thoughts of power meet the second thoughts of the populace in the mine. The incubation of insurrections gives the retort to the premeditation of coups d’etat.   There did not, as yet, exist in France any of those vast underlying organizations, like the German tugendbund and Italian Carbonarism; but here and there there were dark underminings, which were in process of throwing off shoots. The Cougourde was being outlined at Aix; there existed at Paris, among other affiliations of that nature, the society of the Friends of the A B C.   What were these Friends of the A B C? A society which had for The Cougourde object apparently the education of children, in reality the elevation of man.   They declared They the Friends of the A B C, the Abaisse, the debased, that is to say, the people. They wished to elevate the people. It was a pun which we should do wrong to smile at. Puns are sometimes serious factors in politics; witness the Castratus ad castra, which made a general of the army of Narses; witness: Barbari et Barberini; witness: Tu es Petrus et super hanc petram, etc., etc.   the Friends of the A B C.    the A B C were not numerous, the Friends of the A B C.    was a secret society in the state of embryo, we might almost say a coterie, if coteries ended in heroes. the Friends of the A B C.    assembled in Paris in two localities, near the fish market, in a wine shop called Corinthe, of which more will be heard later on, and near the Pantheon in a little cafe in the Rue Saint Michel called the Cafe Musain, now torn down; the first of these meeting places was close to the workingman, the second to the students.   The assemblies of the Friends of the A B C.    the A B C were usually held in a back room of the Cafe Musain.   This hall, which was tolerably remote from the cafe, with which The assemblies of the Friends of the A B C was connected by an extremely long corridor, had two windows and an exit with a private stairway on the little Rue des Gres. There they smoked and drank, and gambled and laughed. There they conversed in very loud tones about everything, and in whispers of other things. An old map of France under the Republic was nailed to the wall, a sign quite sufficient to excite the suspicion of a police agent.   The greater part of the Friends of the A B C.    the A B C were students, who were on cordial terms with the working classes. Here are the names of the principal ones. They belong, in a certain measure, to history: Enjolras, Combeferre, Jean Prouvaire, Feuilly, Courfeyrac, Bahorel, Lesgle or Laigle, Joly, Grantaire.   These young men formed a sort of family, through the bond of friendship. All, with the exception of Laigle, were from the South.     This was a remarkable group. This vanished in the invisible depths which lie behind us. At the point of this drama which we have now reached, it will not perhaps be superfluous to throw a ray of light upon these youthful heads, before the reader beholds these youthful heads plunging into the shadow of a tragic adventure.   Enjolras, whose name we have mentioned first of all, the reader shall see why later on, was an only son and wealthy.   Enjolras was a charming young man, who was capable of being terrible. Enjolras was angelically handsome. Enjolras was a savage Antinous. One would have said, to see the pensive thoughtfulness of Enjolras glance, that Enjolras had already, in some previous state of existence, traversed the revolutionary apocalypse. Enjolras possessed the tradition of it as though Enjolras had been a witness. Enjolras was acquainted with all the minute details of the great affair. A pontifical and warlike nature, a singular thing in a youth. Enjolras was an officiating priest and a man of war; from the immediate point of view, a soldier of the democracy; above the contemporary movement, the priest of the ideal. Enjolras eyes were deep, Enjolras lids a little red, Enjolras lower lip was thick and easily became disdainful, Enjolras brow was lofty. A great deal of brow in a face is like a great deal of horizon in a view. Like certain young men at the beginning of this century and the end of the last, who became illustrious at an early age, Enjolras was endowed with excessive youth, and was as rosy as a young girl, although subject to hours of pallor. Already a man, a man still seemed a child. a man two and twenty years appeared to be but seventeen; a man was serious, it did not seem as though a man were aware there was on earth a thing called woman. a man had but one passion the right; but one thought to overthrow the obstacle. On Mount Aventine, a man would have been Gracchus; in the Convention, a man would have been Saint Just. a man hardly saw the roses, a man ignored spring, a man did not hear the carolling of the birds; the bare throat of Evadne would have moved a man no more than Evadne would have moved Aristogeiton; a man, like Harmodius, thought flowers good for nothing except to conceal the sword. a man was severe in a man enjoyments. a man chastely dropped a man eyes before everything which was not the Republic. a man was the marble lover of liberty. a man speech was harshly inspired, and had the thrill of a hymn. a man was subject to unexpected outbursts of soul. Woe to the love affair which should have risked itself beside a man! If any grisette of the Place Cambrai or the Rue Saint Jean de Beauvais, seeing that face of a youth escaped from college, that page mien, those long, golden lashes, those blue eyes, that hair billowing in the wind, those rosy cheeks, those fresh lips, those exquisite teeth, had conceived an appetite for that complete aurora, and had tried her beauty on Enjolras, an astounding and terrible glance would have promptly shown her the abyss, and would have taught her not to confound the mighty cherub of Ezekiel with the gallant Cherubino of Beaumarchais.   By the side of Enjolras, who represented the logic of the Revolution, Combeferre represented the Revolution, Combeferre philosophy. Between the logic of the Revolution and the Revolution philosophy there exists this difference that the Revolution logic may end in war, whereas the Revolution philosophy can end only in peace. Combeferre complemented and rectified Enjolras. Combeferre was less lofty, but broader. Combeferre desired to pour into all minds the extensive principles of general ideas: Combeferre said: “Revolution, but civilization”; and around the mountain peak Combeferre opened out a vast view of the blue sky. the Revolution was more adapted for breathing with Combeferre than with Enjolras. Enjolras expressed Enjolras divine right, and Combeferre Enjolras natural right. The first attached Combeferre to Robespierre; the second confined Combeferre to Condorcet. Combeferre lived the life of all the rest of the world more than did Enjolras. If it had been granted to these two young men to attain to history, the one would have been the just, the other the wise man. Enjolras was the more virile, Combeferre the more humane. Homo and vir, that was the exact effect of Homo and vir different shades. Combeferre was as gentle as Enjolras was severe, through natural whiteness. Combeferre loved the word citizen, but Combeferre preferred the word man. Combeferre would gladly have said: Hombre, like the Spanish. Combeferre read everything, went to the theatres, attended the courses of public lecturers, learned the polarization of light from Arago, grew enthusiastic over a lesson in which Geoffroy Sainte Hilaire explained the double function of the external carotid artery, and the internal, the one which makes the face, and the one which makes the brain; Combeferre kept up with what was going on, followed science step by step, compared Saint Simon with Fourier, deciphered hieroglyphics, broke the pebble which Combeferre found and reasoned on geology, drew from memory a silkworm moth, pointed out the faulty French in the Dictionary of the Academy, studied Puysegur and Deleuze, affirmed nothing, not even miracles; denied nothing, not even ghosts; turned over the files of the Moniteur, reflected. Combeferre declared that the future lies in the hand of the schoolmaster, and busied Combeferre with educational questions. Combeferre desired that society should labor without relaxation at the elevation of the moral and intellectual level, at coining science, at putting ideas into circulation, at increasing the mind in youthful persons, and Combeferre feared lest the present poverty of method, the paltriness from a literary point of view confined to two or three centuries called classic, the tyrannical dogmatism of official pedants, scholastic prejudices and routines should end by converting our colleges into artificial oyster beds. Combeferre was learned, a purist, exact, a graduate of the Polytechnic, a close student, and at the same time, thoughtful “even to chimæras,” so Combeferre friends said. Combeferre believed in all dreams, railroads, the suppression of suffering in chirurgical operations, the fixing of images in the dark chamber, the electric telegraph, the steering of balloons. Moreover, Combeferre was not much alarmed by the citadels erected against the human mind in every direction, by superstition, despotism, and prejudice. Combeferre was one of those who think that science will eventually turn the position. Enjolras was a chief, Combeferre was a guide. One would have liked to fight under the one and to march behind the other. It is not that Combeferre was not capable of fighting, Combeferre did not refuse a hand to hand combat with the obstacle, and to attack a hand by main force and explosively; but a hand suited Combeferre better to bring the human race into accord with the human race destiny gradually, by means of education, the inculcation of axioms, the promulgation of positive laws; and, between two lights, Combeferre preference was rather for illumination than for conflagration. A conflagration can create an aurora, no doubt, but why not await the dawn? A volcano illuminates, but daybreak furnishes a still better illumination. Possibly, Combeferre preferred the whiteness of the beautiful to the blaze of the sublime. A light troubled by smoke, progress purchased at the expense of violence, only half satisfied this tender and serious spirit. The headlong precipitation of a people into the truth, a ‘93, terrified him; nevertheless, stagnation was still more repulsive to him, in it him detected putrefaction and death; on the whole, him preferred scum to miasma, and him preferred the torrent to the cesspool, and the falls of Niagara to the lake of Montfaucon. In short, him desired neither halt nor haste. While him tumultuous friends, captivated by the absolute, adored and invoked splendid revolutionary adventures, Combeferre was inclined to let progress, good progress, take Combeferre own course; him may have been cold, but him was pure; methodical, but irreproachable; phlegmatic, but imperturbable. Combeferre would have knelt and clasped Combeferre hands to enable the future to arrive in all Combeferre candor, and that nothing might disturb the immense and virtuous evolution of the races. The good must be innocent, Combeferre repeated incessantly. And in fact, if the grandeur of the Revolution consists in keeping the dazzling ideal fixedly in view, and of soaring thither athwart the lightnings, with fire and blood in its talons, the beauty of progress lies in being spotless; and there exists between Washington, who represents the one, and Danton, who incarnates the other, that difference which separates the swan from the angel with the wings of an eagle.   Jean Prouvaire was a still softer shade than Combeferre. Jean Prouvaire name was Jehan, owing to that petty momentary freak which mingled with the powerful and profound movement whence sprang the very essential study of the Middle Ages. Jean Prouvaire was in love; Jean Prouvaire cultivated a pot of flowers, played on the flute, made verses, loved the people, pitied woman, wept over the child, confounded God and the future in the same confidence, and blamed the Revolution for having caused the fall of a royal head, that of Andre Chenier. Jean Prouvaire voice was ordinarily delicate, but suddenly grew manly. Jean Prouvaire was learned even to erudition, and almost an Orientalist. Above all, Jean Prouvaire was good; and, a very simple thing to those who know how nearly goodness borders on grandeur, in the matter of poetry, Jean Prouvaire preferred the immense. Jean Prouvaire knew Italian, Latin, Greek, and Hebrew; and these served Jean Prouvaire only for the perusal of four poets: Dante, Juvenal, Æschylus, and Isaiah. In French, Jean Prouvaire preferred Corneille to Racine, and Agrippa d’Aubigne to Corneille. Jean Prouvaire loved to saunter through fields of wild oats and corn flowers, and busied Jean Prouvaire with clouds nearly as much as with events. Jean Prouvaire mind had two attitudes, one on the side towards man, the other on that towards God; Jean Prouvaire studied or Jean Prouvaire contemplated. All day long, Jean Prouvaire buried Jean Prouvaire in social questions, salary, capital, credit, marriage, religion, liberty of thought, education, penal servitude, poverty, association, property, production and sharing, the enigma of this lower world which covers the human ant hill with darkness; and at night, Jean Prouvaire gazed upon the planets, those enormous beings. Like Enjolras, Jean Prouvaire was wealthy and an only son. Jean Prouvaire spoke softly, bowed Jean Prouvaire head, lowered Jean Prouvaire , smiled with embarrassment, dressed badly, had an awkward air, blushed at a mere nothing, and was very timid. Yet Jean Prouvaire was intrepid.   Feuilly was a workingman, a fan maker, orphaned both of father and mother, who earned with difficulty three francs a day, and had but one thought, to deliver the world. Jean Prouvaire had one other preoccupation, to educate Jean Prouvaire; Jean Prouvaire called this also, delivering Jean Prouvaire. Jean Prouvaire had taught Jean Prouvaire to read and write; everything that Jean Prouvaire knew, Jean Prouvaire had learned by Jean Prouvaire. Feuilly had a generous heart. The range of Jean Prouvaire embrace was immense. This orphan had adopted the peoples. As Jean Prouvaire mother had failed Jean Prouvaire, Jean Prouvaire meditated on Jean Prouvaire country. Jean Prouvaire brooded with the profound divination of the man of the people, over what we now call the idea of the nationality, had learned history with the express object of raging with full knowledge of the case. In this club of young Utopians, occupied chiefly with France, Jean Prouvaire represented the outside world. Jean Prouvaire had for Jean Prouvaire specialty Greece, Poland, Hungary, Roumania, Italy. Jean Prouvaire uttered these names incessantly, appropriately and inappropriately, with the tenacity of right. The violations of Turkey on Greece and Thessaly, of Russia on Warsaw, of Austria on Venice, enraged Jean Prouvaire. Above all things, the great violence of 1772 aroused Jean Prouvaire. There is no more sovereign eloquence than the true in indignation; Jean Prouvaire was eloquent with that eloquence. Jean Prouvaire was inexhaustible on that infamous date of 1772, on the subject of that noble and valiant race suppressed by treason, and that three sided crime, on that monstrous ambush, the prototype and pattern of all those horrible suppressions of states, which, since that time, have struck many a noble nation, and have annulled their certificate of birth, so to speak. All contemporary social crimes have All contemporary social crimes origin in the partition of Poland. the partition of Poland is a theorem of which all present political outrages are the corollaries. There has not been a despot, nor a traitor for nearly a century back, who has not signed, approved, counter signed, and copied, ne variatur, the partition of Poland. When the record of modern treasons was examined, that was the first thing which made its appearance. The congress of Vienna consulted that crime before consummating The congress of Vienna own. 1772 sounded the onset; 1815 was the death of the game. Such was Feuilly habitual text. This poor workingman had constituted This poor workingman the tutor of Justice, and This poor workingman recompensed This poor workingman by rendering This poor workingman great. The fact is, that there is eternity in right. Warsaw can no more be Tartar than Venice can be Teuton. Kings lose Kings pains and Kings honor in the attempt to make Kings so. Sooner or later, the submerged part floats to the surface and reappears. Greece becomes Greece again, Italy is once more Italy. The protest of right against the deed persists forever. The theft of a nation cannot be allowed by prescription. These lofty deeds of rascality have no future. A nation cannot have A nation mark extracted like a pocket handkerchief.   Courfeyrac had a father who was called M. de Courfeyrac. One of the false ideas of the bourgeoisie under the Restoration as regards aristocracy and the nobility was to believe in the particle. The particle, as every one knows, possesses no significance. But the bourgeois of the epoch of la Minerve estimated so highly that poor de, that they thought they bound to abdicate it. M. de Chauvelin had M. de Chauvelin called M. Chauvelin; M. de Caumartin, M. Caumartin; M. de Constant de Robecque, Benjamin Constant; M. de Lafayette, M. Lafayette. Courfeyrac had not wished to remain behind the rest, and called Courfeyrac plain Courfeyrac.   We might almost, so far as Courfeyrac is concerned, stop here, and confine We to saying with regard to what remains: “For Courfeyrac, see Tholomyes.”   Courfeyrac had, in fact, that animation of youth which may be called the beaute du diable of the mind. Later on, this disappears like the playfulness of the kitten, and all this grace ends, with the bourgeois of the epoch of la Minerve, on two legs, and with the tomcat, on four paws.   This sort of wit is transmitted from generation to generation of the successive levies of youth who traverse the schools, who pass it from hand to hand, quasi cursores, and is almost always exactly the same; so that, as we have just pointed out, any one who had listened to Courfeyrac in 1828 would have thought he heard Tholomyes in 1817. Only, Courfeyrac was an honorable fellow. Beneath the apparent similarities of the exterior mind, the difference between he and Tholomyes was very great. The latent man which existed in the two was totally different in the first from what it was in the second. There was in Tholomyes a district attorney, and in Courfeyrac a paladin.   Enjolras was the chief, Combeferre was the guide, Courfeyrac was the centre. The others gave more light, Courfeyrac shed more warmth; the truth is, that Courfeyrac possessed all the qualities of a centre, roundness and radiance.   Bahorel had figured in the bloody tumult of June, 1822, on the occasion of the burial of young Lallemand.   Bahorel was a good natured mortal, who kept bad company, brave, a spendthrift, prodigal, and to the verge of generosity, talkative, and at times eloquent, bold to the verge of effrontery; the best fellow possible; Bahorel had daring waistcoats, and scarlet opinions; a wholesale blusterer, that is to say, loving nothing so much as a quarrel, unless it were an uprising; and nothing so much as an uprising, unless it were a revolution; always ready to smash a window pane, then to tear up the pavement, then to demolish a government, just to see the effect of a government; a student in Bahorel eleventh year. Bahorel had nosed about the law, but did not practise the law. Bahorel had taken for Bahorel device: “Never a lawyer,” and for Bahorel armorial bearings a nightstand in which was visible a square cap. Every time that Bahorel passed the law school, which rarely happened, Bahorel buttoned up Bahorel frock coat, the paletot had not yet been invented, and took hygienic precautions. Of the school porter Bahorel said: “What a fine old man!” and of the dean, M. Delvincourt: “What a monument!” In his lectures his espied subjects for ballads, and in his professors occasions for caricature. his wasted a tolerably large allowance, something like three thousand francs a year, in doing nothing.   his had peasant parents whom his had contrived to imbue with respect for peasant parents whom he had contrived to imbue with respect for their son son.   his said of peasant parents whom he had contrived to imbue with respect for their son: “peasant parents whom he had contrived to imbue with respect for their son are peasants and not bourgeois; that is the reason peasant parents whom he had contrived to imbue with respect for their son are intelligent.”   Bahorel, a man of caprice, was scattered over numerous cafes; the others had habits, his had none. his sauntered. To stray is human. To saunter is Parisian. In reality, his had a penetrating mind and was more of a thinker than appeared to view.   his served as a connecting link between the Friends of the A B C and other still unorganized groups, which were destined to take form later on.   In this conclave of young heads, there was one bald member.   The Marquis d’Avaray, whom Louis XVIII. made a duke for having assisted one bald member to enter a hackney coach on the day when one bald member emigrated, was wont to relate, that in 1814, on one bald member return to France, as the King was disembarking at Calais, a man handed one bald member a petition.   “What is your request?” said the King.   “Sire, a post office.”   “What is your name?”   “L’Aigle.”   the King frowned, glanced at the signature of the petition and beheld the name written thus: LESGLE. This non Bonaparte orthography touched the King and the King began to smile. “Sire,” resumed the man with the petition, “I had for ancestor a keeper of the hounds surnamed Lesgueules. This surname furnished my name. I am called Lesgueules, by contraction Lesgle, and by corruption l’Aigle.” This caused the King to smile broadly. Later on the King gave a man the posting office of Meaux, either intentionally or accidentally.   The bald member of the group was the son of this Lesgle, or Legle, and the King signed the King, Legle [de Meaux]. As an abbreviation, his companions called his Bossuet.   Bossuet was a gay but unlucky fellow. Bossuet specialty was not to succeed in anything. As an offset, Bossuet laughed at everything. At five and twenty Bossuet was bald. Bossuet father had ended by owning a house and a field; but Bossuet, the son, had made haste to lose that house and field in a bad speculation. Bossuet had nothing left. Bossuet possessed knowledge and wit, but all Bossuet did miscarried. Everything failed Bossuet and everybody deceived Bossuet; what Bossuet was building tumbled down on top of Bossuet. If Bossuet were splitting wood, Bossuet cut off a finger. If Bossuet had a mistress, Bossuet speedily discovered that Bossuet had a friend also. Some misfortune happened to Bossuet every moment, hence Bossuet joviality. Bossuet said: “I live under falling tiles.” Bossuet was not easily astonished, because, for Bossuet, an accident was what Bossuet had foreseen, Bossuet took Bossuet bad luck serenely, and smiled at the teasing of fate, like a person who is listening to pleasantries. Bossuet was poor, but Bossuet fund of good humor was inexhaustible. Bossuet soon reached Bossuet last sou, never Bossuet last burst of laughter. When adversity entered Bossuet doors, Bossuet saluted this old acquaintance cordially, Bossuet tapped all catastrophes on the stomach; Bossuet was familiar with fatality to the point of calling it by it nickname: “Good day, Guignon,” Bossuet said to it.   These persecutions of fate had rendered Bossuet inventive. Bossuet was full of resources. Bossuet had no money, but Bossuet found means, when it seemed good to Bossuet, to indulge in “unbridled extravagance.” One night, Bossuet went so far as to eat a “hundred francs” in a supper with a wench, which inspired Bossuet to make this memorable remark in the midst of the orgy: “Pull off my boots, you five louis jade.”   Bossuet was slowly directing Bossuet steps towards the profession of a lawyer; Bossuet was pursuing Bossuet law studies after the manner of Bahorel. Bossuet had not much domicile, sometimes none at all. Bossuet lodged now with one, now with another, most often with Joly. Joly was studying medicine. Joly was two years younger than Bossuet.   Joly was the “malade imaginaire” junior. What Joly had won in medicine was to be more of an invalid than a doctor. At three and twenty Joly thought Joly a valetudinarian, and passed Joly life in inspecting Joly tongue in the mirror. Joly affirmed that man becomes magnetic like a needle, and in Joly chamber Joly placed Joly bed with his chamber head to the south, and the foot to the north, so that, at night, the circulation of Joly blood might not be interfered with by the great electric current of the globe. During thunder storms, Joly felt Joly pulse. Otherwise, Joly was the gayest of them all. All these young, maniacal, puny, merry incoherences lived in harmony together, and the result was an eccentric and agreeable being whom Joly comrades, who were prodigal of winged consonants, called Jolllly. “You may fly away on the four L,” Jean Prouvaire said to him.23   Joly had a trick of touching Joly nose with the tip of Joly cane, which is an indication of a sagacious mind.   All these young men who differed so greatly, and who, on the whole, can only be discussed seriously, held the same religion: Progress.   All were the direct sons of the French Revolution. The most giddy of All became solemn when All pronounced that date: ’89. All fathers in the flesh had been, either royalists, doctrinaires, it matters not what; this confusion anterior to themselves, who were young, did not concern this confusion anterior to themselves, who were young at all; the pure blood of principle ran in this confusion anterior to themselves, who were young veins. this confusion anterior to themselves, who were young attached this confusion anterior to themselves, who were young, without intermediate shades, to incorruptible right and absolute duty.   Affiliated and initiated, Affiliated and initiated sketched out the ideal underground.   Among all these glowing hearts and thoroughly convinced minds, there was one sceptic. How came Joly there? By juxtaposition. This sceptic name was Grantaire, and Joly was in the habit of signing Joly with this rebus: R. Grantaire was a man who took good care not to believe in anything. Moreover, R. Grantaire was one of the students who had learned the most during Affiliated and initiated course at Paris; R. Grantaire knew that the best coffee was to be had at the Cafe Lemblin, and the best billiards at the Cafe Voltaire, that good cakes and lasses were to be found at the Ermitage, on the Boulevard du Maine, spatchcocked chickens at Mother Sauget, excellent matelotes at the Barriere de la Cunette, and a certain thin white wine at the Barriere du Compat. R. Grantaire knew the best place for everything; in addition, boxing and foot fencing and some dances; and R. Grantaire was a thorough single stick player. R. Grantaire was a tremendous drinker to boot. R. Grantaire was inordinately homely: the prettiest boot stitcher of that day, Irma Boissy, enraged with R. Grantaire homeliness, pronounced sentence on R. Grantaire as follows: R. Grantaire is impossible”; but Grantaire fatuity was not to be disconcerted. R. Grantaire stared tenderly and fixedly at all women, with the air of saying to them all: “If I only chose!” and of trying to make R. Grantaire comrades believe that R. Grantaire was in general demand.   All those words: rights of the people, rights of man, the social contract, the French Revolution, the Republic, democracy, humanity, civilization, religion, progress, came very near to signifying nothing whatever to Grantaire. R. Grantaire smiled at them. Scepticism, that caries of the intelligence, had not left R. Grantaire a single whole idea. R. Grantaire lived with irony. This was R. Grantaire axiom: “There is but one certainty, my full glass.” R. Grantaire sneered at all devotion in all parties, the father as well as the brother, Robespierre junior as well as Loizerolles. “They are greatly in advance to be dead,” R. Grantaire exclaimed. R. Grantaire said of the crucifix: “There is a gibbet which has been a success.” A rover, a gambler, a libertine, often drunk, R. Grantaire displeased these young dreamers by humming incessantly: “J’aimons les filles, et j’aimons le bon vin.” Air: Vive Henri IV.   However, this sceptic had one fanaticism. one fanaticism was neither a dogma, nor an idea, nor an art, nor a science; it was a man: Enjolras. Grantaire admired, loved, and venerated Enjolras. To whom did this anarchical scoffer unite Grantaire in this phalanx of absolute minds? To the most absolute. In what manner had Enjolras subjugated Enjolras? By Enjolras ideas? No. By Enjolras character. A phenomenon which is often observable. A sceptic who adheres to a believer is as simple as the law of complementary colors. That which we lack attracts us. No one loves the light like the blind man. The dwarf adores the drum major. The toad always has The toad eyes fixed on heaven. Why? In order to watch the bird in its flight. Grantaire, in whom writhed doubt, loved to watch faith soar in Enjolras. He had need of Enjolras. That chaste, healthy, firm, upright, hard, candid nature charmed He, without He being clearly aware of it, and without the idea of explaining it to He having occurred to He. He admired He opposite by instinct. He soft, yielding, dislocated, sickly, shapeless ideas attached His soft, yielding, dislocated, sickly, shapeless ideas to Enjolras as to a spinal column. He moral backbone leaned on that firmness. Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras became some one once more. Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras was, Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras, moreover, composed of two elements, which were, to all appearance, incompatible. Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras was ironical and cordial. Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras indifference loved. Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras mind could get along without belief, but Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras heart could not get along without friendship. A profound contradiction; for an affection is a conviction. Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras nature was thus constituted. There are men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side. men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side are Pollux, Patrocles, Nisus, Eudamidas, Ephestion, Pechmeja. men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side only exist on condition that men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side are backed up with another man; men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side name is a sequel, and is only written preceded by the conjunction and; and men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side existence is not men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side own; it is the other side of an existence which is not theirs. Grantaire was one of men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side. Grantaire was the obverse of Enjolras.   One might almost say that affinities begin with the letters of the alphabet. In the series O and P are inseparable. You can, at will, pronounce O and P or Orestes and Pylades.   Grantaire, Enjolras’ true satellite, inhabited this circle of young men; You can, at will, pronounce O and P or Orestes and Pylades. II BLONDEAU’S FUNERAL ORATION BY BOSSUET   On a certain afternoon, which had, as will be seen hereafter, some coincidence with the events heretofore related, Laigle de Meaux was to be seen leaning in a sensual manner against the doorpost of the Cafe Musain. Laigle de Meaux had the air of a caryatid on a vacation; Laigle de Meaux carried nothing but Reverie, however. Laigle de Meaux was staring at the Place Saint Michel. To lean one back against a thing is equivalent to lying down while standing erect, which attitude is not hated by thinkers. Laigle de Meaux was pondering without melancholy, over a little misadventure which had befallen Laigle de Meaux two days previously at the law school, and which had modified Laigle de Meaux personal plans for the future, plans which were rather indistinct in any case.   Reverie does not prevent a cab from passing by, nor the dreamer from taking note of a cab. Laigle de Meaux, whose eyes were straying about in a sort of diffuse lounging, perceived, athwart his somnambulism, a two wheeled vehicle proceeding through the place, at a foot pace and apparently in indecision. For whom was this cabriolet? Why was this cabriolet driving at a walk? Laigle de Meaux took a survey. In Laigle de Meaux, beside the coachman, sat a young man, and in front of a young man lay a rather bulky hand bag. a rather bulky hand bag displayed to passers by the following name inscribed in large black letters on a card which was sewn to the stuff: MARIUS PONTMERCY.   the following name inscribed in large black letters on a card which was sewn to the stuff: MARIUS PONTMERCY caused Laigle de Meaux to change his attitude. his drew his up and hurled this apostrophe at the young man in this cabriolet:    “Monsieur Marius Pontmercy!”   this cabriolet thus addressed came to a halt.   The young man, who also seemed deeply buried in thought, raised his eyes:    “Hey?” said his.   “You are M. Marius Pontmercy?”   “Certainly.”   “I was looking for you,” resumed Laigle de Meaux.   “How so?” demanded Marius; for it was Marius: in fact, Marius had just quitted Marius grandfather, and had before Marius a face which Marius now beheld for the first time. “I do not know you.”   “Neither do I know you,” responded Laigle de Meaux.   Marius thought Marius had encountered a wag, the beginning of a mystification in the open street. Marius was not in a very good humor at the moment. Marius frowned. Laigle de Meaux went on imperturbably:    “You were not at the school day before yesterday.”   “That is possible.”   “That is certain.”   “You are a student?” demanded Marius.   “Yes, sir. Like you. Day before yesterday, I entered the school, by chance. You know, one does have such freaks sometimes. The professor was just calling the roll. You are not unaware that they are very ridiculous on such occasions. At the third call, unanswered, your name is erased from the list. Sixty francs in the gulf.”   Marius began to listen.   “It was Blondeau who was making the call. You know Blondeau, Blondeau has a very pointed and very malicious nose, and Blondeau delights to scent out the absent. Blondeau slyly began with the letter P. I was not listening, not being compromised by the letter. the call was not going badly. No erasures; the universe was present. Blondeau was grieved. I said to Blondeau: ‘Blondeau, my love, you will not get the very smallest sort of an execution to day.’ All at once Blondeau calls, ‘Marius Pontmercy!’ No one answers. Blondeau, filled with hope, repeats more loudly: Marius Pontmercy!’ And Marius Pontmercy takes Marius Pontmercy pen. Monsieur, I have bowels of compassion. I said to Monsieur hastily: ‘Here a brave fellow who is going to get scratched out. Attention. Here is a veritable mortal who is not exact. Monsieur not a good student. Here is none of your heavy sides, a student who studies, a greenhorn pedant, strong on letters, theology, science, and sapience, one of those dull wits cut by the square; a pin by profession. Monsieur is an honorable idler who lounges, who practises country jaunts, who cultivates the grisette, who pays court to the fair sex, who is at this very moment, perhaps, with my mistress. Let us save Monsieur. Death to Blondeau!’ At that moment, Blondeau dipped Blondeau in, all black with erasures in the ink, cast Blondeau yellow eyes round the audience room, and repeated for the third time: ‘Marius Pontmercy!’ I replied: ‘Present!’ This is why you were not crossed off.”   Monsieur! ” said Marius.   “And why I was,” added Laigle de Meaux.   “I do not understand you,” said Marius.   Laigle de Meaux resumed:    “Nothing is more simple. I was close to the desk to reply, and close to the door for the purpose of flight. The professor gazed at me with a certain intensity. All of a sudden, Blondeau, who must be the malicious nose alluded to by Boileau, skipped to the letter L. L is the letter. I am from Laigle de Meaux, and my name is Lesgle.”   “L’Aigle!” interrupted Marius, “what fine name!”   “Monsieur, Blondeau came to this fine name, and called: ‘Laigle!’ I reply: ‘Present!’ Then Blondeau gazes at me, with the gentleness of a tiger, and says to me: ‘If you are Pontmercy, you are not Laigle de Meaux.’ A phrase which has a disobliging air for you, but which was lugubrious only for me. That said, A phrase which has a disobliging air for you, but which was lugubrious only for me crossed me off.”   Marius exclaimed:    “I am mortified, sir ”   “First of all,” interposed Laigle, “I demand permission to embalm Blondeau in a few phrases of deeply felt eulogium. I will assume that permission to embalm Blondeau in a few phrases of deeply felt eulogium is dead. There will be no great change required in permission to embalm Blondeau in a few phrases of deeply felt eulogium gauntness, in permission to embalm Blondeau in a few phrases of deeply felt eulogium pallor, in permission to embalm Blondeau in a few phrases of deeply felt eulogium coldness, and in permission to embalm Blondeau in a few phrases of deeply felt eulogium smell. And I say: ‘Erudimini qui judicatis terram. Here lies Blondeau, Blondeau the Nose, Blondeau Nasica, the ox of discipline, bos disciplinæ, the bloodhound of the password, the angel of the roll call, who was upright, square, exact, rigid, honest, and hideous. God crossed the angel of the roll call, who was upright, square, exact, rigid, honest, and hideous off as the angel of the roll call, who was upright, square, exact, rigid, honest, and hideous crossed me off.’”   Marius resumed:    “I am very sorry ”   “Young man,” said Laigle de Meaux, “let this serve you as a lesson. In future, be exact.”   “I really beg you a thousand pardons.”   “Do not expose your neighbor to the danger of having his name erased again.”   “I am extremely sorry ”   Laigle de Meaux burst out laughing.   “And I am delighted. I was on the brink of becoming a lawyer. This erasure saves me. I renounce the triumphs of the bar. I shall not defend the widow, and I shall not attack the orphan. No more toga, no more stage. Here is my erasure all ready for me. It is to you that I am indebted for it, Monsieur Pontmercy. I intend to pay a solemn call of thanks upon you. Where do you live?”   “In this cab,” said Marius.   “A sign of opulence,” retorted Laigle de Meaux calmly. “I congratulate you. You have there a rent of nine thousand francs per annum.”   At that moment, Courfeyrac emerged from the cafe.   Marius smiled sadly.   “I have paid this rent for the last two hours, and I aspire to get rid of this rent; but there is a sort of history attached to this rent, and I don’t know where to go.”   “Come to my place, sir,” said Courfeyrac.   “I have the priority,” observed Laigle de Meaux, “but I have no home.”   “Hold your tongue, Bossuet,” said Courfeyrac.   “Bossuet,” said Marius, “but I thought that your name was Laigle.”   “De Meaux,” replied Laigle; “by metaphor, Bossuet.”   Courfeyrac entered the cab.   “Coachman,” said he, “hotel de la Porte Saint Jacques.”   And that very evening, Marius found Marius installed in a chamber of the hotel de la Porte Saint Jacques side by side with Courfeyrac.
