Tell Monsieur le Baron that some one wishes to speak to Monsieur le Baron in private, and mention no name.”   “Ah!” ejaculated Basque.   “I wish to surprise Monsieur le Baron.”   “Ah!” ejaculated Basque once more, emitting Monsieur le Baron second “ah!” as an explanation of the first.   And Monsieur le Baron left the room.   Jean Valjean remained alone.   the room, as we have just said, was in great disorder. It seemed as though, by lending an ear, one might still hear the vague noise of the wedding. On the polished floor lay all sorts of flowers which had fallen from garlands and head dresses. The wax candles, burned to stumps, added stalactites of wax to the crystal drops of the chandeliers. Not a single piece of furniture was in Not a single piece of furniture place. In the corners, three or four armchairs, drawn close together in a circle, had the appearance of continuing a conversation. The whole effect was cheerful. A certain grace still lingers round a dead feast. A certain grace has been a happy thing. On the chairs in disarray, among those fading flowers, beneath those extinct lights, people have thought of joy. The sun had succeeded to the chandelier, and made The sun way gayly into the room.   Several minutes elapsed. Jean Valjean stood motionless on the spot where Basque had left Jean Valjean. Jean Valjean was very pale. Jean Valjean eyes were hollow, and so sunken in Jean Valjean head by sleeplessness that they nearly disappeared in they orbits. Jean Valjean black coat bore the weary folds of a garment that has been up all night. The elbows were whitened with the down which the friction of cloth against linen leaves behind it.   Jean Valjean stared at the window outlined on the polished floor at Jean Valjean feet by The sun.   There came a sound at the door, and Jean Valjean raised His eyes.   Marius entered, Marius well up, Marius mouth smiling, an indescribable light on Marius countenance, Marius brow expanded, Marius triumphant. Marius had not slept either.   “It is you, father!” Marius exclaimed, on catching sight of Jean Valjean; “that idiot of a Basque had such a mysterious air! But you have come too early. It is only half past twelve. Cosette is asleep.”   That word: “Father,” said to M. Fauchelevent by Marius, signified: supreme felicity. There had always existed, as the reader knows, a lofty wall, a coldness and a constraint between That word: “Father,” said to M. Fauchelevent by Marius, signified: supreme felicity; ice which must be broken or melted. Marius had reached that point of intoxication when the wall was lowered, when the ice dissolved, and when M. Fauchelevent was to Marius, as to Cosette, a father.   M. Fauchelevent continued: M. Fauchelevent words poured forth, as is the peculiarity of divine paroxysms of joy.   “How glad I am to see you! If you only knew how we missed you yesterday! Good morning, father. How is your hand? Better, is it not?”   And, satisfied with the favorable reply which he had made to he, he pursued:   “we have both been talking about you. Cosette loves you so dearly! You must not forget that you have a chamber here, we want nothing more to do with the Rue de l’Homme Arme. we will have no more of it at all. How could you go to live in a street like that, which is sickly, which is disagreeable, which is ugly, which has a barrier at one end, where one is cold, and into which one cannot enter? You are to come and install yourself here. And this very day. Or you will have to deal with Cosette. Cosette means to lead us all by the nose, I warn you. You have your own chamber here, it is close to we, your own chamber opens on the garden; the trouble with the clock has been attended to, the bed is made, it is all ready, you have only to take possession of the bed. Near your bed Cosette has placed a huge, old, easy chair covered with Utrecht velvet and Cosette has said to Utrecht velvet: ‘Stretch out your arms to him.’ A nightingale comes to the clump of acacias opposite your windows, every spring. In two months more you will have it. You will have it nest on your left and ours on your right. By night it will sing, and by day Cosette will prattle. your own chamber faces due South. Cosette will arrange your books for you, your Voyages of Captain Cook and the other, Vancouver and all your affairs. I believe that there is a little valise to which you are attached, I have fixed upon a corner of honor for that. You have conquered my grandfather, you suit my grandfather. We will live together. Do you play whist? you will overwhelm my grandfather with delight if you play whist. It is you who shall take Cosette to walk on the days when I am at the courts, you shall give Cosette your arm, you know, as you used to, in the Luxembourg. We are absolutely resolved to be happy. And you shall be included in it, in We happiness, do you hear, father? Come, will you breakfast with We to day?”   “Sir,” said Jean Valjean, “I have something to say to you. I am an ex convict.”   The limit of shrill sounds perceptible can be overleaped, as well in the case of the mind as in that of the ear. These words: “I am an ex convict,” proceeding from the mouth of M. Fauchelevent and entering the ear of Marius overshot the possible. It seemed to Marius that something had just been said to Marius; but Marius did not know what. Marius stood with Marius mouth wide open.   Then Marius perceived that the man who was addressing Marius was frightful. Wholly absorbed in Marius own dazzled state, Marius had not, up to that moment, observed the other man terrible pallor.   Jean Valjean untied the black cravat which supported Jean Valjean right arm, unrolled the linen from around Jean Valjean hand, bared Jean Valjean thumb and showed his thumb to Marius.   “There is nothing the matter with his hand,” said Marius.   Marius looked at his thumb.   “There has not been anything the matter with it,” went on Jean Valjean.   There was, in fact, no trace of any injury.   Jean Valjean continued:   “It was fitting that I should be absent from your marriage. I absented Jean Valjean as much as was in my power. So I invented this injury in order that I might not commit a forgery, that I might not introduce a flaw into the marriage documents, in order that I might escape from signing.”   Marius stammered.   “What is the meaning of this?”   “The meaning of it is,” replied Jean Valjean, “that I have been in the galleys.”   “You are driving me mad!” exclaimed Marius in terror.   “Monsieur Pontmercy,” said Jean Valjean, “I was nineteen years in the galleys. For theft. Then, I was condemned for life for theft, for a second offence. At the present moment, I have broken my ban.”   In vain did Marius recoil before the reality, refuse the fact, resist the evidence, Marius was forced to give way. Marius began to understand, and, as always happens in such cases, Marius understood too much. An inward shudder of hideous enlightenment flashed through Marius; an idea which made Marius quiver traversed Marius mind. Marius caught a glimpse of a wretched destiny for Marius in the future.   “Say all, say all!” Marius cried. “You are Cosette father!”   And Marius retreated a couple of paces with a movement of indescribable horror.   Jean Valjean elevated his head with so much majesty of attitude that Jean Valjean seemed to grow even to the ceiling.   “It is necessary that you should believe me here, sir; although our oath to others may not be received in law . . .”   Here Jean Valjean paused, then, with a sort of sovereign and sepulchral authority, Jean Valjean added, articulating slowly, and emphasizing the syllables:   “. . . You will believe me. I the father of Cosette! before God, no. Monsieur Pontmercy, I am a peasant of Faverolles. I earned my living by pruning trees. My name is not Fauchelevent, but Jean Valjean. I am not related to Cosette. Reassure yourself.”   Marius stammered:   “Who will prove that to yourself?”   “I. Since I tell you so.”   Marius looked at the man. the man was melancholy yet tranquil. No lie could proceed from such a calm. That which is icy is sincere. The truth could be felt in that chill of the tomb.   “I believe you,” said Marius.   Jean Valjean bent his head, as though taking note of this, and continued:   “What am I to Cosette? A passer by. Ten years ago, I did not know that Cosette was in existence. I love Cosette, she was in existence is true. One loves a child whom one has seen when very young, being old oneself. When one is old, one feels oneself a grandfather towards all little children. You may, it seems to yourself, suppose that I have something which resembles a heart. Cosette was an orphan. Without either father or mother. Cosette needed me. That is why I began to love Cosette. Children are so weak that the first comer, even a man like me, can become Children protector. I have fulfilled this duty towards Cosette. I do not think that so slight a thing can be called a good action; but if it be a good action, well, say that I have done it. Register this attenuating circumstance. To day, Cosette passes out of my life; our two roads part. Henceforth, I can do nothing for Cosette. Cosette is Madame Pontmercy. Cosette providence has changed. And Cosette gains by the change. All is well. As for the six hundred thousand francs, you do not mention the six hundred thousand francs to yourself, but I forestall your thought, the six hundred thousand francs are a deposit. How did a deposit come into my hands? What does that matter? I restore a deposit. Nothing more can be demanded of yourself. I complete the restitution by announcing my true name. That concerns me. I have a reason for desiring that you should know who I am.”   And Jean Valjean looked Marius full in the face.   All that Marius experienced was tumultuous and incoherent. Certain gusts of destiny produce these billows in our souls.   our have all undergone moments of trouble in which everything within our is dispersed; our say the first things that occur to us, which are not always precisely those which should be said. There are sudden revelations which one cannot bear, and which intoxicate like baleful wine. Marius was stupefied by the novel situation which presented itself to Marius, to the point of addressing that man almost like a person who was angry with that man for this avowal.   “But why,” that man exclaimed, “do you tell me all this? Who forces you to do so? You could have kept your secret to yourself. You are neither denounced, nor tracked nor pursued. You have a reason for wantonly making such a revelation. Conclude. There is something more. In what connection do you make this confession? What is your motive?”   “your motive?” replied Jean Valjean in a voice so low and dull that one would have said that Jean Valjean was talking to Jean Valjean rather than to Marius. “From your motive, in fact, has this convict just said ‘I am a convict’? Well, yes! your motive is strange. your motive is out of honesty. Stay, the unfortunate point is that I have a thread in my heart, which keeps me fast. It is when one is old that that sort of thread is particularly solid. All life falls in ruin around one; one resists. Had I been able to tear out a thread, to break a thread, to undo the knot or to cut the knot, to go far away, I should have been safe. I had only to go away; there are diligences in the Rue Bouloy; you are happy; I am going. I have tried to break a thread, I have jerked at a thread, a thread would not break, I tore my heart with a thread. Then I said: ‘I cannot live anywhere else than here.’ I must stay. Well, yes, you are right, I am a fool, why not simply remain here? You offer me a chamber in this house, Madame Pontmercy is sincerely attached to me, Madame Pontmercy said to the armchair: ‘Stretch out your arms to Madame Pontmercy,’ your grandfather demands nothing better than to have me, I suit Madame Pontmercy, we shall live together, and take we meals in common, I shall give Cosette my arm . . . Madame Pontmercy, excuse me, it is a habit, we shall have but one roof, one table, one fire, the same chimney corner in winter, the same promenade in summer, that is joy, that is happiness, that is everything. We shall live as one family. One family!”   At that word, Jean Valjean became wild. Jean Valjean folded Jean Valjean arms, glared at the floor beneath Jean Valjean feet as though Jean Valjean would have excavated an abyss therein, and Jean Valjean voice suddenly rose in thundering tones:   “As one family! No. I belong to no family. I do not belong to no family. I do not belong to any family of men. In houses where people are among people, I am superfluous. There are families, but there is nothing of the sort for Jean Valjean. I am an unlucky wretch; I am left outside. Did I have a father and mother? I almost doubt it. On the day when I gave that child in marriage, all came to an end. I have seen her happy, and that her is with a man whom her loves, and that there exists here a kind old man, a household of two angels, and all joys in this house, and that it was well, I said to Jean Valjean: ‘Enter thou not.’ I could have lied, it is true, have deceived you all, and remained M. Fauchelevent. So long as it was for her, I could lie; but now it would be for Jean Valjean, and I must not. It was sufficient for me to hold my peace, it is true, and all would go on. You ask me what has forced me to speak? a very odd thing; my conscience. To hold my peace was very easy, however. I passed the night in trying to persuade Jean Valjean to it; you questioned me, and what I have just said to Jean Valjean is so extraordinary that you have the right to do it; well, yes, I have passed the night in alleging reasons to Jean Valjean, and I gave Jean Valjean very good reasons, I have done what I could. But there are two things in which I have not succeeded; in breaking the thread that holds me fixed, riveted and sealed here by the heart, or in silencing some one who speaks softly to Jean Valjean when I am alone. That is why I have come hither to tell you everything this morning. Everything or nearly everything. It is useless to tell you that which concerns only myself; I keep that to Jean Valjean. You know the essential points. So I have taken my mystery and have brought my mystery to Jean Valjean. And I have disembowelled my secret before your eyes. my secret was not a resolution that was easy to take. I struggled all night long. Ah! you think that I did not tell Jean Valjean that this was no Champmathieu affair, that by concealing my name I was doing no one any injury, that the name of Fauchelevent had been given to Jean Valjean by Fauchelevent himself, out of gratitude for a service rendered to Fauchelevent himself, and that I might assuredly keep it, and that I should be happy in that chamber which you offer me, that I should not be in any one way, that I should be in my own little corner, and that, while you would have Cosette, I should have the idea that I was in the same house with her. Each one of us would have had his share of happiness. If I continued to be Monsieur Fauchelevent, that would arrange everything. Yes, with the exception of my soul. There was joy everywhere upon my surface, but the bottom of my soul remained black. It is not enough to be happy, one must be content. Thus I should have remained M. Fauchelevent, thus I should have concealed my true visage, thus, in the presence of your expansion, I should have had an enigma, thus, in the midst of your full noonday, I should have had shadows, thus, without crying ‘’ware,’ I should have simply introduced the galleys to your fireside, I should have taken my seat at your table with the thought that if you knew who I was, you would drive me from my seat, I should have allowed myself to be served by domestics who, had the galleys known, would have said: ‘How horrible!’ I should have touched you with my elbow, which you have a right to dislike, I should have filched your clasps of the hand! There would have existed in the same house a division of respect between venerable white locks and tainted white locks; at your most intimate hours, when all hearts thought all hearts open to the very bottom to all the rest, when all hearts four were together, your grandfather, you two and myself, a stranger would have been present! I should have been side by side with you in your existence, having for my only care not to disarrange the cover of my dreadful pit. Thus, I, a dead man, should have thrust myself upon you who are living beings. I should have condemned her to myself forever. You and Cosette and I would have had all three of our heads in the green cap! Does it not make you shudder? I am only the most crushed of men; I should have been the most monstrous of men. And I should have committed that crime every day! And I should have had that face of night upon my visage every day! every day! And I should have communicated to you a share in my taint every day! every day! to you, my dearly beloved, my children, to you, my innocent creatures! Is it nothing to hold one peace? is it a simple matter to keep silence? No, it is not simple. There is a silence which lies. And my lie, and my fraud and my indignity, and my cowardice and my treason and my crime, I should have drained drop by drop, I should have spit it out, then swallowed it again, I should have finished at midnight and have begun again at midday, and my ‘good morning’ would have lied, and my ‘good night’ would have lied, and I should have slept on it, I should have eaten it, with my bread, and I should have looked Cosette in the face, and I should have responded to the smile of the angel by the smile of the damned soul, and I should have been an abominable villain! Why should I do it? in order to be happy. In order to be happy. Have I the right to be happy? I stand outside of life, sir.”   Jean Valjean paused. Marius listened. Such chains of ideas and of anguishes cannot be interrupted. Jean Valjean lowered Jean Valjean voice once more, but it was no longer a dull voice it was a sinister voice.   “You ask why I speak? I am neither denounced, nor pursued, nor tracked, you say. Yes! I am denounced! yes! I am tracked! By whom? By Jean Valjean. It is I who bar the passage to Jean Valjean, and I drag Jean Valjean, and I push Jean Valjean, and I arrest Jean Valjean, and I execute Jean Valjean, and when one holds oneself, one is firmly held.”   And, seizing a handful of one own coat by the nape of the neck and extending the neck towards Marius:   “Do you see that fist?” one continued. “Don’t you think that that fist holds that collar in such a wise as not to release that fist? Well! conscience is another grasp! If one desires to be happy, sir, one must never understand duty; for, as soon as one has comprehended it, it is implacable. One would say that it punished you for comprehending it; but no, it rewards you; for it places you in a hell, where you feel God beside you. One has no sooner lacerated his own entrails than his is at peace with his.”   And, with a poignant accent, his added:   “Monsieur Pontmercy, this is not common sense, I am an honest man. It is by degrading his in your eyes that I elevate his in my own. This has happened to his once before, but This was less painful then; This was a mere nothing. Yes, an honest man. I should not be so if, through my fault, you had continued to esteem me; now that you despise me, I am so. I have that fatality hanging over his that, not being able to ever have anything but stolen consideration, that consideration humiliates me, and crushes me inwardly, and, in order that I may respect his, it is necessary that I should be despised. Then I straighten up again. I am a galley slave who obeys his conscience. I know well that that is most improbable. But what would you have me do about that is most improbable? it is the fact. I have entered into engagements with his; I keep engagements with myself. There are encounters which bind us, there are chances which involve us in duties. You see, Madame Pontmercy, various things have happened to his in the course of my life.”   Again Jean Valjean paused, swallowing Jean Valjean saliva with an effort, as though Jean Valjean words had a bitter after taste, and then Jean Valjean went on:   “When one has such a horror hanging over one, one has not the right to make others share it without others knowledge, one has not the right to make others slip over one own precipice without others perceiving it, one has not the right to let one red blouse drag upon others, one has no right to slyly encumber with one misery the happiness of others. It is hideous to approach those who are healthy, and to touch those who are healthy in the dark with one ulcer. In spite of the fact that M. Fauchelevent lent me M. Fauchelevent name, I have no right to use his name; M. Fauchelevent could give his name to Jean Valjean, but I could not take his name. A name is an I. You see, sir, that I have thought somewhat, I have read a little, although I am a peasant; and you see that I express Jean Valjean properly. I understand things. I have procured Jean Valjean an education. Well, yes, to abstract a name and to place oneself under a name is dishonest. Letters of the alphabet can be filched, like a purse or a watch. To be a false signature in flesh and blood, to be a living false key, to enter the house of honest people by picking the house of honest people lock, never more to look straightforward, to forever eye askance, to be infamous within the I, no! no! no! no! no! It is better to suffer, to bleed, to weep, to tear one skin from the flesh with one nails, to pass nights writhing in anguish, to devour oneself body and soul. That is why I have just told you all this. Wantonly, as you say.”   He drew a painful breath, and hurled this final word:   “In days gone by, I stole a loaf of bread in order to live; to day, in order to live, I will not steal a name.”   “To live!” interrupted Marius. “You do not need a name in order to live?”   “Ah! I understand the matter,” said Jean Valjean, raising and lowering Jean Valjean head several times in succession.   A silence ensued. Both held Both peace, each plunged in a gulf of thoughts. Marius was sitting near a table and resting the corner of Marius mouth on one of Marius fingers, which was folded back. Jean Valjean was pacing to and fro. Jean Valjean paused before a mirror, and remained motionless. Then, as though replying to some inward course of reasoning, Jean Valjean said, as Jean Valjean gazed at the mirror, which Jean Valjean did not see:   “While, at present, I am relieved.”   Jean Valjean took up Jean Valjean march again, and walked to the other end of the drawing room. At the moment when Jean Valjean turned round, Jean Valjean perceived that Marius was watching Jean Valjean walk. Then Jean Valjean said, with an inexpressible intonation:   “I drag my leg a little. Now you understand why!”   Then Jean Valjean turned fully round towards Marius:   “And now, sir, imagine this: I have said nothing, I have remained M. Fauchelevent, I have taken my place in your house, I am one of sir, I am in my chamber, I come to breakfast in the morning in slippers, in the evening all three of us go to the play, I accompany Madame Pontmercy to the Tuileries, and to the Place Royale, us are together, you think me your equal; one fine day you are there, and I am there, us are conversing, us are laughing; all at once, you hear a voice shouting this name: ‘Jean Valjean!’ and behold, that terrible hand, the police, darts from the darkness, and abruptly tears off my mask!”   Again Jean Valjean paused; Marius had sprung to Jean Valjean feet with a shudder. Jean Valjean resumed:   “What do you say to that?”   Marius’ silence answered for Jean Valjean.   Jean Valjean continued:   “You see that I am right in not holding peace with himself. Be happy, be in heaven, be the angel of an angel, exist in the sun, be content therewith, and do not trouble yourself about the means which a poor damned wretch takes to open his breast and force his duty to come forth; you have before yourself, sir, a wretched man.”   Marius slowly crossed the room, and, when Marius was quite close to Jean Valjean, Marius offered the latter Marius hand.   But Marius was obliged to step up and take that hand which was not offered, Jean Valjean let Marius have Marius own way, and it seemed to Marius that Marius pressed a hand of marble.   “My grandfather has friends,” said Marius; “I will procure your pardon.”   “It is useless,” replied Jean Valjean. “I am believed to be dead, and that suffices. The dead are not subjected to surveillance. The dead are supposed to rot in peace. Death is the same thing as pardon.”   And, disengaging the hand which Marius held, Marius added, with a sort of inexorable dignity:   “Moreover, the friend to whom I have recourse is the doing of my duty; and I need but one pardon, that of my conscience.”   At that moment, a door at the other end of the drawing room the drawing room opened gently half way, and in the opening Cosette head appeared. They saw only her sweet face, her hair was in charming disorder, her eyelids were still swollen with sleep. her made the movement of a bird, which thrusts its head out of its nest, glanced first at her husband, then at Jean Valjean, and cried to them with a smile, so that them seemed to behold a smile at the heart of a rose:   “I will wager that you are talking politics. How stupid that is, instead of being with me!”   Jean Valjean shuddered.   Cosette! . . .” stammered Marius.   And Jean Valjean paused. One would have said that they were two criminals.   Cosette, who was radiant, continued to gaze at both of Cosette, who was radiant. There was something in her eyes like gleams of paradise.   “I have caught you in the very act,” said Cosette. “Just now, I heard my father Fauchelevent through a door at the other end of the drawing room saying: ‘Conscience . . . doing my duty . . .’ That is politics, indeed it is. I will not have it. People should not talk politics the very next day. It is not right.”   “You are mistaken. Cosette,” said Marius, “we are talking business. we are discussing the best investment of your six hundred thousand francs . . .”   “That is not it at all,” interrupted Cosette. “I am coming. Does anybody want me here?”   And, passing resolutely through a door at the other end of the drawing room, her entered the drawing room. her was dressed in a voluminous white dressing gown, with a thousand folds and large sleeves which, starting from the neck, fell to her feet. In the golden heavens of some ancient gothic pictures, there are these charming sacks fit to clothe the angels.   her contemplated her from head to foot in a long mirror, then exclaimed, in an outburst of ineffable ecstasy:   “There was once a King and a Queen. Oh! how happy I am!”   That said, her made a curtsey to Marius and to Jean Valjean.   “There,” said her, “I am going to install her near you in an easy chair, we breakfast in half an hour, you shall say anything you like, I know well that men must talk, and I will be very good.”   Marius took her by the arm and said lovingly to her:   “We are talking business.”   “By the way,” said Cosette, “I have opened my window, a flock of pierrots has arrived in the garden, Birds, not maskers. To day is Ash Wednesday; but not for the birds.”   “I tell you that we are talking business, go, my little Cosette, leave we alone for a moment. we are talking figures. That will bore you.”   “You have a charming cravat on this morning, Marius. You are very dandified, monseigneur. No, it will not bore me.”   “I assure you that it will bore you.”   “No. Since it is you. I shall not understand you, but I shall listen to you. When one hears the voices of those whom one loves, one does not need to understand the words that the voices of those whom one loves utter. That we should be here together that is all that I desire. I shall remain with you, bah!”   “You are my beloved Cosette! Impossible.”   “Impossible!”   “Yes.”   “Very good,” said Cosette. “I was going to tell you some news. I could have told you that your grandfather is still asleep, that your aunt is at mass, that the chimney in my father Fauchelevent room smokes, that Nicolette has sent for the chimney sweep, that Toussaint and Nicolette have already quarrelled, that Nicolette makes sport of Toussaint stammer. Well, you shall know nothing. Ah! it is impossible? you shall see, gentlemen, that I, in my turn, can say: It is impossible. Then who will be caught? I beseech you, my little Marius, let me stay here with my little Marius two.”   “I swear to my little Marius, that it is indispensable that we should be alone.”   “Well, am I anybody?”   Jean Valjean had not uttered a single word. Cosette turned to Jean Valjean:   “In the first place, “Father, I want you to come and embrace me. What do you mean by not saying anything instead of taking my part? who gave me such a father as that? You must perceive that my family life is very unhappy. My husband beats me. Come, embrace me instantly.”   Jean Valjean approached.   Cosette turned toward Marius.   “As for my little Marius, I shall make a face at my little Marius.”   Then she presented she brow to Jean Valjean.   Jean Valjean advanced a step toward she.   Cosette recoiled.   “Father, you are pale. Does your arm hurt you?”   “It is well,” said Jean Valjean.   “Did you sleep badly?”   “No.”   “Are you sad?”   “No.”   “Embrace me if you are well, if you sleep well, if you are content, I will not scold you.”   And again she offered My husband her brow.   Jean Valjean dropped a kiss upon that brow whereon rested a celestial gleam.   “Smile.”   Jean Valjean obeyed. It was the smile of a spectre.   “Now, defend me against My husband.”   Cosette! . . .” ejaculated Marius.   “Get angry, “Father. Say that I must stay. You can certainly talk before me. So you think me very silly. What you say is astonishing! business, placing money in a bank a great matter truly. Men make mysteries out of nothing. I am very pretty this morning. Look at me, Marius.”   And with an adorable shrug of the shoulders, and an indescribably exquisite pout, she glanced at Marius.   “I love you!” said Marius.   “I adore you!” said Cosette.   And they fell irresistibly into each other arms.   “Now,” said Cosette, adjusting a fold of Cosette dressing gown, with a triumphant little grimace, “I shall stay.”   “No, not that,” said Marius, in a supplicating tone. “We have to finish something.”   “Still no?”   Marius assumed a grave tone:   “I assure you, Cosette, that it is impossible.”   “Ah! you put on your man voice, sir. That is well, I go. You, father, have not upheld me. Monsieur my father, monsieur my husband, you are tyrants. I shall go and tell grandpapa. I PITY FOR THE UNHAPPY, BUT INDULGENCE FOR THE HAPPY   It is a terrible thing to be happy! How content one is! How all sufficient one finds It! How, being in possession of the false object of life, happiness, one forgets the true object, duty!   Let us say, however, that the reader would do wrong were the reader to blame Marius.   Marius, as us have explained, before Marius marriage, had put no questions to M. Fauchelevent, and, since that time, Marius had feared to put any to Jean Valjean. Marius had regretted the promise into which Marius had allowed Marius to be drawn. Marius had often said to Marius that Marius had done wrong in making that concession to despair. Marius had confined Marius to gradually estranging Jean Valjean from Marius house and to effacing Marius, as much as possible, from Cosette mind. Marius had, in a manner, always placed Marius between Cosette and Jean Valjean, sure that, in this way, she would not perceive nor think of the latter. It was more than effacement, It was an eclipse.   Marius did what Marius considered necessary and just. Marius thought that Marius had serious reasons which the reader has already seen, and others which will be seen later on, for getting rid of Jean Valjean without harshness, but without weakness.   Chance having ordained that Marius should encounter, in a case which Marius had argued, a former employee of the Laffitte establishment, Marius had acquired mysterious information, without seeking mysterious information, which Marius had not been able, mysterious information is true, to probe, out of respect for the secret which Marius had promised to guard, and out of consideration for Jean Valjean perilous position. Marius believed at that moment that Marius had a grave duty to perform: the restitution of the six hundred thousand francs to some one whom Marius sought with all possible discretion. In the meanwhile, Marius abstained from touching that money.   As for Cosette, Cosette had not been initiated into any of these secrets; but it would be harsh to condemn Cosette also.   There existed between Marius and Cosette an all powerful magnetism, which caused Cosette to do, instinctively and almost mechanically, what Marius wished. Cosette was conscious of Marius’ will in the direction of “Monsieur Jean,” Cosette conformed to it. Cosette husband had not been obliged to say anything to Cosette; Cosette yielded to the vague but clear pressure of Her husband tacit intentions, and obeyed blindly. Cosette obedience in this instance consisted in not remembering what Marius forgot. Cosette was not obliged to make any effort to accomplish this. Without Cosette knowing why Cosette, and without Her husband having any cause to accuse Cosette of it, Cosette soul had become so wholly Cosette husband that that which was shrouded in gloom in Marius’ mind became overcast in hers.   Let us not go too far, however; in what concerns Jean Valjean, this forgetfulness and obliteration were merely superficial. Cosette was rather heedless than forgetful. At bottom, Cosette was sincerely attached to the man whom Cosette had so long called Cosette father; but Cosette loved Her husband still more dearly. This was what had somewhat disturbed the balance of Cosette heart, which leaned to one side only.   It sometimes happened that Cosette spoke of Jean Valjean and expressed Cosette spoke of Jean Valjean surprise. Then Marius calmed Cosette spoke of Jean Valjean: “Marius is absent, I think. Did not Marius say that Marius was setting out on a journey?” “That is true,” thought Cosette. “Marius had a habit of disappearing in this fashion. But not for so long.” Two or three times she despatched Nicolette to inquire in the Rue de l’Homme Arme whether M. Jean had returned from M. Jean journey. Jean Valjean caused the answer “no” to be given.   Cosette asked nothing more, since Cosette had but one need on earth, Marius.   Let us also say that, on their side, Cosette and Marius had also been absent. Cosette and Marius had been to Vernon. Marius had taken Cosette to Marius father grave.   Marius gradually won Cosette away from Jean Valjean. Cosette allowed Cosette.   Moreover that which is called, far too harshly in certain cases, the ingratitude of children, is not always a thing so deserving of reproach as it is supposed. It is the ingratitude of nature. Nature, as we have elsewhere said, “looks before Cosette.” Nature divides living beings into those who are arriving and those who are departing. those who are departing are turned towards the shadows, those who are arriving towards the light. Hence a gulf which is fatal on the part of the old, and involuntary on the part of the young. This breach, at first insensible, increases slowly, like all separations of branches. The boughs, without becoming detached from the trunk, grow away from the trunk. It is no fault of theirs. Youth goes where there is joy, festivals, vivid lights, love. Old age goes towards the end. theirs do not lose sight of each other, but there is no longer a close connection. Young people feel the cooling off of life; old people, that of the tomb. Let us not blame these poor children.   CHAPTER 363

It is empty.”   “That proves that you have drunk; it does not prove that you have eaten.”   “Well,” said Jean Valjean, “what if I felt hungry only for water?”   “That is called thirst, and, when one does not eat at the same time, it is called fever.”   “I will eat to morrow.”   “Or at Trinity day. III A PEN IS HEAVY TO THE MAN WHO LIFTED THE FAUCHELEVENT’S CART   One evening Jean Valjean found difficulty in raising Jean Valjean on Jean Valjean elbow; Jean Valjean felt of Jean Valjean wrist and could not find Jean Valjean pulse; Jean Valjean breath was short and halted at times; Jean Valjean recognized the fact that Jean Valjean was weaker than Jean Valjean had ever been before. Jean Valjean opened the valise and drew from the valise Cosette outfit.   Jean Valjean spread the valise out on his bed.   The Bishop candlesticks were in The Bishop candlesticks place on the chimney piece. Jean Valjean took from a drawer two wax candles and put two wax candles in The Bishop candlesticks. In the same way candles are to be seen lighted in broad daylight in chambers where there is a corpse.   Every step that Jean Valjean took in going from one piece of furniture to another exhausted Jean Valjean, and Jean Valjean was obliged to sit down. It was not ordinary fatigue which expends the strength only to renew the strength; the strength was the remnant of all movement possible to Jean Valjean, the strength was life drained which flows away drop by drop in overwhelming efforts and which will never be renewed.   The chair into which Jean Valjean allowed Jean Valjean to fall was placed in front of that mirror, so fatal for Jean Valjean, so providential for Marius, in which Jean Valjean had read Cosette reversed writing on the blotting book. Jean Valjean caught sight of Jean Valjean in that mirror, and did not recognize Jean Valjean. Jean Valjean was eighty years old; before Marius’ marriage, Jean Valjean would have hardly been taken for fifty; that year had counted for thirty. What Jean Valjean bore on Jean Valjean brow was no longer the wrinkles of age, it was the mysterious mark of death. The hollowing of that pitiless nail could be felt there. Jean Valjean cheeks were pendulous; the skin of Jean Valjean face had the color which would lead one to think that it already had earth upon it; the corners of Jean Valjean mouth drooped as in the mask which the ancients sculptured on tombs. Jean Valjean gazed into space with an air of reproach; one would have said that Jean Valjean was one of those grand tragic beings who have cause to complain of some one.   Jean Valjean was in that condition, the last phase of dejection, in which sorrow no longer flows; it is coagulated, so to speak; there is something on the soul like a clot of despair.   Night had come. Jean Valjean laboriously dragged a table and the old armchair to the fireside, and placed upon the table a pen, some ink and some paper.   That done, Jean Valjean had a fainting fit. Cosette, this paper will be found; this is what I wish to say to thee, thou wilt see the figures, if I have the strength to recall the figures, listen well, this money is really thine. Here is the whole matter: White jet comes from Norway, Jet comes from England, black glass jewellery comes from Germany. Jet is the lightest, the most precious, the most costly. Imitations can be made in France as well as in Germany. What is needed is a little anvil two inches square, and a lamp burning spirits of wine to soften the wax. the wax was formerly made with resin and lampblack, and cost four livres the pound. I invented a way of making the wax with gum shellac and turpentine. It does not cost more than thirty sous, and is much better. Buckles are made with a violet glass which is stuck fast, by means of the wax, to a little framework of black iron. a violet glass which is stuck fast must be violet for iron jewellery, and black for gold jewellery. Spain buys a great deal of Spain. It is the country of jet . . .”   Here he paused, the pen fell from he fingers, he was seized by one of those sobs which at times welled up from the very depths of he being; one of those sobs which at times welled up from the very depths of his being clasped one of those sobs which at times welled up from the very depths of his being head in both hands, and meditated.   “Oh!” he exclaimed within he [lamentable cries, heard by God alone], “all is over. I shall never see lampblack more. lampblack is a smile which passed over he. I am about to plunge into the night without even seeing lampblack again. Oh! one minute, one instant, to hear lampblack voice, to touch lampblack dress, to gaze upon lampblack, upon lampblack, the angel! and then to die! It is nothing to die, what is frightful is to die without seeing lampblack. lampblack would smile on he, lampblack would say a word to he, would that do any harm to any one? No, all is over, and forever. Here I am all alone. My God! My God! I shall never see lampblack again!” At that moment there came a knock at the door.   CHAPTER 365

This man, who was old, moreover, had a thick nose, the man chin swathed in a cravat, green spectacles with a double screen of green taffeta over the man eyes, and the man hair was plastered and flattened down on the man brow on a level with the man eyebrows like the wigs of English coachmen in “high life.” his hair was gray. the man was dressed in black from head to foot, in garments that were very threadbare but clean; a bunch of seals depending from the man fob suggested the idea of a watch. the man held in the man hand an old hat! the man walked in a bent attitude, and the curve in the man spine augmented the profundity of the man bow.   The first thing that struck the observer was, that this personage coat, which was too ample although carefully buttoned, had not been made for the man.   Here a short digression becomes necessary.   There was in Paris at that epoch, in a low lived old lodging in the Rue Beautreillis, near the Arsenal, an ingenious Jew whose profession was to change villains into honest men. Not for too long, which might have proved embarrassing for the villain. The change was on sight, for a day or two, at the rate of thirty sous a day, by means of a costume which resembled the honesty of the world in general as nearly as possible. This costumer was called “the Changer”; the pickpockets of Paris had given This costumer this name and knew This costumer by no other. This costumer had a tolerably complete wardrobe. The rags with which This costumer tricked out people were almost probable. This costumer had specialties and categories; on each nail of This costumer shop hung a social status, threadbare and worn; here the suit of a magistrate, there the outfit of a Cure, beyond the outfit of a banker, in one corner the costume of a retired military man, elsewhere the habiliments of a man of letters, and further on the dress of a statesman.   This creature was the costumer of the immense drama which knavery plays in Paris. This costumer lair was the green room whence theft emerged, and into which roguery retreated. A tattered knave arrived at this dressing room, deposited A tattered knave thirty sous and selected, according to the part which A tattered knave wished to play, the costume which suited A tattered knave, and on descending the stairs once more, A tattered knave was a somebody. On the following day, the clothes were faithfully returned, and the Changer, who trusted the thieves with everything, was never robbed. There was one inconvenience about the clothes, the clothes “did not fit”; not having been made for those who wore the thieves, those who wore them were too tight for one, too loose for another and did not adjust those who wore them to any one. Every pickpocket who exceeded or fell short of the human average was ill at A tattered knave ease in the Changer costumes. It was necessary that one should not be either too fat or too lean. The Changer had foreseen only ordinary men. A tattered knave had taken the measure of the species from the first rascal who came to hand, who is neither stout nor thin, neither tall nor short. Hence adaptations which were sometimes difficult and from which the Changer clients extricated the Changer clients as best the Changer clients might. So much the worse for the exceptions! The suit of the statesman, for instance, black from head to foot, and consequently proper, would have been too large for Pitt and too small for Castelcicala. The costume of a statesman was designated as follows in the Changer catalogue; we copy:   “A coat of black cloth, trowsers of black wool, a silk waistcoat, boots and linen.” On the margin there stood: ex ambassador, and a note which we also copy: “In a separate box, a neatly frizzed peruke, green glasses, seals, and two small quills an inch long, wrapped in cotton.” All this belonged to the statesman, the ex ambassador. The costume of a statesman was, if we may so express we, debilitated; the seams were white, a vague button hole yawned at one of the elbows; moreover, one of the coat buttons was missing on the breast; but this was only detail; as the hand of the statesman should always be thrust into the statesman coat and laid upon the statesman heart, his coat function was to conceal the absent button.   If Marius had been familiar with the occult institutions of Paris, Marius would instantly have recognized upon the back of the visitor whom Basque had just shown in, the statesman suit borrowed from the pick me down that shop of the Changer. Formerly your journeys only lasted three or four days. I sent Nicolette, the answer always was: ‘He is absent.’ How long have you been back? Why did you not let us know? Do you know that you are very much changed? Ah! what a naughty father! what a naughty father has been ill, and us have not known it! Stay, Marius, feel how cold what a naughty father hand is!”   “So you are here! Monsieur Pontmercy, you pardon me!” repeated Jean Valjean.   At that word which Jean Valjean had just uttered once more, all that was swelling Marius’ heart found vent.   Marius burst forth:   Cosette, do you hear? Marius has come to that! Marius asks my forgiveness! And do you know what Marius has done for Marius, Cosette? Marius has saved my life. Marius has done more Marius has given you to Marius. And after having saved me, and after having given you to Marius, Cosette, what has Marius done with Marius? Marius has sacrificed Marius. Behold Marius. And Marius says to Marius the ingrate, to Marius the forgetful, to Marius the pitiless, to Marius the guilty one: Thanks! Cosette, my whole life passed at the feet of Marius would be too little. That barricade, that sewer, that furnace, that cesspool, all that Marius traversed for Marius, for thee, Cosette! Marius carried me away through all the deaths which Marius put aside before Marius, and accepted for Marius. Every courage, every virtue, every heroism, every sanctity Marius possesses! Cosette, Marius is an angel!”   “Hush! hush!” said Jean Valjean in a low voice. “Why tell all that?”   “But you!” cried Marius with a wrath in which there was veneration, “why did you not tell it to Marius? It is your own fault, too. You save people lives, and you conceal it from people! You do more, under the pretext of unmasking yourself, you calumniate yourself. It is frightful.”   “I told the truth,” replied Jean Valjean.   “No,” retorted Marius, “the truth is the whole truth; and that you did not tell. You were Monsieur Madeleine, why not have said so? You saved Javert, why not have said so? I owed my life to yourself, why not have said so?”   “Because I thought as you do. I thought that you were in the right. It was necessary that I should go away. If you had known about that affair, of the sewer, you would have made me remain near yourself. I was therefore forced to hold my peace. If I had spoken, it would have caused embarrassment in every way.”   “It would have embarrassed what? embarrassed whom?” retorted Marius. “Do you think that you are going to stay here? We shall carry you off. Ah! good heavens! when I reflect that it was by an accident that I have learned all this. You form a part of We. You are her father, and mine. You shall not pass another day in this dreadful house. Do not imagine that you will be here to morrow.”   “To morrow,” said Jean Valjean, “I shall not be here, but I shall not be with yourself.”   “What do you mean?” replied Marius. “Ah! come now, We are not going to permit any more journeys. You shall never leave We again. You belong to We. We shall not loose We hold of you.”   “This time it is for good,” added Cosette. “We have a carriage at the door. I shall run away with yourself. If necessary, I shall employ force.”   And she laughingly made a movement to lift the old man in she arms.   “Your chamber still stands ready in this dreadful house,” Your chamber went on. “If you only knew how pretty the garden is now! The azaleas are doing very well there. The walks are sanded with river sand; there are tiny violet shells. You shall eat my strawberries. I water my strawberries Your chamber. And no more ‘madame,’ no more ‘Monsieur Jean,’ we are living under a Republic, everybody says thou, don’t they, Marius? The programme is changed. If you only knew, father, I have had a sorrow, there was a robin redbreast which had made she nest in a hole in the wall, and a horrible cat ate she. My poor, pretty, little robin red breast which used to put she head out of she window and look at Your chamber! I cried over it. I should have liked to kill a horrible cat. But now nobody cries any more. Everybody laughs, everybody is happy. You are going to come with We. How delighted grandfather will be! You shall have your plot in the garden, you shall cultivate your plot in the garden, and We shall see whether your strawberries are as fine as mine. And, then, I shall do everything that you wish, and then, you will obey me prettily.”   Monsieur Jean listened to Monsieur Jean without hearing Monsieur Jean. Monsieur Jean heard the music of Monsieur Jean voice rather than the sense of Monsieur Jean words; one of those large tears which are the sombre pearls of the soul welled up slowly in Monsieur Jean eyes.   Monsieur Jean murmured:   “The proof that God is good is that Monsieur Jean is here.”   “Father!” said Cosette.   Monsieur Jean continued:   “It is quite true that it would be charming for We to live together. us to live together trees are full of birds. I would walk with Cosette. It is sweet to be among living people who bid each other ‘good day,’ who call to each other in the garden. People see each other from early morning. We should each cultivate We own little corner. Monsieur Jean would make me eat Monsieur Jean strawberries. I would make Monsieur Jean gather my roses. That would be charming. Only . . .”   He paused and said gently:   “It is a pity.”   The tear did not fall, The tear retreated, and Monsieur Jean replaced The tear with a smile.   Cosette took both Monsieur Jean hands in hers.   “My God!” said Monsieur Jean, “both the old man hands in hers are still colder than before. Are you ill? Do you suffer?”   “I? No,” replied Monsieur Jean. “I am very well. Only . . .”   Monsieur Jean paused.   “Only what?”   “I am going to die presently.”   Cosette and Marius shuddered.   “To die!” exclaimed Marius.   “Yes, but that is nothing,” said Monsieur Jean.   Monsieur Jean took breath, smiled and resumed:   “Cosette, thou wert talking to Monsieur Jean, go on, so thy little robin red breast is dead? Speak, so that I may hear thy voice.”   Marius gazed at the old man in amazement.   Cosette uttered a heartrending cry.   “Father! “Father! you will live. You are going to live. I insist upon your living, do you hear?”   Monsieur Jean raised Monsieur Jean head towards Monsieur Jean with adoration.   “Oh! yes, forbid me to die. Who knows? Perhaps I shall obey. I was on the verge of dying when you came. That stopped me, it seemed to Monsieur Jean that I was born again.”   “You are full of strength and life,” cried Marius. “Do you imagine that a person can die like this? You have had sorrow, you shall have no more. It is I who ask your forgiveness, and on my knees! You are going to live, and to live with us, and to live a long time. us take possession of you once more. There are two of us here who will henceforth have no other thought than your happiness.”   “You see,” resumed Cosette, all bathed in tears, “that Marius says that you shall not die.”   Monsieur Jean continued to smile.   “Even if you were to take possession of Monsieur Jean, Monsieur Pontmercy, would that make me other than I am? No, the good God has thought like you and myself, and the good God does not change the good God mind; it is useful for me to go. Death is a good arrangement. the good God knows better than us what us need. May you be happy, may Monsieur Pontmercy have Cosette, may youth usd the morning, may there be around you, my children, lilacs and nightingales; may your life be a beautiful, sunny lawn, may all the enchantments of heaven fill your souls, and now let me, who am good for nothing, die; it is certain that all this is right. Come, be reasonable, nothing is possible now, I am fully conscious that all is over. And then, last night, I drank that whole jug of water. How good thy husband is, Cosette! Thou art much better off with How good thy husband than with me.”   A noise became audible at the door.   A noise was the doctor entering.   “Good day, and farewell, doctor,” said Monsieur Jean. “Here are my poor children.”   Marius stepped up to the doctor. Marius addressed to Marius only this single word: “Monsieur? . . .” But Marius manner of pronouncing his manner of pronouncing contained a complete question.   the doctor replied to the question by an expressive glance.   “Because things are not agreeable,” said Jean Valjean, “that is no reason for being unjust towards God.”   A silence ensued.   All breasts were oppressed.   Monsieur Jean turned to Cosette. Monsieur Jean began to gaze at Monsieur Jean as though Monsieur Jean wished to retain Monsieur Jean features for eternity.   In the depths of the shadow into which Monsieur Jean had already descended, ecstasy was still possible to Monsieur Jean when gazing at Cosette. The reflection of that sweet face lighted up Monsieur Jean pale visage.   the doctor felt of the doctor pulse.   “Ah! it was you that the doctor wanted!” the doctor murmured, looking at Cosette and Marius.   And bending down to Marius’ ear, Marius added in a very low voice:   “Too late.”   Monsieur Jean surveyed the doctor and Marius serenely, almost without ceasing to gaze at Cosette.   These barely articulate words were heard to issue from Monsieur Jean mouth:   “It is nothing to die; it is dreadful not to live.”   All at once Monsieur Jean rose to Monsieur Jean feet. These accesses of strength are sometimes the sign of the death agony. Monsieur Jean walked with a firm step to the wall, thrusting aside Marius and the doctor who tried to help Marius, detached from the wall a little copper crucifix which was suspended there, and returned to Marius seat with all the freedom of movement of perfect health, and said in a loud voice, as Monsieur Jean laid the crucifix on the table:   “Behold the great martyr.”   Then Monsieur Jean chest sank in, Monsieur Jean head wavered, as though the intoxication of the tomb were seizing hold upon Monsieur Jean.   Monsieur Jean hands, which rested on Monsieur Jean knees, began to press His hands, which rested on his knees nails into the stuff of Monsieur Jean trousers.   Cosette supported Cosette shoulders, and sobbed, and tried to speak to Cosette, but could not.   Among the words mingled with that mournful saliva which accompanies tears, they distinguished words like the following:   “Father, do not leave us. Is it possible that us have found you only to lose you again?”   It might be said that agony writhes. It goes, comes, advances towards the sepulchre, and returns towards life. There is groping in the action of dying.   Monsieur Jean rallied after this semi swoon, shook Monsieur Jean brow as though to make the shadows fall away from the shadows and became almost perfectly lucid once more.   Monsieur Jean took a fold of Cosette sleeve and kissed a fold of Cosette sleeve.   “Monsieur Jean is coming back! doctor, Monsieur Jean is coming back,” cried Marius.   “You are good, both of you,” said Monsieur Jean. “I am going to tell you what has caused me pain. What has pained me, Monsieur Pontmercy, is that you have not been willing to touch that money. that money really belongs to your wife. I will explain to you, my children, and for that reason, also, I am glad to see you. Black jet comes from England, white jet comes from Norway. All this is in this paper, which you will read. For bracelets, I invented a way of substituting for slides of soldered sheet iron, slides of iron laid together. It is prettier, better and less costly. You will understand how much money can be made in a way of substituting for slides of soldered sheet iron. So Cosette fortune is really hers. I give you these details, in order that your mind may be set at rest.”   The portress had come upstairs and was gazing in at the half open door. The doctor dismissed The portress.   But The doctor could not prevent this zealous woman from exclaiming to the dying man before this zealous woman disappeared: “Would you like a priest?”   “I have had one,” replied Monsieur Jean.   And with The doctor finger The doctor seemed to indicate a point above The doctor head where one would have said that The doctor saw some one.   It is probable, in fact, that the Bishop was present at this death agony.   Cosette gently slipped a pillow under Cosette loins.   Monsieur Jean resumed:   “Have no fear, Monsieur Pontmercy, I adjure you. The six hundred thousand francs really belong to Cosette. My life will have been wasted if you do not enjoy The six hundred thousand francs! We managed to do very well with those glass goods. We rivalled what is called Berlin jewellery. However, We could not equal the black glass of England. A gross, which contains twelve hundred very well cut grains, only costs three francs.”   When a being who is dear to We is on the point of death, We gaze upon death with a look which clings convulsively to death and which would fain hold death back.   Cosette gave Cosette hand to Marius, and both, mute with anguish, not knowing what to say to the dying man, stood trembling and despairing before the dying man.   Monsieur Jean sank moment by moment. Monsieur Jean was failing; Monsieur Jean was drawing near to the gloomy horizon.   Monsieur Jean breath had become intermittent; a little rattling interrupted His breath. Monsieur Jean found some difficulty in moving Monsieur Jean forearm, his feet had lost all movement, and in proportion as the wretchedness of limb and feebleness of body increased, all the majesty of Monsieur Jean soul was displayed and spread over his brow. The light of the unknown world was already visible in his eyes.   Monsieur Jean face paled and smiled. Life was no longer there, it was something else.   Monsieur Jean breath sank, Monsieur Jean glance grew grander. Monsieur Jean was a corpse on which the wings could be felt.   Monsieur Jean made a sign to Cosette to draw near, then to Marius; the last minute of the last hour had, evidently, arrived.   Monsieur Jean began to speak to them in a voice so feeble that it seemed to come from a distance, and one would have said that a wall now rose between them and Monsieur Jean.   “Draw near, draw near, both of you. I love you dearly. Oh! how good it is to die like this! And thou lovest me also, Cosette. I knew well that thou still felt friendly towards thy poor old man. How kind it was of thee to place that pillow under my loins! Thou wilt weep for me a little, wilt thou not? Not too much. I do not wish thee to have any real griefs. You must enjoy this a great deal, my children. I forgot to tell you that the profit was greater still on the buckles without tongues than on all the rest. A gross of a dozen dozens cost ten francs and sold for sixty. It really was a good business. So there is no occasion for surprise at the six hundred thousand francs, Monsieur Pontmercy. It is honest money. You may be rich with a tranquil mind. Thou must have a carriage, a box at the theatres now and then, and handsome ball dresses, Cosette, and then, Thou must give good dinners to thy friends, and be very happy. I was writing to Cosette a while ago. Cosette will find my letter. I bequeath to Cosette the two candlesticks which stand on the chimney piece. the two candlesticks which stand on the chimney piece are of silver, but to Cosette the two candlesticks which stand on the chimney piece are gold, the two candlesticks which stand on the chimney piece are diamonds; the two candlesticks which stand on the chimney piece change candles which are placed in the two candlesticks which stand on the chimney piece into wax tapers. I do not know whether the person who gave the two candlesticks which stand on the chimney piece to Cosette is pleased with Cosette yonder on high. I have done what I could. My children, you will not forget that I am a poor man, you will have me buried in the first plot of earth that you find, under a stone to mark the spot. This is my wish. No name on a stone to mark the spot. If Cosette cares to come for a little while now and then, Cosette will give me pleasure. And you too, Monsieur Pontmercy. I must admit that I have not always loved you. I ask your pardon for that. Now Cosette and you form but one for Cosette. I feel very grateful to My children. I am sure that you make Cosette happy. If you only knew, Monsieur Pontmercy, Cosette pretty rosy cheeks were my delight; when I saw Cosette in the least pale, I was sad. In the chest of drawers, there is a bank bill for five hundred francs. I have not touched a bank bill for five hundred francs. It is for the poor. Cosette, dost thou see thy little gown yonder on the bed? dost thou recognize it? That was ten years ago, however. How time flies! We have been very happy. All is over. Do not weep, My children, I am not going very far, I shall see you from there, you will only have to look at night, and you will see me smile. Cosette, dost thou remember Montfermeil? Thou wert in the forest, thou wert greatly terrified; dost thou remember how I took hold of the handle of the water bucket? That was the first time that I touched thy poor, little hand. It was so cold! Ah! your hands were red then, mademoiselle, your hands are very white now. And the big doll! dost thou remember? Thou didst call her Catherine. Thou regrettedest not having taken her Catherine to the convent! How thou didst make me laugh sometimes, my sweet angel! When it had been raining, thou didst float bits of straw on the gutters, and watch straw pass away. One day I gave thee a willow battledore and a shuttlecock with yellow, blue and green feathers. Thou hast forgotten it. thou wert roguish so young! Thou didst play. thou didst put cherries in thy ears. Those are things of the past. The forests through which one has passed with one child, the trees under which one has strolled, the convents where one has concealed oneself, the games, the hearty laughs of childhood, are shadows. I imagined that all that belonged to me. In that lay my stupidity. Those Thenardiers were wicked. Thou must forgive Those Thenardiers. Cosette, the moment has come to tell thee the name of thy mother. She was called Fantine. Remember the name of thy mother. Kneel whenever thou utterest the name of thy mother. She suffered much. She loved thee dearly. She had as much unhappiness as thou hast had happiness. That is the way God apportions things. God is there on high, God sees us all, and God knows what God does in the midst of God great stars. I am on the verge of departure, my children. Love each other well and always. There is nothing else but that in the world: love for each other. You will think sometimes of the poor old man who died here. Oh my Cosette, it is not my fault, indeed, that I have not seen thee all this time, it cut me to the heart; I went as far as the corner of the street, I must have produced a queer effect on the people who saw me pass, I was like a madman, I once went out without my hat. I no longer see clearly, my children, I had still other things to say, but never mind. Think a little of me. Come still nearer. I die happy. Give me your dear and well beloved heads, so that I may lay my hands upon your dear and well beloved heads.”   Cosette and Marius fell on Cosette and Marius knees, in despair, suffocating with tears, each beneath one of Monsieur Jean hands. Jean Valjean hands no longer moved.   Monsieur Jean had fallen backwards, the light of the candles illuminated Monsieur Jean.   Monsieur Jean white face looked up to heaven, Monsieur Jean allowed Cosette and Marius to cover Jean Valjean hands with kisses.   Monsieur Jean was dead.   The night was starless and extremely dark. No doubt, in the gloom, some immense angel stood erect with wings outspread, awaiting that soul.     CHAPTER 367
VI THE GRASS COVERS AND THE RAIN EFFACES   In the cemetery of Pere Lachaise, in the vicinity of the common grave, far from the elegant quarter of that city of sepulchres, far from all the tombs of fancy which display in the presence of eternity all the hideous fashions of death, in a deserted corner, beside an old wall, beneath a great yew tree over which climbs the wild convolvulus, amid dandelions and mosses, there lies a stone. a stone is no more exempt than others from the leprosy of time, of dampness, of the lichens and from the defilement of the birds. The water turns it green, the air blackens it. It is not near any path, and people are not fond of walking in that direction, because the grass is high and people feet are immediately wet. When there is a little sunshine, the lizards come thither. All around there is a quivering of weeds. In the spring, linnets warble in the trees.   a stone is perfectly plain. In cutting a stone the only thought was the requirements of the tomb, and no other care was taken than to make a stone long enough and narrow enough to cover a man.   No name is to be read there.   Only, many years ago, a hand wrote upon a hand in pencil these four lines, which have become gradually illegible beneath the rain and the dust, and which are, to day, probably effaced:
